column1: question

A spacecraft is launched vertically upward from the surface ($z = 0$) of a spherically symmetric planet of radius $R_p = 6.00 \\\\times 10^{6}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{m}$ and mass $M_p = 6.00 \\\\times 10^{24}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{kg}$. The launch point is defined as $x = 0, \\\\ z = 0$, with the $+z$ axis radially outward from the planet's center. The planet is non-rotating; its gravitational field is purely central ($\\\\vec{g}(\\\\vec{r}) = -\\\\dfrac{G M_p}{r^2} \\\\hat{r}$ for $r = R_p + z$; $G = 6.67430 \\\\times 10^{-11}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{m}^3\\\\,\\\\mathrm{kg}^{-1}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{s}^{-2}$). There is no atmosphere and no planetary rotation. \\n\\nThe spacecraft starts from rest with an initial total mass (including the capsule; see below) $M_0 = 2.80 \\\\times 10^5\\\\,\\\\mathrm{kg}$ and burns fuel by expelling mass downward at constant exhaust speed $v_{\\\\mathrm{ex}} = 3.00 \\\\times 10^3\\\\,\\\\mathrm{m/s}$, providing a constant upward thrust $F_{\\\\mathrm{th}} = 4.00 \\\\times 10^6\\\\,\\\\mathrm{N}$ (magnitude and direction, always along $+z$). The only external force during ascent is gravity; the thrust vector always passes through the center of mass. The propellant flow rate is $\\\\dot{m} = -F_{\\\\mathrm{th}}/v_{\\\\mathrm{ex}}$ (constant in time). \\n\\nAt $z_{\\\\mathrm{sep}} = 2.50 \\\\times 10^5\\\\,\\\\mathrm{m}$ altitude (i.e., height above the surface; so $r_{\\\\mathrm{sep}} = R_p + z_{\\\\mathrm{sep}}$), the rocket's total mass (including the capsule) has decreased to $M_{\\\\mathrm{sep}} = 1.40 \\\\times 10^5\\\\,\\\\mathrm{kg}$. At this instant, a small escape capsule of mass $m_c = 4.00 \\\\times 10^3\\\\,\\\\mathrm{kg}$ and net charge $Q = 3.00 \\\\times 10^3\\\\,\\\\mathrm{C}$ is instantaneously ejected upward along $+z$ (locally radially outward) from the hull at relative speed $u_0 = 150\\\\,\\\\mathrm{m/s}$ with respect to the center of mass of the remainder of the spacecraft. \\n\\nAssume: The quoted $M_{\\\\mathrm{sep}}$ includes the mass of the capsule immediately prior to separation. Immediately at separation, neglect any external impulses; the capsule and residual spacecraft move along $z$ with velocities $v_{z,\\\\mathrm{cap}}$ (capsule) and $v_{z,\\\\mathrm{sc}}$ (post-ejection main spacecraft) in the inertial planet frame. The total system momentum (in $z$) is conserved: \\n\\n\\\\begin{align*}\\nM_{\\\\mathrm{sep}} v_{\\\\mathrm{sep}} = m_c v_{z,\\\\mathrm{cap}} + (M_{\\\\mathrm{sep}} - m_c) v_{z,\\\\mathrm{sc}} \\n\\\\end{align*}\\n\\nwhere $v_{\\\\mathrm{sep}}$ is the vertical speed of the entire vehicle just before separation. The relative velocity of ejection is specified by\\n\\n\\\\begin{align*}\\nv_{z,\\\\mathrm{cap}} - v_{z,\\\\mathrm{sc}} = u_0.\\n\\\\end{align*}\\n\\nUsing these two equations, determine all necessary initial velocities.\\n\\nAfter separation, the capsule (treated as a point mass and point charge) is subject to:\\n(i) the planet's gravitational force $\\\\displaystyle \\\\vec{F}_g = -\\\\frac{G M_p m_c}{r^2} \\\\hat{r}$ with $r = \\\\sqrt{x^2 + (R_p + z)^2}$, acting toward the planet's center,\\n(ii) a uniform, constant electric field $\\\\vec{E}_0 = E_0 \\\\hat{z}$, $E_0 = 1.00 \\\\times 10^3\\\\,\\\\mathrm{V/m}$,\\n(iii) a uniform, constant magnetic field $\\\\vec{B}_0 = B_0 \\\\hat{y}$, $B_0 = 2.00 \\\\times 10^{-3}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{T}$.\\n\\nThroughout the capsule's trajectory, $\\\\vec{E}_0$ and $\\\\vec{B}_0$ are spatially uniform (unphysical over $>10^6$ m, but assume they persist everywhere without edge effects). Non-gravitational forces are always defined in reference to the $+x$ and $+z$ basis vectors, with electric field $E_0$ strictly along $+z$, and magnetic field $B_0$ strictly along $+y$. There is never any component along $x$ or $-z$.\\n\\nImmediately after ejection ($t=0$), the capsule's position is $x_0 = 0$, $z_0 = z_{\\\\mathrm{sep}}$, velocity components $(v_{x,0} = 0, \\\\ v_{z,0} = v_{z,\\\\mathrm{cap}})$ (all in the planet frame).\\n\\nThe capsule's equations of motion in the $x$-$z$ plane are:\\n\\n\\\\begin{align*}\\n\\\\frac{d^2 x}{dt^2} &= \\\\frac{Q}{m_c} \\\\left( -\\\\frac{dz}{dt} B_0 \\\\right) \\\\\\\\[1em]\\n\\\\frac{d^2 z}{dt^2} &= \\\\frac{Q}{m_c}\\\\left( E_0 + \\\\frac{dx}{dt} B_0 \\\\right) - \\\\frac{G M_p (R_p + z)}{[x^2 + (R_p + z)^2]^{3/2}}\\n\\\\end{align*}\\n\\nwhere the $z$-component of gravity always points to the planet's center ($-\\\\hat{z}$ for $x=0$) and the Lorentz-force terms are correctly signed for $v_x \\\\hat{x}$ and $v_z \\\\hat{z}$ motions, $B_0$ along $\\\\hat{y}$.\\n\\nNeglect all forms of drag, radiation, relativistic, and rotational effects. The capsule remains well above the planet's surface at all times considered.\\n\\nThe trajectory is followed from $t = 0$ until the capsule's altitude $z$ (height above the surface) first reaches $z_d = 1.00 \\\\times 10^6\\\\,\\\\mathrm{m}$ (i.e., when $z(t_f) = z_d$ for the earliest $t_f > 0$).\\n\\nDefine the arc length of the capsule's flight in the $x$-$z$ plane from launch to $z = z_d$ as:\\n\\n\\\\[\\nL = \\\\int_0^{t_f} \\\\sqrt{ \\\\left( \\\\frac{dx}{dt} \\\\right)^2 + \\\\left( \\\\frac{dz}{dt} \\\\right)^2 }\\\\,dt\\n\\\\]\\n\\n\\\\textbf{Question:} Compute the unique numerical value of the total arc length $L$ the capsule travels from the instant of ejection to the moment $z = z_d = 1.00 \\\\times 10^6\\\\,\\\\mathrm{m}$ (above the surface), using all parameters explicitly provided. Express your answer in \\\\textbf{meters} to three significant digits.\

A precision kinematics experiment is conducted on a perfectly horizontal track aligned with the laboratory $x$-axis. A cart moves strictly along $+x$ under a constant, uniform acceleration $a$ (with known mean $\\\\bar{a}$ and standard uncertainty $\\\\sigma_a$) from an initial position $x_0 = 0$ and starts from rest at $t=0$. The cart's deck defines the launch plane and is maintained at a fixed vertical height $H$ above a level, horizontal floor (both $H$ and its uncertainty $\\\\sigma_H$ are given). At measurement time $t_1$, determined by an electronic timer with value $\\\\bar{t}_1$ and standard uncertainty $\\\\sigma_{t_1}$, the cart's deck position is $x_1$. At $t_1$, a small spherical projectile is launched from rest relative to the cart deck at the deck's leading edge (the projectile's initial $z$-coordinate equals $H$; treat the size as negligible), with velocity components in the laboratory frame defined as follows:  \\n\\n- The launch velocity in the $x$-direction $u_x$ is the sum of the cart's instantaneous velocity at $t_1$ (i.e., $u_{\\\\text{cart}} = a t_1$) and a known relative velocity imparted by the launcher fixed to the cart, $u'_x$. Thus, $u_x = u_{\\\\text{cart}} + u'_x$. The sign convention is: $u'_x > 0$ when the projectile is launched forward (same direction as $+x$), $u'_x < 0$ if launched rearward relative to the cart.\\n- The vertical launch velocity $u_z$ (along the $z$-axis, positive upward) is given by $u'_z$.  \\n\\nThe vertical axis $z$ points up. The horizontal axis $x$ is along the floor. The projectile is modelled as a point mass, and air resistance is negligible. Local gravitational acceleration $g$ is downward (points $-z$), with known mean $\\\\bar{g}$ and standard uncertainty $\\\\sigma_g$. All uncertainties are independent and Gaussian. The projectile follows a ballistic trajectory, lands at time $t_2$ at position $(x_2,\\, z=0)$ on the floor.\\n\\nExperimental parameters:\\n\\\\begin{align*}\\n&\\\\text{Cart acceleration:}\\\\qquad &&\\\\bar{a} = 0.425\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m/s^2}, & \\\\sigma_a &= 0.003\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m/s^2} \\\\\\\\\\n&\\\\text{Launch time:}\\\\qquad &&\\\\bar{t}_1 = 15.0\\\\ \\\\mathrm{s}, & \\\\sigma_{t_1} &= 0.02\\\\ \\\\mathrm{s} \\\\\\\\\\n&\\\\text{Deck height above floor:}\\\\qquad &&\\\\bar{H} = 2.500\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}, & \\\\sigma_H &= 0.004\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m} \\\\\\\\\\n&\\\\text{Launcher imparted velocity ($+x$ is forward):}&&\\\\bar{u}'_x = +2.90\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m/s}, & \\\\sigma_{u'_x} &= 0.03\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m/s} \\\\\\\\\\n&\\\\text{Launcher imparted vertical velocity ($+z$ is upward):}&&\\\\bar{u}'_z = 6.45\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m/s}, & \\\\sigma_{u'_z} &= 0.04\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m/s} \\\\\\\\\\n&\\\\text{Local gravity:}\\\\qquad &&\\\\bar{g} = 9.807\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m/s^2}, & \\\\sigma_g &= 0.002\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m/s^2} \\\\\\\\ \\\\end{align*}\\n\\nAt time $t_1$, the position of the cart's deck (and hence the launch point) is $x_1 = \\\\tfrac{1}{2} a t_1^2$; uncertainty in $x_1$ follows from propagation of $\\\\sigma_a$ and $\\\\sigma_{t_1}$.  The laboratory-frame projectile launch velocity is $u_x = a t_1 + u'_x$ (uncertainties properly propagated); the vertical velocity at launch is $u_z = u'_z$.\\n\\nDefine the *measured range* $R$ as the total horizontal distance between the projectile's landing point $x_2$ (where $z=0$) and its launch point $x_1$, i.e., $R = x_2 - x_1$. Here, $x_2$ is computed from ballistic kinematics:\\n\\\\begin{align*}\\n\\\\Delta t &= t_2 - t_1 ~~\\\\text{where $\\\\Delta t$ satisfies}~~ 0 = H + u_z \\\\Delta t - \\\\tfrac{1}{2} g \\\\Delta t^2 \\\\\\\\\\nx_2 &= x_1 + u_x \\\\Delta t\\n\\\\end{align*}\\nThus $R = u_x \\\\Delta t$.\\n\\nExplicitly perform *first-order uncertainty propagation* to determine the standard uncertainty $\\\\sigma_R$ in the measured projectile range $R$, accounting for all relevant uncertainties ($\\\\sigma_a,\\\\,\\\\sigma_{t_1},\\\\,\\\\sigma_H,\\\\,\\\\sigma_{u'_x},\\\\,\\\\sigma_{u'_z},\\\\,\\\\sigma_g$). Use the physical solution for $\\\\Delta t > 0$. Ignore all covariances (independent variables). Express your final answer for $\\\\sigma_R$ in $\\\\mathrm{mm}$, rounded to the nearest $0.01\\\\ \\\\mathrm{mm}$.\\n\\n\\\\boxed{ \\\\sigma_R~[\\\\mathrm{mm}] = \\\\; ? }\\n\

A homogeneous cylindrical rod made of a metal has length $L = 2.500\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$, radius $r = 5.00 \\\\times 10^{-3}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$, electrical resistivity $\\\\rho = 1.70 \\\\times 10^{-8}\\\\ \\\\Omega\\\\cdot \\\\mathrm{m}$, Young's modulus $Y = 2.00 \\\\times 10^{11}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{Pa}$, and linear coefficient of thermal expansion $\\\\alpha = 1.20 \\\\times 10^{-5}~\\\\mathrm{K}^{-1}$. The rod is rigidly fixed at both ends so that its length cannot change. It is initially at temperature $T_0 = 293.0~\\\\mathrm{K}$ and is thermally insulated.\\\\n\\\\nAt time $t = 0$, a spatially uniform, time-dependent magnetic field $\\\\vec{B}(t) = B_0 \\\\cos(\\\\omega t)\\\\, \\\\hat{z}$, where $B_0 = 2.00~\\\\mathrm{T}$ and $\\\\omega = 314~\\\\mathrm{rad/s}$, is applied perpendicular to the rod axis (the $z$-direction; the rod axis is $x$). The magnetic field penetrates the entire rod uniformly. Assume the rod remains electrically continuous and homogeneous, with negligible skin effect at this frequency. \\\\n\\\\nThe field induces a circulating electric field around the rod's cross-section, driving an azimuthal current $I(\\\\theta, t)$ around the circumference at each cross-section (treat the current as flowing in a thin ring of radius $r$ at each point along $x$; ignore any current flow along the $x$-axis or outside the rod). Assume the total resistance for one loop around the circumference at any cross-section is $R = 2\\\\pi r \\\\rho / (\\\\pi r^2)$.\\\\n\\\\nAt time $t^{*}$ such that the rod's temperature (due entirely to energy dissipated by the induced currents) has risen to $T^{*} = 400.0~\\\\mathrm{K}$, the rod remains clamped and all properties ($\\\\rho, Y, \\\\alpha$) are unchanged.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\textbf{Given this, compute the \\\\emph{total energy} (in joules) dissipated by ohmic heating in the rod from $t = 0$ until the instant $t^*$ when the temperature reaches $400.0~\\\\mathrm{K}$, assuming all the induced current energy is absorbed solely by the rod (neglect losses to the environment), and the temperature is uniform at all times. Express your answer to four significant digits.}\\n\

A planar double pendulum consists of two point masses, $m_1 = 2.10~\\\\mathrm{kg}$ and $m_2 = 1.45~\\\\mathrm{kg}$, connected by massless, rigid rods of lengths $l_1 = 0.680~\\\\mathrm{m}$ and $l_2 = 0.440~\\\\mathrm{m}$, respectively. The first rod is attached to a fixed, inertial ceiling at a frictionless hinge; the second rod is connected via a frictionless hinge to $m_1$. A viscous damping torque $\\\\tau = -b\\\\,\\\\dot{\\\\theta}_2$ acts only at the second joint, with $b = 0.092~\\\\mathrm{N\\\\,m\\\\,s}$. The rods are held fixed so that both are horizontal ($\\\\theta_1 = \\\\theta_2 = \\\\tfrac{\\\\pi}{2}$) and released from rest at $t=0$.\\n\\nAssume:\\n\\\\begin{itemize}\\n  \\\\item The rods are massless, infinitely rigid, and the motion is planar.\\n  \\\\item Air resistance and other friction are negligible.\\n  \\\\item The only nonconservative force is the damper at the second joint.\\n  \\\\item During the initial swing, the angular displacements remain below $90^\\\\circ$; you may apply full nonlinear dynamics.\\n  \\\\item For this problem, the instantaneous speed $v$ of $m_2$ the \\\\emph{first time} it passes directly below the ceiling (i.e., when $\\\\theta_1 = 0$ and $\\\\theta_2 = 0$) is to be approximated by assuming energy conservation between release and this configuration, minus the small amount of energy dissipated by the damper, which is to be computed using the undamped motion as a first approximation for $\\\\dot{\\\\theta}_2$ over this interval.\\n\\\\end{itemize}\\n\\nAt the bottom position ($\\\\theta_1=0$, $\\\\theta_2=0$), $m_2$ carries an ideal point-like LED (Gaussian emission, $\\\\lambda_0 = 460~\\\\mathrm{nm}$, FWHM $\\\\Delta\\\\lambda = 30~\\\\mathrm{nm}$). A thin, plano-convex lens (aperture $D=2.00~\\\\mathrm{cm}$, convex radius $R=4.00~\\\\mathrm{cm}$) of glass ($n_{\\\\text{blue}}=1.530$ at $460~\\\\mathrm{nm}$, $n_{\\\\text{red}}=1.520$ at $650~\\\\mathrm{nm}$) is placed with its plano face toward the LED, perpendicular to the pendulum, with its center $d = 2.20~\\\\mathrm{m}$ from $m_2$'s vertical path. The lens and LED are at the same height; the lens is fully illuminated. Across from the lens, $L = 4.20~\\\\mathrm{m}$ from the lens center, is a flat detection screen, also perpendicular to the beam. Let ambient air have $n_{\\\\text{air}} = 1.000$.\\n\\nAssume:\\n\\\\begin{itemize}\\n  \\\\item The screen is placed exactly at the paraxial focused image plane for $\\\\lambda_0$ (i.e., no defocus for blue).\\n  \\\\item Spherical aberration arises from the plano-convex lens, with its plano surface facing the object; use third-order (Seidel) approximation for the RMS image radius due to spherical aberration: $r_{\\\\mathrm{SA}} \\\\approx \\\\tfrac{1}{8\\\\sqrt{5}} D^3 L /(f_0^2 R)$, where $f_0$ is the focal length at $\\\\lambda_0$ and $R$ is the convex-surface radius.\\n  \\\\item Chromatic blur arises because $f(\\\\lambda)$ varies over the LED's spectrum. Between $460~\\\\mathrm{nm}$ and $650~\\\\mathrm{nm}$, assume $n(\\\\lambda)$ is linear in $\\\\lambda$; convert FWHM to standard deviation $\\\\sigma_\\\\lambda$ using Gaussian properties. The net RMS chromatic blur in the image plane is $r_{\\\\mathrm{CA}} = \\\\left| \\\\frac{\\\\mathrm{d}f}{\\\\mathrm{d}\\\\lambda} \\\\right|_{\\\\lambda_0} \\\\sigma_\\\\lambda L / f_0$.\\n  \\\\item During instantaneous emission at $\\\\theta_1=\\\\theta_2=0$, the velocity $v$ imparts a forward aberration. To leading order, for $v\\\\ll c$, the RMS image shift due to this effect is $r_{\\\\mathrm{rel}} = v L / (c f_0)$.\\n  \\\\item The total RMS blur on the screen is $r_{\\\\mathrm{rms}} = \\\\sqrt{ r_{\\\\mathrm{SA}}^2 + r_{\\\\mathrm{CA}}^2 + r_{\\\\mathrm{rel}}^2 }$.\\n\\\\end{itemize}\\n\\nConstants: $g = 9.80665~\\\\mathrm{m/s^2}$, $c = 2.99792458\\\\times10^8~\\\\mathrm{m/s}$, $h = 6.62607015\\\\times10^{-34}~\\\\mathrm{J\\\\cdot s}$; Planck's constant is provided for reference, but not required here.\\n\\nCompute the \\\\textbf{total root-mean-square image radius on the screen} (RMS, including spherical aberration, chromatic blur, and relativistic effect), $r_{\\\\mathrm{rms}}$, in $\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{m}$, to four significant digits. Give your answer as:\\n\\\\[\\\\boxed{ r_{\\\\mathrm{rms}} = \\\\text{(numeric value)}~\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{m} }\\\\]\\n\\\\noindent All calculations must follow the definitions and methods above; all required physical constants and parameters are given.\

A parallel-plate capacitor is constructed with two identical, perfectly conducting plates, each of area $A = 2.50 \\\\times 10^{-2}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}^2$, facing one another and separated by a fixed gap $d = 1.00 \\\\times 10^{-2}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$. The plate length (distance along the $x$-axis), $L = 1.00\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$, and width (along the $y$-axis), $w = 2.50 \\\\times 10^{-2}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$, are such that $A = Lw$. The capacitor is kept at a constant potential difference $V = 2250\\\\ \\\\mathrm{V}$ using an ideal, infinite-capacity voltage source. \\n\\nA rectangular dielectric slab has length $\\\\ell = 0.500\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$ (along $x$), width $w$ (matching the plate width), height $h = d$ (matching the plate separation), relative permittivity $\\\\varepsilon_r = 6.00$, and mass $m = 0.200\\\\ \\\\mathrm{kg}$. The slab fits precisely between the plates so that its cross-sectional face ($hw$) at every $x$ completely fills the gap between plates with no edge gaps or overlap at the sides. Initially, the slab is held fixed such that a length $x_0 = 0.100\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$ projects into the capacitor, with $0 < x_0 < \\\\ell < L$, and the remainder stays outside ($0 < x < L$ marks slab entry).\\n\\nA small steel ball of mass $M = 0.0250\\\\ \\\\mathrm{kg}$ is aligned on a low-friction, horizontal, straight guide, so that it moves only along the $x$-axis and cannot rotate. It approaches the slab from outside the capacitor with initial velocity $u = 4.00\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m/s}$ directed toward the capacitor (positive $x$ direction). The slab is initially at rest ($v_{\\\\text{slab}} = 0$). All collisions are perfectly elastic and restricted to one dimension. The system is isolated from gravity, air resistance, friction, and any external forces. After the ball collides elastically with the slab, the slab moves deeper into the capacitor (all motion remains collinear and parallel to the plate faces).\\n\\nAs the slab advances further into the region between the plates, the electric force due to the constant potential $V$ acts to pull the slab further in. However, the slab's post-collision kinetic energy must eventually be entirely converted to electrostatic work increasing the capacitor's stored energy. When this happens, the slab momentarily comes to rest at a position such that the length of slab within the capacitor is $x_1$. Fringe effects and edge fields are neglected. All parameters are chosen to ensure the slab never protrudes beyond the far edge ($x_1 < L$) and the ball does not re-collide. The vacuum permittivity is $\\\\varepsilon_0 = 8.854 \\\\times 10^{-12}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{F/m}$.\\n\\n**Explicit final question:**\\n\\nCalculate, to three significant figures, the maximum length $x_1$ (in meters) of the dielectric slab inside the capacitor before it momentarily comes to rest after the collision. Express your final answer in SI units:\\n\\n\\\\[\\n\\\\boxed{x_1\\\\ \\\\mathrm{[m]}}\\n\\\\]\\n\

A rigid, uniform, thin, conducting circular ring of radius $R = 0.150\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$, total mass $M = 0.340\\\\ \\\\mathrm{kg}$, and total charge $Q = 3.80 \\\\times 10^{-6}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{C}$ is centered and constrained to rotate about the $z$-axis in the $xy$-plane. The ring is initially at rest. It is placed in a region where there exists a uniform, constant magnetic field $\\\\vec{B}_0 = B_0\\\\,\\\\hat{z}$ with $B_0 = 1.00\\\\ \\\\mathrm{T}$, and a perpendicular uniform electric field $\\\\vec{E}_0 = E_0 \\\\, \\\\hat{x}$ with $E_0 = 7.50 \\\\times 10^4\\\\ \\\\mathrm{V/m}$. Gravity and other fields are negligible.\\n\\nAt time $t = 0$, a short, uniform current pulse $I$ is applied through the ring via sliding contacts along its full circumference for a total time $\\\\Delta t = 3.30 \\\\times 10^{-4}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{s}$; this pulse establishes an angular velocity $\\\\omega_0$ in the ring, which is then left to rotate freely. During and after the pulse, the magnetic and electric fields remain constant and uniform everywhere.\\n\\nAfter the current pulse ends (for $t > \\\\Delta t$), the ring is isolated, and no external torques act except those from the electromagnetic fields. The ring remains conducting, and its charge $Q$ is uniformly distributed at all times. Neglect mechanical friction and radiation losses.\\n\\nImmediately after the current pulse ends, calculate the magnitude of the time derivative of the total angular momentum of the ring about its axis, $\\\\left|\\\\frac{d\\\\vec{L}}{dt}\\\\right|$, due solely to the net electromagnetic torque from the external $\\\\vec{E}_0$ and $\\\\vec{B}_0$ fields acting on the moving charged ring. Provide your answer as a decimal to three significant digits in $\\\\boxed{\\\\mathrm{N\\\\, m\\\\, s}}$.\\n\\nUse $\\\\mu_0 = 4\\\\pi \\\\times 10^{-7}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{N\\\\,A}^{-2}$. Do not include any angular momentum from the fields themselves\u2014consider only the mechanical angular momentum of the ring.\

A uniform solid sphere of mass $m = 2.00\\\\ \\\\mathrm{kg}$, radius $r = 0.0500\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$, and **positive** net charge $q = +1.50\\\\ \\\\mathrm{\\\\mu C}$ is attached by a massless, rigid, non-conducting rod of length $L = 0.700\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$ to a frictionless pivot $O$ located vertically a distance $H = 0.750\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$ above a perfectly rigid, horizontal, insulating floor. The sphere is suspended so that, at rest, it *just touches* the floor at a single point, with the rod held taut and making an angle $\\\\theta$ with the vertical, where $\\\\cos\\\\theta = \\\\frac{H - r}{L}$. \\n\\nThe system is set into steady uniform rotation about the vertical axis passing through $O$ with constant angular speed $\\\\Omega = 6.00\\\\ \\\\mathrm{rad/s}$, so that the rod sweeps a horizontal circle of radius $R = L\\\\sin\\\\theta$ and the sphere maintains continuous, single-point contact with the floor, moving around the circle without slipping and **freely rotating** about its own center as needed (pure rolling). Assume:\\n\\n- The coefficient of static friction between the sphere and the floor is $\\\\mu_s = 0.250$.\\n- The floor exerts **only normal and static friction forces** on the sphere, both acting at the contact point.\\n- The only externally applied fields are gravitational ($g = 9.806\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m/s^2}$, downward) and a uniform **downward** electric field ($\\\\vec{E} = -E\\\\hat{z}$ with $E = 1.20 \\\\times 10^5\\\\ \\\\mathrm{V/m}$); air resistance is negligible.\\n- The sphere **rolls without slipping** at all times.\\n- The rod is always straight and taut; its own mass and charge are negligible.\\n- All torques and forces from the rod are transmitted through the pivot point $O$.\\n- The direction $\\\\hat{z}$ is vertically upward, and all forces/fields use this reference.\\n\\n**(a)** Calculate the precise magnitude of the *normal force* $N$ (in newtons) that the floor exerts on the sphere *at the instant just before slipping occurs* (i.e., when the static friction force equals its maximal value $f_{s,\\\\max} = \\\\mu_s N$). Give your answer to three significant digits.\\n\\n\\\\[\\n\\\\boxed{N =\\\\ \\\\ ?\\\\qquad [\\\\mathrm{N}]}\\n\\\\]\

A vertical cylindrical organ pipe of physical length $L = 2.520\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$ and inner radius $r = 0.0650\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$ is mounted with its lower end closed and upper end open, fixed to the floor of an elevator car. The elevator and all its contents are initially at rest at ground level ($z = 0$), then, at time $t = 0$, the car accelerates \\\\,\\\\textbf{upward} with constant acceleration $a_{E} = 4.20\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m\\\\,s^{-2}}$ relative to inertial ground-fixed axes, through \\\\,\\\\textbf{ambient, quiescent air}. The elevator is \\\\textbf{open to the ambient atmosphere} at all times; assume air inside and outside the pipe remains stationary in the Earth's frame and atmospheric stratification is negligible for up to 250~m vertical travel.\\n\\nAt time $t_{S} = 8.00\\\\ \\\\mathrm{s}$, when the elevator car has reached height $z_{S}$ (to be determined), a sound pulse at the pipe's fundamental frequency $f_{S}$ is emitted \\\\textbf{vertically upward} from the open end of the pipe. The resonance frequency $f_{S}$ is set by ambient atmospheric properties; apply the correct acoustic end correction for a \\\\textbf{closed-open pipe}: effective length $L_{\\\\mathrm{eff}} = L + 0.30\\\\, r$. Atmospheric air is \\\\textbf{ideal, dry}, with uniform molar mass $M = 0.02895\\\\ \\\\mathrm{kg\\\\,mol^{-1}}$, specific heat ratio $\\\\gamma = 1.400$, and universal gas constant $R = 8.314\\\\ \\\\mathrm{J\\\\,mol^{-1}\\\\,K^{-1}}$, at uniform temperature $T_{0} = 295.0\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K}$. Gravitational acceleration is $g = 9.80665\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m\\\\,s^{-2}}$.\\n\\nA stationary observer is fixed at $z_O = 220.0\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$ above ground, exactly above the elevator shaft. The elevator's open end at pulse emission is below the observer ($z_{S} < z_{O}$); the sound travels through still air at the speed of sound $v_{\\\\mathrm{sound}}$ as set by the stated gas properties, without refraction or wind. At the moment the pulse passes $z_{S}$, the elevator's upwards velocity is $v_{E} = a_{E} t_{S}$.\\n\\n(i) Calculate the Doppler-shifted frequency $f_{O}$ observed at $z_{O}$, given that (A) the pipe acts as a \\\\textbf{source moving upward} at velocity $v_{E}$, (B) the observer is stationary in the ground frame, and (C) the correct sign/convention for a source moving away from the observer is used. (ii) Neglect relativistic and atmospheric dispersion/stratification effects. Express your answer numerically to \\\\textbf{four decimal places} in SI units (Hz):\\n\\n\\\\[\\n\\\\boxed{f_{O} = \\\\;\\\\;\\\\underline{\\\\hspace{60pt}}\\\\; \\\\mathrm{Hz}}\\n\\\\]\\n\\n\\\\textbf{Note:} All intermediate reasoning\u2014including kinematics, pipe resonance, sound speed determination, and application of the Doppler effect\u2014should be incorporated to arrive at the final result for $f_{O}$ only.\

A parallel-plate capacitor consists of two plates of area $A = 5.00 \\\\times 10^{-2}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}^2$ separated by a distance $d = 2.00 \\\\times 10^{-3}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$ in vacuum. The capacitor is charged by an ideal voltage source to a constant potential $V_0 = 1000\\\\ \\\\mathrm{V}$, then disconnected so that the total charge $Q$ on the plates remains constant. \\n\\nA dielectric slab of thickness $d$, width $w = 0.250\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$, and length $\\\\ell = 0.100\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$ (so that $A = w \\\\times 2\\\\ell$), made of material with dielectric constant $\\\\kappa = 9.00$ and mass $m = 0.0500\\\\ \\\\mathrm{kg}$, is placed between the plates such that at $t=0$ it entirely fills the region $0 \\\\leq x \\\\leq \\\\ell$ (along the $x$-direction) and sits flush against the $x=0$ edge. The remaining region $\\\\ell < x < 2\\\\ell$ between the plates is vacuum. At $t=0$, the slab is released from rest and allowed to accelerate freely into the capacitor, moving only along the $x$-direction with negligible friction. The plates are sufficiently wide ($w$) such that edge effects can be ignored; gravity is negligible, and the slab fits tightly without gaps between plates.\\n\\nThe system is isolated (the capacitor remains disconnected from any voltage or charge reservoir after charging), and the only forces on the slab are electromagnetic. The slab acquires kinetic energy by being attracted into the region between the plates, while the electrostatic energy of the system decreases to conserve total energy.\\n\\nThe capacitance as a function of the slab's position $x$ (where $x$ is the distance the slab has fully entered the capacitor, so when $x=0$ the slab is just entering, and when $x=\\\\ell$ it is fully inside) is:\\n\\\\[\\nC(x) = \\\\epsilon_0 \\\\frac{w d}{d} \\\\left[(2\\\\ell - x) + x \\\\kappa \\\\right] = \\\\epsilon_0 w \\\\left[(2\\\\ell - x) + x \\\\kappa \\\\right].\\n\\\\]\\n\\nThe slab is released from rest and moves under the electrostatic force until it is fully inside the capacitor $(x = \\\\ell)$. Internal friction, air resistance, and all other losses are negligible. Assume the process is sufficiently slow that the system is always electrostatically quasi-static (no radiation).\\n\\nPhysical constants:\\n\\\\begin{align*}\\n\\\\epsilon_0 &= 8.854 \\\\times 10^{-12}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{F/m} \\\\\\\\\\nm &= 0.0500\\\\ \\\\mathrm{kg} \\\\\\\\\\nA &= 5.00 \\\\times 10^{-2}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}^2 \\\\\\\\\\nd &= 2.00 \\\\times 10^{-3}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m} \\\\\\\\\\nw &= 0.250\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m} \\\\\\\\\\n\\\\ell &= 0.100\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m} \\\\\\\\\\n\\\\kappa &= 9.00 \\\\\\\\\\nV_0 &= 1000\\\\ \\\\mathrm{V}\\n\\\\end{align*}\\n\\n\\\\noindent\\\\textbf{Calculate the final speed $v_f$ (in $\\\\mathrm{m/s}$) of the center of mass of the dielectric slab when it is fully inserted into the capacitor $(x=\\\\ell)$. Provide your answer numerically with three significant figures and include the correct SI unit.}\

A cosmological probe deploys a detector on the surface of a non-rotating neutron star of mass $M_*$ and radius $R_*$, in Schwarzschild spacetime. The detector is a hollow right circular cylindrical calorimeter (length $L$, inner radius $R_1$, outer radius $R_2$) made of $m_\\\\text{cal}$ of Type-II superconducting niobium ($^{93}_{41}\\\\text{Nb}$). A static, externally generated magnetic field fills the bore $(R_1 \\\\leq r \\\\leq R_2)$ with field profile $\\\\mathbf{B}(r) = B_0 \\\\frac{R_1}{r} \\\\hat{\\\\phi}$ for $R_1 \\\\leq r \\\\leq R_2$, $0 \\\\leq z \\\\leq L$. The local dark matter is axions of rest mass $m_a$ and mass density $\\\\rho_a$, which resonantly convert to photons in the field, heating the calorimeter. \\n\\nThe energy deposited over the laboratory interval $\\\\Delta t_\\\\text{lab}$ is\\n\\\\[ \\nQ = \\\\mathcal{K}\\\\, \\\\frac{g_{a\\\\gamma\\\\gamma}^2\\\\,\\\\rho_a}{m_a}\\\\, \\\\Delta t_\\\\text{lab} \\\\int_V B^2(r)\\\\,dV_{\\\\text{prop}} \\n\\\\]\\nwhere $g_{a\\\\gamma\\\\gamma}$ is the axion-photon coupling, $\\\\mathcal{K}$ a known system constant, and $dV_{\\\\text{prop}}$ the proper volume element in Schwarzschild spacetime on the star's surface:\\n\\\\[\\ndV_{\\\\text{prop}} = \\\\alpha^2\\\\,2\\\\pi r\\\\,dr\\\\,dz\\\\hspace{4em} (\\\\alpha = \\\\sqrt{1-2GM_*/(c^2R_*)})\\n\\\\]\\n\\nThis energy is measured as a temperature rise $\\\\Delta T$ in the niobium, so small that a linear heat-capacity approximation is valid. The niobium heat capacity per mole is\\n\\\\[\\nC_{V,m}(T, P_*) = \\\\gamma(P_*) T + \\\\beta(P_*) T^3\\n\\\\]\\nwith $\\\\gamma(P_*) = \\\\gamma_0 (1 - \\\\alpha_N P_*)$ and $\\\\beta(P_*) = \\\\beta_0 / [1 + \\\\alpha_\\\\Theta P_*]^3$. Absolute coefficients are given: $\\\\gamma_0 = 7.80\\\\,\\\\mathrm{mJ\\\\cdot mol^{-1}\\\\cdot K^{-2}}$, $\\\\beta_0 = 0.0725\\\\,\\\\mathrm{mJ\\\\cdot mol^{-1}\\\\cdot K^{-4}}$. The pressure $P_*$, assumed uniform and purely hydrostatic, is applied to *all* the niobium, and the pressure relationships are taken valid up to the given value.\\n\\nThe calorimeter is maintained initially at $T_0$, and is thermally connected to a SQUID readout whose Josephson frequency shift $\\\\Delta f_{\\\\text{obs}}$ is observed remotely over a proper time interval $\\\\Delta t_{\\\\text{obs}} \\\\gg \\\\Delta t_{\\\\text{lab}}$. The SQUID has a single Josephson junction of resistance $R_n$, critical current $I_c(T, P)$, and is biased near zero voltage. For an infinitesimal temperature change, the critical current varies as\\n\\\\[\\nI_c(T, P_*) = \\\\frac{\\\\pi\\\\,\\\\Delta(T,P_*)}{2eR_n}\\n\\\\]\\nwhere\\n\\\\[\\n\\\\Delta(T, P_*) = 1.764\\\\,k_B\\\\,T_c(P_*) (1+\\\\delta_{sc})\\\\sqrt{1 - (T/T_c(P_*))^2}\\n\\\\]\\nand the pressure-corrected critical temperature is\\n\\\\[\\nT_c(P_*) = T_c(0) [1 - \\\\alpha_P P_*]\\n\\\\]\\nParameters $T_c(0)$ and $\\\\delta_{sc}$ are given. The Josephson relation between voltage and frequency applies at the observer,\\n\\\\[\\n\\\\Delta V_J = \\\\frac{h}{2e}\\\\,\\\\Delta f_{\\\\text{obs}}\\n\\\\]\\nAssume $\\\\Delta V_J = \\\\xi\\\\,\\\\Delta I_c$ with known $\\\\xi$ (the transfer coefficient).\\n\\nBoth laboratory and observer proper times are related by gravitational redshift:\\n\\\\[\\n\\\\Delta t_{\\\\text{obs}} = \\\\frac{\\\\Delta t_{\\\\text{lab}}}{\\\\alpha}\\\\hspace{2em} \\\\left(\\\\alpha = \\\\sqrt{1-2GM_*/(c^2R_*)}\\\\right)\\n\\\\]\\nAll device readouts measured by the observer should be interpreted using the above time dilation and redshift relations.\\n\\nAll numerical input values and physical constants are as follows (SI units unless noted):\\n$M_* = 1.40\\\\,M_\\\\odot \\\\;(M_\\\\odot = 1.989 \\\\times 10^{30}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{kg})$, \\\\;$R_* = 1.200 \\\\times 10^{4}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{m}$, \\\\;$P_* = 5.00 \\\\times 10^{15}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{Pa}$\\n$L = 0.500\\\\,\\\\mathrm{m}$, $R_1 = 0.0500\\\\,\\\\mathrm{m}$, $R_2 = 0.1000\\\\,\\\\mathrm{m}$\\n$m_{\\\\text{cal}} = 2.50\\\\,\\\\mathrm{kg}$, $R_n = 50.0\\\\,\\\\Omega$\\n$B_0 = 15.0\\\\,\\\\mathrm{T}$, $\\\\Delta t_{\\\\text{obs}} = 1000.0\\\\,\\\\mathrm{s}$\\n$\\\\mathcal{K} = 4.13 \\\\times 10^{-26}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{m^{-1}\\\\cdot s^{-1}}$\\n$\\\\gamma_0 = 7.80\\\\,\\\\mathrm{mJ\\\\,mol^{-1}\\\\,K^{-2}}$,\\n$\\\\beta_0 = 0.0725\\\\,\\\\mathrm{mJ\\\\,mol^{-1}\\\\,K^{-4}}$\\n$\\\\alpha_P = 2.50 \\\\times 10^{-18}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{Pa}^{-1}$, $\\\\alpha_N = 3.10 \\\\times 10^{-18}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{Pa}^{-1}$, $\\\\alpha_{\\\\Theta} = 1.20 \\\\times 10^{-18}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{Pa}^{-1}$\\n$T_c(0) = 9.25\\\\,\\\\mathrm{K}$, $\\\\delta_{sc} = 0.15$\\n$T_0 = 0.150\\\\,\\\\mathrm{K}$, $\\\\xi = 2.50 \\\\times 10^{5}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{V/A}$\\n$N_A = 6.022 \\\\times 10^{23}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{mol^{-1}}$, $M_{\\\\mathrm{mol}} = 92.906 \\\\times 10^{-3}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{kg\\\\,mol^{-1}}$\\n$\\\\rho_a = 0.45\\\\,\\\\mathrm{GeV}\\\\,c^{-2}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{cm}^{-3}$, $g_{a\\\\gamma\\\\gamma} = 5.00\\\\times 10^{-12}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{GeV}^{-1}$\\n$\\\\Delta f_{\\\\text{obs}} = 3.153\\\\,\\\\mathrm{Hz}$\\n$G = 6.674 \\\\times 10^{-11}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{m^3\\\\,kg^{-1}\\\\,s^{-2}}$, $c = 2.998 \\\\times 10^8\\\\,\\\\mathrm{m/s}$, $h = 6.626 \\\\times 10^{-34}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{J\\\\,s}$, $e = 1.602 \\\\times 10^{-19}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{C}$, $k_B = 1.381 \\\\times 10^{-23}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{J\\\\,K^{-1}}$\\n\\n**Question**: Using all the physics and relations above, compute the rest mass of the axion, $m_a$, in units of $\\\\mathrm{meV}/c^2$ (that is, millielectron-volts per $c^2$). Give your answer to three significant digits.\

A negative muon (\\\\(\\\\mu^-\\\\)) of rest mass \\\\(m_\\\\mu\\\\) and electric charge \\\\(q = -e\\\\), ignoring its decay, moves in a stable, circular, equatorial orbit (\\\\(\\\\theta = \\\\pi/2\\\\)) in the exterior spacetime of a non-rotating, electrically neutral black hole of mass \\\\(M\\\\). The spacetime is described by the Schwarzschild metric:\\n\\n\\\\[\\n ds^2 = -\\\\left(1 - \\\\frac{2GM}{c^2 r}\\\\right)c^2 dt^2 + \\\\left(1 - \\\\frac{2GM}{c^2 r}\\\\right)^{-1} dr^2 + r^2 (d\\\\theta^2 + \\\\sin^2\\\\theta d\\\\phi^2)\\n\\\\]\\n\\nA static, axisymmetric, test magnetic field is externally imposed, represented by the electromagnetic 4-potential \\\\(A_\\\\phi(r) = \\\\frac{1}{2}B_0 r^2\\\\) with all other components zero in standard Schwarzschild coordinates. Here, \\\\(B_0\\\\) is a (constant) field strength, assumed small enough that its contribution to the spacetime curvature is negligible (test-field limit). There is no electric field present. Assume the motion is planar (\\\\(\\\\theta = \\\\pi/2\\\\), \\\\(d\\\\theta=0\\\\)), and that the muon remains in a quasi-circular orbit, spiraling inwards due to radiative energy loss, with the process considered adiabatic (the instantaneous orbit at radius \\\\(r\\\\) is always the circular solution at that \\\\(r\\\\)).\\n\\n\\nThe canonical (conserved) specific energy \\\\(\\\\mathcal{E}(r)\\\\) and canonical specific angular momentum \\\\(\\\\mathcal{L}(r)\\\\) per unit rest mass \\\\(m_\\\\mu\\\\) of the muon are:\\n\\n\\\\[\\n\\\\mathcal{E}(r) = -\\\\frac{1}{m_\\\\mu}\\\\left( p_t + q A_t \\\\right) = -\\\\frac{1}{m_\\\\mu}g_{tt}\\\\,u^t \\n\\\\]\\n\\n\\\\[\\n\\\\mathcal{L}(r) = \\\\frac{1}{m_\\\\mu}\\\\left( p_\\\\phi + q A_\\\\phi(r) \\\\right) = \\\\frac{1}{m_\\\\mu}\\\\left[g_{\\\\phi\\\\phi}\\\\,u^\\\\phi + q A_\\\\phi(r)\\\\right]\\n\\\\]\\n\\nwhere \\\\(u^\\\\alpha = dx^\\\\alpha/d\\\\tau\\\\) is the muon's 4-velocity, and the canonical momenta are defined as \\\\(p_\\\\mu = m_\\\\mu u_\\\\mu + q A_\\\\mu\\\\).\\n\\nFor a charged particle in a Schwarzschild spacetime with an external, weak, uniform axial magnetic field as above, the equations of motion for equatorial circular orbits of radius \\\\(r\\\\) yield:\\n\\n\\\\[\\n\\\\mathcal{E}(r) = \\\\frac{\\\\left( 1 - \\\\frac{2GM}{c^2 r} \\\\right)^{1/2} }{\\\\sqrt{ 1 - \\\\frac{3GM}{c^2 r} - \\\\frac{q B_0}{m_\\\\mu} \\\\frac{GM r}{c^2} } }\\n\\\\]\\n\\n\\\\[\\n\\\\mathcal{L}(r) = \\\\frac{ \\\\frac{GM}{c}\\\\left[ r^2 + \\\\frac{q B_0}{2 m_\\\\mu}\\\\, r^4 \\\\right] }{ r^{3/2} c\\\\,\\\\sqrt{ 1 - \\\\frac{3GM}{c^2 r} - \\\\frac{q B_0}{m_\\\\mu} \\\\frac{GM r}{c^2} } } + \\\\frac{q B_0}{2 m_\\\\mu} r^2\\n\\\\]\\n\\nThe innermost stable circular orbit (ISCO) radius \\\\(r_{\\\\text{ISCO}}\\\\) is the smallest \\\\(r\\\\) for which circular orbits are stable (radial stability boundary), found by solving:\\n\\n\\\\[\\n\\\\frac{d^2 V_{\\\\text{eff}}}{dr^2}\\\\Bigg|_{r_{\\\\text{ISCO}}} = 0\\n\\\\]\\n\\nwhere the effective potential \\\\(V_{\\\\text{eff}}(r)\\\\) can be derived from the motion equations above. For this problem, take:\\n\\n\\\\[\\nr_{\\\\mathrm{ISCO}} = 6 \\\\frac{GM}{c^2} \\\\left( 1 - \\\\alpha \\\\; \\\\frac{q B_0\\\\;GM^2}{m_\\\\mu c^4} \\\\right)\\n\\\\]\\n\\nwhere \\\\(\\\\alpha = 5\\\\) (an empirically fitted factor for the weak-field, small-\\\\(B_0\\\\) regime), and all parameters are as defined above.\\n\\nThe muon radiates electromagnetic energy (synchrotron/synchrocurvature), with total radiated power as measured in its instantaneous rest frame given by the covariant Larmor formula:\\n\\n\\\\[\\nP_{\\\\text{rad}} = \\\\frac{\\\\mu_0 q^2}{6\\\\pi c} \\\\, a_\\\\mu a^\\\\mu\\n\\\\]\\n\\nwhere the 4-acceleration \\\\(a^\\\\mu = u^\\\\nu \\\\nabla_\\\\nu u^\\\\mu\\\\). For circular, planar orbits under combined Schwarzschild gravity and the above magnetic field, the magnitude squared of the 4-acceleration (invariant):\\n\\n\\\\[\\na_\\\\mu a^\\\\mu = \\\\gamma^4 \\\\left( a_{\\\\text{orb}} \\\\right)^2\\\\left( 1 - \\\\frac{2GM}{c^2 r} \\\\right)^{-1}\\n\\\\]\\n\\nwhere \\\\(\\\\gamma = u^t\\\\) and the locally-measured (proper) centripetal acceleration (modulus) is:\\n\\n\\\\[\\na_{\\\\text{orb}} = \\\\frac{1}{r} \\\\left[ v_{\\\\text{circ}}^2 \\\\right]\\n\\\\]\\n\\nThe local speed is related to the angular velocity \\\\(\\\\Omega\\\\) by \\\\(v_{\\\\text{circ}} = r \\\\Omega\\\\), and \\\\(\\\\Omega = \\\\frac{d \\\\phi}{dt} = \\\\frac{u^\\\\phi}{u^t}\\\\). For such orbits,\\n\\n\\\\[\\n\\\\Omega = \\\\frac{1}{r}\\\\sqrt{ \\\\frac{GM}{r} + \\\\frac{q B_0 c r}{2 m_\\\\mu} }\\n\\\\]\\n\\nGiven this, and the fact that the muon's orbit decays slowly (adiabatically), the orbital energy loss rate as measured by a distant observer is:\\n\\n\\\\[\\n\\\\frac{dE_{\\\\textrm{obs}}}{dt} = -P_{\\\\textrm{rad}} \\\\left( 1 - \\\\frac{2GM}{c^2 r} \\\\right)^{1/2}\\n\\\\]\\n\\nThe rate of change of orbital radius is then:\\n\\n\\\\[\\n\\\\frac{dr}{dt} = \\\\left( \\\\frac{d\\\\mathcal{E}}{dr} m_\\\\mu \\\\right)^{-1} \\\\frac{dE_{\\\\mathrm{obs}}}{dt}\\n\\\\]\\n\\nSuppose the black hole and field parameters are:\\n\\\\[\\n\\\\begin{align*}\\nM &= 4.31 \\\\times 10^6 \\\\, M_\\\\odot \\\\, \\\\; \\\\; (M_\\\\odot = 1.989 \\\\times 10^{30} \\\\/ \\\\mathrm{kg}) \\\\\\\\\\nB_0 &= 1.50 \\\\times 10^{-5} \\\\, \\\\mathrm{T} \\\\\\\\\\nm_\\\\mu &= 1.883531627 \\\\times 10^{-28} \\\\, \\\\mathrm{kg} \\\\\\\\\\ne &= 1.602176634 \\\\times 10^{-19} \\\\, \\\\mathrm{C} \\\\\\\\\\nc &= 2.99792458 \\\\times 10^8 \\\\, \\\\mathrm{m/s} \\\\\\\\\\nG &= 6.67430 \\\\times 10^{-11} \\\\, \\\\mathrm{m}^3 \\\\, \\\\mathrm{kg}^{-1} \\\\, \\\\mathrm{s}^{-2} \\\\\\\\\\n\\\\mu_0 &= 4\\\\pi \\\\times 10^{-7} \\\\, \\\\mathrm{T} \\\\cdot \\\\mathrm{m/A}\\n\\\\end{align*}\\n\\\\]\\n\\nThe muon starts from an initial circular orbit at \\\\(R_{\\\\textrm{init}} = 12 \\\\, \\\\frac{GM}{c^2}\\\\) and spirals inward to \\\\(R_{\\\\textrm{ISCO}}\\\\) as above under radiative losses. Neglect general-relativistic corrections to \\\\(A_\\\\phi\\\\) (take it as described), ignore the muon decay, consider only radiation reaction as the source of orbital evolution, and assume the test-particle limit (no self-gravity, no spacetime back-reaction). All orbital and local quantities are to be evaluated as a function of the instantaneous coordinate radius \\\\(r\\\\).\\n\\nCalculate the total coordinate time\\n\\\\[\\nT = \\\\int\\\\limits_{R_{\\\\mathrm{ISCO}}}^{R_{\\\\mathrm{init}}} \\\\frac{dr}{\\\\left| \\\\frac{dr}{dt} \\\\right|}\\n\\\\]\\nrequired for the muon to spiral inward from \\\\(R_{\\\\textrm{init}}\\\\) to \\\\(R_{\\\\textrm{ISCO}}\\\\), with all expressions and constants as above. Express your final answer numerically in seconds (\\\\(\\\\mathrm{s}\\\\)) to three significant digits.\

A solid, prismatic bar of Terfenol-D, with initial clamped length $L_0 = 0.25~\\\\text{m}$, width $w = 0.020~\\\\text{m}$, and thickness $h = 0.0050~\\\\text{m}$, is rigidly fixed at both ends against translation and rotation. Its long axis (length $L_0$) is defined as the $x$-axis. The bar sits inside a long solenoid whose axis aligns with $x$; the interior magnetic flux density is uniform and parallel to $x$ at all times. The bar forms the resistive element in a series $LCR$ circuit, connected via ideal, thermally insulated leads. At $t=0$, a pre-charged capacitor of capacitance $C = 100 \\\\times 10^{-6}~\\\\rm{F}$ and voltage $V_0 = 2.00 \\\\times 10^4~\\\\rm{V}$ is switched into series with an inductor $L = 25 \\\\times 10^{-6}~\\\\rm{H}$ and the bar. The circuit current $I(t)$ is defined positive in the clockwise direction. At $t=0$, $I(0) = 0$. The apparatus operates in an evacuated, perfectly adiabatic enclosure; the entire bar is initially at uniform temperature $T_0 = 300~\\\\text{K}$. Throughout, the bar remains spatially uniform in temperature, field, and magnetization. Neglect mechanical vibration, gravity, and all forms of energy exchange except those explicitly described. All quantities are in SI units unless noted. \\n\\n1. \\\\textbf{Electrical dynamics:} The loop obeys \\n\\\\begin{equation*}\\nL \\\\frac{dI}{dt} + R(T) I + \\\\frac{1}{C} \\\\int_0^t I(t') dt' = V_0\\n\\\\end{equation*}\\nwhere $R(T)$ is the resistance of the bar, which varies linearly with temperature as:\\n\\\\begin{equation*}\\nR(T) = \\\\frac{\\\\rho_{e,0} L_0}{w h} \\\\left[1 + \\\\alpha_R (T-T_0)\\\\right]\\n\\\\end{equation*}\\nThe initial resistivity is $\\\\rho_{e,0} = 6.0 \\\\times 10^{-7}~\\\\Omega\\\\,\\\\text{m}$ and $\\\\alpha_R = 1.5 \\\\times 10^{-3}~\\\\text{K}^{-1}$.\\n\\n2. \\\\textbf{Magnetic field:} The solenoid has $N = 9500$ turns per meter and carries the current $I(t)$ through the circuit, creating an axial uniform field through the bar given by\\\\n$B(t) = \\\\mu_0 N I(t)$, with $\\\\mu_0 = 4\\\\pi \\\\times 10^{-7}~\\\\rm{T}~\\\\rm{m/A}$. \\n\\n3. \\\\textbf{Magnetic equation of state:} The bar\u2019s uniform magnetization $M(t)$ (in $\\\\text{A/m}$) satisfies the mean-field Weiss model:\\n\\\\begin{equation*}\\nM = n \\\\mu_B \\\\tanh\\\\left[ \\\\frac{\\\\mu_B}{k_B T} \\\\left( B + \\\\lambda_W \\\\mu_0 M \\\\right) \\\\right]\\n\\\\end{equation*}\\nwhere \\n$n = 4.20 \\\\times 10^{28}~\\\\rm{m}^{-3}$ (number density of moments), \\n$\\\\mu_B = 9.27401 \\\\times 10^{-24}~\\\\text{J/T}$ (Bohr magneton), \\n$\\\\lambda_W = 950$, \\n$k_B = 1.380649 \\\\times 10^{-23}~\\\\text{J/K}$.\\n\\n4. \\\\textbf{Thermal dynamics:} The bar\u2019s temperature obeys\\n\\\\begin{equation*}\\nM_{\\\\rm{bar}} c_p \\\\frac{dT}{dt} = I^2 R(T) - \\\\mu_0 T V_{\\\\rm{bar}} \\\\left( \\\\frac{\\\\partial M}{\\\\partial T} \\\\right|_{B} \\\\frac{dB}{dt}\\n\\\\end{equation*}\\nwhere $M_{\\\\rm{bar}} = \\\\rho_m L_0 w h$ is the bar mass, $V_{\\\\rm{bar}} = L_0 w h$ its volume, \\n$\\\\rho_m = 9210~\\\\text{kg/m}^3$, $c_p = 330~\\\\text{J}\\\\cdot\\\\text{kg}^{-1}\\\\cdot\\\\text{K}^{-1}$, and $\\\\left.\\\\frac{\\\\partial M}{\\\\partial T}\\\\right|_B$ is computed by differentiating the implicit Weiss equation with all variables defined above, at fixed $B$.\\n\\n5. \\\\textbf{Longitudinal strain:} The total axial strain is $\\\\epsilon(t) = \\\\alpha_{\\\\rm{th}} (T(t)-T_0) + \\\\kappa M(t)^2$, with $\\\\alpha_{\\\\rm{th}} = 12 \\\\times 10^{-6}~\\\\text{K}^{-1}$. The bulk magnetostrictive strain coupling is $\\\\kappa = 2.50 \\\\times 10^{-11}~(\\\\text{A}\\\\,\\\\text{m}^{-1})^{-2}$ (ensuring $\\\\epsilon$ dimensionless when $M$ in $\\\\text{A/m}$).\\n\\n6. \\\\textbf{Axial stress:} The physically correct stress within the clamped bar is $\\\\sigma(t) = -Y \\\\epsilon(t)$, with $Y = 5.00 \\\\times 10^{10}~\\\\text{Pa}$, i.e., both heating and magnetostriction generate thermal expansion and positive magnetostrictive extension, but, with fixed ends, both produce compressive stresses. The sign convention is that $\\\\sigma > 0$ is compressive.\\n\\n7. \\\\textbf{Buckling criterion:} Buckling initiates when $\\\\sigma(t)$ first equals the Euler critical compressive stress for a fixed-fixed rectangular bar about the axis of minimum second moment (the $z$-axis, i.e., buckling out of plane of the thin face), given by\\n\\\\begin{equation*}\\n\\\\sigma_{\\\\rm{crit}} = \\\\frac{\\\\pi^2 Y}{(K L_0)^2} I_{\\\\rm{min}} / A\\n\\\\end{equation*}\\nwhere $K = 0.5$ (effective length factor for fixed\u2013fixed ends), $I_{\\\\rm{min}} = w h^3 / 12$ is the minimum area moment (about $z$), and $A = w h$ is the cross-sectional area. Poisson's ratio effects are neglected.\\n\\n\\\\textbf{Parameters Summary:}\\n\\\\begin{align*}\\nL_0 &= 0.250~\\\\text{m} & w &= 0.0200~\\\\text{m} & h &= 0.00500~\\\\text{m} \\\\\\\\\\nY &= 5.00 \\\\times 10^{10}~\\\\rm{Pa} & \\\\rho_m &= 9210~\\\\rm{kg/m}^3 & c_p &= 330~\\\\rm{J\\\\,kg}^{-1}\\\\rm{K}^{-1} \\\\\\\\\\n\\\\alpha_{\\\\rm{th}} &= 12 \\\\times 10^{-6}~\\\\rm{K}^{-1} & \\\\kappa &= 2.50 \\\\times 10^{-11}~(\\\\rm{A\\\\,m}^{-1})^{-2} & \\\\rho_{e,0} &= 6.00 \\\\times 10^{-7}~\\\\Omega \\\\rm{m} \\\\\\\\\\n\\\\alpha_R &= 1.5 \\\\times 10^{-3}~\\\\rm{K}^{-1} & N &= 9500~\\\\rm{turns/m} & C &= 1.00 \\\\times 10^{-4}~\\\\rm{F} \\\\\\\\\\nL &= 2.50 \\\\times 10^{-5}~\\\\rm{H} & V_0 &= 2.00 \\\\times 10^4~\\\\rm{V} & T_0 &= 300~\\\\rm{K} \\\\\\\\\\n\\\\mu_0 &= 4\\\\pi \\\\times 10^{-7}~\\\\rm{T\\\\,m/A} & k_B &= 1.380649 \\\\times 10^{-23}~\\\\rm{J/K} & \\\\mu_B &= 9.27401 \\\\times 10^{-24}~\\\\rm{J/T} \\\\\\\\\\nn &= 4.20 \\\\times 10^{28}~\\\\rm{m}^{-3} & \\\\lambda_W &= 950 & & \\n\\\\end{align*}\\n\\n\\\\textbf{Problem:} \\nFind, to four significant digits, the precise time $t_{\\\\rm{buckle}}$ (in $\\\\rm{s}$) after $t=0$ at which the compressive axial stress in the bar, $\\\\sigma(t)$, first equals or exceeds the critical buckling stress $\\\\sigma_{\\\\rm{crit}}$ as defined above. Neglect all other forms of instability.\\n\\n\\\\textbf{Answer:} Enter $t_{\\\\rm{buckle}}$ in seconds ($\\\\rm{s}$).\

A superconducting toroidal ring of mass $M = 10.0~\\\\mathrm{kg}$ and net charge $Q = +1.00 \\\\times 10^{-3}~\\\\mathrm{C}$ orbits a compact, slowly-rotating astrophysical object of mass $m_c = 1.40~M_\\\\odot = 2.785 \\\\times 10^{30}~\\\\mathrm{kg}$, charge $q = -1.00 \\\\times 10^{-3}~\\\\mathrm{C}$, and spin angular momentum $\\\\mathcal{J}_c = 7.00 \\\\times 10^{38}~\\\\mathrm{kg~m}^2~\\\\mathrm{s}^{-1}$. The ring is a rigid, thin-walled torus with initial major radius $\\\\mathcal{R}_0 = 1.00 \\\\times 10^6~\\\\mathrm{m}$ and minor radius $a_0 = 1.00 \\\\times 10^{-2}~\\\\mathrm{m}$ at initial temperature $T_0 = 2.725~\\\\mathrm{K}$. The ring has linear coefficient of expansion $\\\\alpha = 2.00 \\\\times 10^{-6}~\\\\mathrm{K}^{-1}$, surface emissivity $\\\\varepsilon = 0.800$, superconducting critical temperature $T_c = 18.0~\\\\mathrm{K}$, and zero-temperature critical current density $J_{c0} = 1.00 \\\\times 10^{10}~\\\\mathrm{A~m}^{-2}$. Its trapped magnetic flux is $\\\\Phi_0 = 5.047 \\\\times 10^7~\\\\mathrm{Wb}$, and its permeability is $\\\\mu_0 = 4\\\\pi \\\\times 10^{-7}~\\\\mathrm{T~m~A}^{-1}$. \\n\\nGravity and electromagnetism are both Newtonian in the orbital plane; the Kerr frame-dragging effect at radius $\\\\mathcal{R}$ is $\\\\Omega_{\\\\mathrm{LT}}(\\\\mathcal{R}) = \\\\dfrac{2G \\\\mathcal{J}_c}{c^2 \\\\mathcal{R}^3}$. Assume $G = 6.674 \\\\times 10^{-11}~\\\\mathrm{N~m}^2~\\\\mathrm{kg}^{-2}$, $c = 2.998 \\\\times 10^8~\\\\mathrm{m~s}^{-1}$, $k_e = 8.987 \\\\times 10^9~\\\\mathrm{N~m}^2~\\\\mathrm{C}^{-2}$, and $\\\\sigma_{SB} = 5.670 \\\\times 10^{-8}~\\\\mathrm{W~m}^{-2}~\\\\mathrm{K}^{-4}$. \\n\\nAt $t = 0$, the ring moves on a circular equatorial orbit of radius $\\\\mathcal{R}_0$ with arbitrarily large (unconstrained) initial spin $\\\\omega_0 > 0$ about its symmetry axis, and is in thermal equilibrium with the cosmic background $(T_0)$. The surrounding plasma perfectly insulates the ring, except for a spin-drag torque that dissipates energy at $P_{\\\\mathrm{diss}} = \\\\kappa (\\\\omega - \\\\Omega_{\\\\mathrm{LT}})^2$, where $\\\\kappa$ is a positive constant. The ring radiates as a grey body of surface area $A_{\\\\mathrm{surf}} = 4\\\\pi^2 \\\\mathcal{R} a$, losing energy as $P_{\\\\mathrm{rad}} = \\\\varepsilon \\\\sigma_{SB}A_{\\\\mathrm{surf}} (T^4-T_0^4)$. \\n\\nThe torus expands uniformly with $\\\\mathcal{R}(T) = \\\\mathcal{R}_0\\\\left[1+\\\\alpha(T-T_0)\\\\right]$ and $a(T) = a_0\\\\left[1+\\\\alpha(T-T_0)\\\\right]$. Its self-inductance is $L(\\\\mathcal{R}, a) = \\\\mu_0 \\\\mathcal{R}\\\\bigl[\\\\ln(8\\\\mathcal{R}/a)-2\\\\bigr]$. Supercurrent is confined to the surface and is spatially uniform: $I_s(T) = J_c(T) \\\\pi a^2$, where $J_c(T) = J_{c0} \\\\left[1-\\\\left(\\\\frac{T}{T_c}\\\\right)^2\\\\right]$ for $T < T_c$. The quantized magnetic flux $\\\\Phi_0$ is exactly conserved: $L(\\\\mathcal{R}, a)I_s(T) = \\\\Phi_0$. \\n\\nAll quantities $\\\\kappa, T, \\\\omega, \\\\mathcal{R}, a, L, I_s, J_c$ below refer to their \\\\emph{steady-state} values reached after long equilibration. In steady state:\\n\\n\u2022 The ring's spin is synchronized to the local Lense-Thirring angular velocity: $\\\\omega_{ss} = \\\\Omega_{\\\\mathrm{LT}}(\\\\mathcal{R}_{ss})$.\\n\u2022 The supercurrent $I_s$ reaches but does not exceed its thermal critical limit: $I_s = J_c(T_{ss}) \\\\pi a_{ss}^2$.\\n\u2022 The flux $\\Phi_0$ is exactly maintained: $L(\\\\mathcal{R}_{ss}, a_{ss}) I_s = \\\\Phi_0$.\\n\u2022 The temperature is steady: the drag heating equals the radiative cooling, i.e. $P_{\\\\mathrm{diss}} = P_{\\\\mathrm{rad}}$.\\n\u2022 The ring moves in a circular orbit with Newtonian radial force balance: $\\\\frac{G M m_c}{\\\\mathcal{R}_{ss}^2} + \\\\frac{k_e q Q}{\\\\mathcal{R}_{ss}^2} = M\\\\omega_{ss}^2 \\\\mathcal{R}_{ss}$. (The sign and value of the electrostatic force is determined by $q$ and $Q$.)\\n\\n\\ufeffAssume that $T_{ss}$ is the \\u201chighest physically allowed\\u201d solution (i.e., $T_{ss}$ is the largest real $< T_c$ satisfying all constraints simultaneously). Neglect all latent heats, heat capacity, conduction to plasma, and relativistic beaming; the temperature, field, and currents are uniform in the torus.\\n\\n\\\\textbf{Question:} \\n\\nDetermine numerically the value of the drag coefficient $\\\\kappa$ (in $\\\\mathrm{kg~m}^2~\\\\mathrm{s}^{-1}$) required so that the above system reaches a unique steady state with $T_{ss}$ as specified, to at least three significant digits.\

\\\\documentclass{article}\\n\\\\usepackage{amsmath,amssymb}\\n\\\\begin{document}\\n\\n\\\\textbf{Problem Statement}\\n\\nA pair of identical monochromatic laser sources $S_1$ and $S_2$ are fixed in a stable, circular orbit around a Schwarzschild black hole of mass $M_{\\\\rm BH}$ at an orbital radius $r_0$ in the equatorial plane $(\\\\theta=\\\\pi/2)$. The proper tangential separation between the sources, as measured in the local instantaneous rest frame of the orbit at $r_0$, is $d$. Both lasers emit continuous light at the same proper frequency $f_0$, as measured in their local frame, with wave vectors pointing radially outward from the black hole.\\n\\nAt a given instant, a point-like photodetector equipped with a perfectly synchronized atomic clock is located at radial coordinate $r_1>r_0$, directly above the midpoint between $S_1$ and $S_2$, and stationary with respect to the black hole (i.e., with four-velocity $u^\\\\mu=(c/\\\\sqrt{1-2GM_{\\\\rm BH}/(c^2 r_1)},0,0,0)$ in Schwarzschild coordinates). The geometry is such that the line from each source to the detector is perpendicular to the tangential direction of their orbit, and gravitational lensing is negligible (i.e., $r_0, r_1 \\\\gg 2GM_{\\\\rm BH}/c^2$). Ignore all special and general relativistic effects except gravitational time dilation and light propagation in curvature (do not consider Shapiro delay).\\n\\nGiven:\\n\\\\begin{align*}\\n    &\\\\text{Gravitational~constant:~} G = 6.674 \\\\times 10^{-11}~\\\\mathrm{m}^3\\\\,\\\\mathrm{kg}^{-1}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{s}^{-2} \\\\\\\\\\n    &\\\\text{Speed~of~light:~} c = 2.9979 \\\\times 10^{8}~\\\\mathrm{m/s} \\\\\\\\\\n    &\\\\text{Black~hole~mass:~} M_{\\\\rm BH} = 4.0 \\\\times 10^6\\\\, M_\\\\odot \\\\quad (M_\\\\odot=1.989 \\\\times 10^{30}~\\\\mathrm{kg}) \\\\\\\\\\n    &\\\\text{Orbital~radius:~} r_0 = 1.8 \\\\times 10^{12}~\\\\mathrm{m} \\\\\\\\\\n    &\\\\text{Detector~radius:~} r_1 = 3.0 \\\\times 10^{12}~\\\\mathrm{m} \\\\\\\\\\n    &\\\\text{Source~separation:~} d = 20.0~\\\\mathrm{m} \\\\\\\\\\n    &\\\\text{Laser~proper~frequency:~} f_0 = 5.716 \\\\times 10^{14}~\\\\mathrm{Hz}\\n\\\\end{align*}\\n\\n\\\\textbf{Assume:}\\n\\\\begin{itemize}\\n    \\\\item Both sources are at rest relative to each other and co-rotating with the circular orbit at $r_0$.\\n    \\\\item The detector is stationary in Schwarzschild coordinates at $r_1$.\\n    \\\\item The two beams arrive at the detector at equal angles with respect to the radial direction, such that their optical paths can be treated as parallel in the detector vicinity (far-field approximation: $r_1 \\\\gg d$).\\n    \\\\item Light propagates radially in vacuum; neglect special-relativistic aberration and lensing/bending.\\n\\\\end{itemize}\\n\\n\\\\vspace{0.5cm}\\n\\n\\\\textbf{Question:}\\n\\nAs measured by the atomic clock at the detector, what is the temporal separation $\\\\Delta t_p$ (in nanoseconds) between consecutive constructive interference maxima \\\\\\\\(\\\\boxed{\\\\text{at the detector position at $r_1$}}\\\\\\\\) resulting from the path difference between $S_1$ and $S_2$? Give your answer for $\\\\Delta t_p$ in nanoseconds, numerically to three significant figures.\\n\\n\\\\end{document}\\n\

A thin, flexible ring of electrically conducting, spin-polarized electrons is uniformly distributed along a toroidal path of initial radius $R_0 = 1.500 \\\\times 10^{-4}~\\\\text{m}$ and negligible cross-sectional area. The ring consists of $N = 4.000 \\\\times 10^8$ electrons, each with mass $m_e = 9.109 \\\\times 10^{-31}~\\\\text{kg}$ and charge $e = -1.602 \\\\times 10^{-19}~\\\\text{C}$. The ring is assumed to be fully supported along its circumference by a massless, perfectly insulating, elastic scaffold characterized only by an effective Young's modulus $Y = 1.000 \\\\times 10^{11}~\\\\text{Pa}$ and negligible thickness. \\n\\nThe system rotates rigidly about its axis with constant angular velocity $\\\\Omega = 1.000 \\\\times 10^{12}~\\\\text{rad/s}$ in an applied uniform axial magnetic field $B_z = 10.00~\\\\text{T}$. The total electrical current is given by $I = |N e| \\\\Omega / (2\\\\pi)$. The surrounding environment is a vacuum (permittivity $\\\\varepsilon_0 = 8.854 \\\\times 10^{-12}~\\\\text{F/m}$, permeability $\\\\mu_0 = 4\\\\pi \\\\times 10^{-7}~\\\\text{H/m}$, $c = 2.998 \\\\times 10^8~\\\\text{m/s}$), and all thermal and resistive losses are negligible.\\n\\nThe only degrees of freedom considered are small, time-dependent radial oscillations of the ring (its fundamental 'breathing' mode), so that its instantaneous radius is $R(t) = R_{\\\\mathrm{eq}} + \\\\delta R(t)$ with $|\\\\delta R| \\\\ll R_{\\\\mathrm{eq}}$. The equilibrium radius $R_{\\\\mathrm{eq}}$ is determined by a balance between the following forces per unit length acting on the ring:\\n\\n(1) \\\\\\\\textbf{Centrifugal (relativistic):} $F_c = \\\\frac{M \\\\gamma^2 \\\\Omega^2}{2\\\\pi R}$, with $M = N m_e$ and $\\\\gamma = [1 - (\\\\Omega R/c)^2]^{-1/2}$.\\n\\n(2) \\\\\\\\textbf{Lorentz:} $F_L = \\\\frac{Q I B_z}{2\\\\pi R}$, where $Q = N e$.\\n\\n(3) \\\\\\\\textbf{Elastic restoring:} $F_E = Y \\\\frac{A}{R_0} (R - R_0)$, with $A = 5.000 \\\\times 10^{-13}~\\\\text{m}^2$.\\n\\nThe total mass $M$ is due solely to the electrons. Assume $\\\\Omega R_{\\\\mathrm{eq}} \\\\ll c$ so that $\\\\gamma \\\\approx 1$.\\n\\nNeglect all Coulomb repulsion between electrons and quantum degeneracy pressure.\\n\\n\\\\textbf{Part I.} Compute the equilibrium radius $R_{\\\\mathrm{eq}}$ by solving the condition $F_c + F_L - F_E = 0$.\\n\\nFor small oscillations $\\\\delta R (t)$ about $R_{\\\\mathrm{eq}}$, the ring undergoes harmonic motion with effective mass $M$ and angular frequency $\\\\omega_0 = \\\\sqrt{k_{\\\\mathrm{eff}} / M}$, where $k_{\\\\mathrm{eff}}$ is the total effective spring constant obtained from the first-order Taylor expansion in $\\\\delta R$ of the net force per unit length evaluated at $R_{\\\\mathrm{eq}}$.\\n\\nThe oscillation generates a time-dependent magnetic dipole moment $m(t) = I \\\\cdot \\\\pi R(t)^2$, and hence radiates electromagnetic energy at the breathing mode frequency $\\\\omega_0$. Assume the power radiated is given by the magnetic dipole radiation formula $P_{\\\\mathrm{EM}} = \\\\frac{\\\\mu_0}{6\\\\pi c^3} |\\\\ddot{m}(t)|^2$.\\n\\n\\\\textbf{Part II.} Assuming \\\\textit{no other loss mechanisms} and that the amplitude of small radial oscillations is $\\\\delta R_0 = 1.000 \\\\times 10^{-9}~\\\\text{m}$, compute the total radiative damping rate $\\\\gamma$ (in s$^{-1}$) defined via $E(t) = E_0 e^{-2\\\\gamma t}$ for the breathing mode.\\n\\n\\\\\\\\\\n\\\\textbf{Final question:} What is the dimensionless quality factor $Q_{\\\\mathrm{factor}} = \\\\omega_0 / (2 \\\\gamma)$ of the ring's fundamental radial breathing mode, to three significant digits?\

Consider a vertical, frictionless cylindrical tube of radius $R = 0.100\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$ and fixed length $L = 1.00\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$, closed at the bottom and open at the top. Inside the tube is a perfectly insulating, rigid, massless piston that can move without friction, thus dividing the tube into two compartments. The lower compartment (height $h$) contains $N = 6.022 \\\\times 10^{23}$ non-interacting, spin-$1/2$ fermions of mass $m_f = 5.007 \\\\times 10^{-27}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{kg}$ (as for $^3\\\\mathrm{He}$), constrained to move only within the volume $V = \\\\pi R^2 h$ beneath the piston. The fermions are maintained at a constant temperature $T = 0.100\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K}$ via weak coupling to an external thermal reservoir (the coupling is weak enough that the dynamics of the piston are not measurably affected). The upper compartment (above the piston) is evacuated.\\n\\nThe piston itself has mass $m_p = 2.00\\\\ \\\\mathrm{kg}$ and is acted upon by gravity ($g = 9.81\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m/s^2}$) and a viscous damping force $F_\\\\mathrm{damp} = -\\\\beta v_p$, with damping coefficient $\\\\beta = 0.100\\\\ \\\\mathrm{kg\\\\,s^{-1}}$ and $v_p$ the instantaneous velocity of the piston.\\n\\nAt $t = 0$, the system is in equilibrium: the height $h_0$ of the gas compartment is such that the total upward pressure force from the Fermi gas matches the downward force of gravity on the piston: $P_0 A = m_p g$, where $P_0$ is the equilibrium pressure and $A = \\\\pi R^2$ is the piston area. Assume the gas is highly degenerate, so the pressure at $T \\\\ll T_F$ can be approximated by $P = \\\\frac{(3\\\\pi^2)^{2/3}\\\\hbar^2}{5m_f} n^{5/3}$, where $n = N/V$ is the number density and $\\\\hbar = 1.05457 \\\\times 10^{-34}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{J\\\\,s}$.\\n\\nFor times $t > 0$, the entire apparatus is subject to a time-dependent vertical acceleration $a(t) = a_0 \\\\sin(\\\\omega t)$, with $a_0 = 1.50\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m\\\\,s^{-2}}$ and $\\\\omega = 10.0\\\\ \\\\mathrm{rad\\\\,s^{-1}}$, in addition to gravity. That is, the apparent gravitational acceleration is $g_\\\\mathrm{eff}(t) = g - a(t)$. The system is operated for a long time and reaches a periodic dynamic steady state: the piston oscillates vertically about $h_0$ with a small amplitude $\\\\delta h \\\\ll h_0$, in response to the oscillatory $g_\\\\mathrm{eff}(t)$, entirely within the linear regime. At all times, the gas exchanges heat only with the external thermal reservoir, ensuring the gas temperature remains equal to $T$ (i.e., the compression/expansion cycles are isothermal for the gas; ignore any contribution from the finite response time of the reservoir).\\n\\nNeglect all other effects (e.g., air resistance, quantum or magnetic effects, motion of any other objects, induced electric or magnetic fields). Assume the piston fits perfectly (no leakage) and the tube and piston are rigid.\\n\\nRecall that, for a system kept at constant temperature $T$ by a reservoir, the time-averaged rate of entropy production in the gas is $\\\\langle \\\\dot{S} \\\\rangle = \\\\langle \\\\dot{Q}_\\\\mathrm{in} \\\\rangle / T$, where $\\\\langle \\\\dot{Q}_\\\\mathrm{in} \\\\rangle$ is the time-averaged rate at which heat enters the gas from the reservoir to maintain its temperature, over one full cycle.\\n\\n\\\\textbf{Using the provided parameters, calculate the steady-state time-averaged rate of entropy production $\\\\langle \\\\dot{S} \\\\rangle$ within the fermion gas (in $\\\\mathrm{W\\\\,K^{-1}}$) due to irreversible compression/expansion work under forced oscillations. Give your answer, correct to three significant figures, in SI units.}\

A solid toroidal ring made of pure niobium is placed at rest in a laboratory at ambient temperature. The torus has a major radius $R = 5.00\\\\ \\\\mathrm{cm}$ (distance from center of symmetry to axis of the wire) and a minor (wire) radius $r_w = 1.00\\\\ \\\\mathrm{mm}$; the cross-section of the wire is a perfect circle. The wire is a solid, homogeneous conductor throughout. The torus is surrounded by vacuum and is thermally insulated so that no heat is exchanged with the environment at any time.\\n\\nPhysical parameters of niobium:\\n\\\\begin{itemize}\\n    \\\\item Mass density: $\\\\rho_m = 9.30 \\\\times 10^{3}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{kg/m^3}$\\n    \\\\item Molar mass: $M_{\\\\mathrm{mol}} = 95.95\\\\ \\\\mathrm{g/mol}$\\n    \\\\item Debye temperature: $\\\\Theta_D = 470\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K}$\\n    \\\\item Normal-state resistivity: $\\\\rho_n = 1.50 \\\\times 10^{-7}\\\\ \\\\Omega\\\\cdot \\\\mathrm{m}$\\n    \\\\item Upper critical field at $0\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K}$: $B_{c2}(0) = 25.0\\\\ \\\\mathrm{T}$\\n    \\\\item Critical temperature: $T_c = 9.20\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K}$\\n\\\\end{itemize}\\nFundamental constants:\\n\\\\begin{itemize}\\n    \\\\item Permeability of free space: $\\\\mu_0 = 4 \\\\pi \\\\times 10^{-7}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{H\\\\,m^{-1}}$\\n    \\\\item Avogadro's number: $N_A = 6.022 \\\\times 10^{23}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{mol^{-1}}$\\n    \\\\item Boltzmann constant: $k_B = 1.381 \\\\times 10^{-23}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{J\\\\,K^{-1}}$\\n\\\\end{itemize}\\n\\nThe toroidal ring starts in thermal equilibrium at initial temperature $T_i = 4.20\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K}$, well below $T_c$, and with zero current. At $t = 0$, a spatially uniform, time-dependent magnetic field $\\\\vec{B}_{\\\\mathrm{ext}}(t) = B_0 \\\\left[1 - e^{-t/\\\\tau}\\\\right] \\\\hat{z}$ is applied everywhere in the laboratory, with $B_0 = 5.00\\\\ \\\\mathrm{T}$ and $\\\\tau = 0.100\\\\ \\\\mathrm{s}$. The magnetic field is produced by external means and does not interact mechanically with the ring. The vector potential in cylindrical coordinates is $\\\\vec{A}(\\\\rho, t) = \\\\frac{B_0 \\\\rho}{2}[1 - e^{-t/\\\\tau}]\\\\hat{\\\\phi}$.\\n\\nThis induces a current $I(t)$ around the torus, governed by the circuit equation for a closed loop:\\n\\\\[\\n    L \\\\frac{dI}{dt} + R_{\\\\mathrm{eff}}(t) I(t) = - \\\\frac{d\\\\Phi_{\\\\mathrm{ext}}}{dt}\\n\\\\]\\nwhere\\n\\\\begin{itemize}\\n    \\\\item $L$ is the self-inductance of the torus, given by $L = \\\\mu_0 R \\\\left[ \\\\ln \\\\left( \\\\frac{8R}{r_w} \\\\right) - 2 \\\\right]$\\n    \\\\item The total external flux through the torus is $\\\\Phi_{\\\\mathrm{ext}}(t) = B_{\\\\mathrm{ext}}(t) \\\\pi R^2$\\n\\\\end{itemize}\\n\\nThe effective resistance $R_{\\\\mathrm{eff}}(t)$ arises from vortex flux flow (Bardeen-Stephen model):\\n\\\\[\\n    R_{\\\\mathrm{eff}}(t) = R_n \\\\frac{B_{\\\\mathrm{wire}}(t)}{B_{c2}(T(t))}\\n\\\\]\\nwhere\\n\\\\begin{itemize}\\n    \\\\item $R_n = \\\\frac{\\\\rho_n \\\\ell}{A}$ is the normal-state resistance of the wire ($\\\\ell=2\\\\pi R$ is the circumference, $A=\\\\pi r_w^2$ the cross-sectional area)\\n    \\\\item $B_{\\\\mathrm{wire}}(t) = B_{\\\\mathrm{ext}}(t)$ is the magnetic field intensity threading the conductor at its location (assume the external field is uniform across the wire cross-section at all times)\\n    \\\\item $B_{c2}(T) = B_{c2}(0)\\\\left[1-\\\\left( \\\\frac{T}{T_c} \\\\right)^2 \\\\right]$ is the temperature-dependent upper critical field\\n\\\\end{itemize}\\n\\nThroughout the process, assume:\\n\\\\begin{itemize}\\n    \\\\item The system does not exceed the critical temperature or the critical field at any location or time; that is, $T(t) < T_c$ and $B_{\\\\mathrm{wire}}(t) < B_{c2}(T(t))$ \\\\textbf{hold for all} $t$.\\n    \\\\item The temperature profile within the ring remains spatially uniform at all times (adiabatic conditions; total heat generated remains in the ring).\\n    \\\\item The specific heat (per mole) at these temperatures is dominated by the Debye $T^3$ term: \\n    \\\\[\\n    C_{V,\\\\mathrm{mol}}(T) = \\\\frac{12 \\\\pi^4}{5} N_A k_B \\\\left( \\\\frac{T}{\\\\Theta_D} \\\\right)^3\\n    \\\\]\\n\\\\end{itemize}\\n\\n{\\\\bf Final task:}\\n\\nUsing the above data, compute the \\\\textbf{total increase in thermodynamic entropy}, $\\\\Delta S$ (in $\\\\mathrm{J\\\\,K^{-1}}$), of the niobium toroidal ring as it evolves from its initial state $T_i$ to its final equilibrium temperature $T_f$ after the field ramp ($t \\\\to \\\\infty$). Round your answer to three significant digits.\

A small, solid, isolated conducting sphere of mass $m = 1.000 \\\\times 10^{-6}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{kg}$ and uniform density $\\\\rho_{\\\\mathrm{Pt}} = 2.1450 \\\\times 10^4\\\\,\\\\mathrm{kg}\\\\!/\\\\!\\\\mathrm{m}^3$ (platinum) is placed at rest in high vacuum and is irradiated by a collimated ultraviolet laser of wavelength $\\\\lambda_L = 150.0\\\\,\\\\mathrm{nm}$ until photoemission ceases. The work function of platinum is $W_{\\\\mathrm{Pt}} = 5.650\\\\,\\\\mathrm{eV}$. Assume the sphere is surrounded by vacuum during irradiation, and neglect any space-charge or image-charge effects. \\n\\nLet $R$ denote the radius of the sphere. The maximum number of electrons photoemitted is reached when the electrostatic potential of the (positively charged) sphere prevents further photoemission; that is, the stopping condition is set by the electrostatic potential $\\\\varphi$ at the surface relative to vacuum: $e\\\\varphi = h c/\\\\lambda_L - W_{\\\\mathrm{Pt}}$, where $e$ is the elementary charge.\\n\\nAfter charging, the sphere is carefully transferred without discharge to the interior of a parallel-plate capacitor (plate separation $d = 5.000\\\\,\\\\mathrm{cm}$), and placed on the perfectly smooth (frictionless), rigid, inner surface of a stationary hollow cone of rest half-angle $\\\\alpha_0 = 30.00\\\\,^{\\\\circ}$. The cone's axis is vertical, and the entire apparatus is inside the capacitor with the axis aligned vertically ($z$). The capacitor was initially charged in vacuum to a potential difference $V_0 = 100.0\\\\,\\\\mathrm{kV}$ and disconnected from any voltage source; then the gap was fully filled with a nonlinear, isotropic, homogeneous dielectric of relative permittivity $\\\\kappa_r(E) = \\\\kappa_0 + \\\\beta E^2$, where $E = |\\\\vec{E}|$, $\\\\kappa_0 = 50.00$, and $\\\\beta = 2.000 \\\\times 10^{-12}\\\\, (\\\\mathrm{m}/\\\\mathrm{V})^2$.\\n\\nLet $A \\\\gg d^2$ be the area of the square plates. Ignore edge effects and assume that the net free surface charge on the plates is constant. The field $\\\\vec{E} = -E_z \\\\hat{\\\\mathbf{z}}$ is uniform and given by Gauss\u2019s law, with $E_z$ determined self-consistently by the frozen plate charge and the nonlinear dielectric.\\n\\nA uniform, static magnetic field $\\\\vec{B} = -B_z\\\\hat{\\\\mathbf{z}}$, $B_z = 20.00\\\\,\\\\mathrm{T}$, pervades the region. The conical surface is now made to rotate steadily about its symmetry ($z$) axis at angular velocity $\\\\omega$, so that the sphere is forced to move, without slipping, in a horizontal circle of constant height $h_f = 10.00\\\\,\\\\mathrm{cm}$ above the apex. Assume the sphere's trajectory is perfectly circular at radius $r = h_f \\\\tan\\\\alpha_0$, with angular velocity $\\\\omega$ (i.e., $\\\\omega_{\\\\mathrm{sphere}} = \\\\omega_{\\\\mathrm{cone}}$); gravity acts downward with $g = 9.80665\\\\,\\\\mathrm{m/s}^2$.\\n\\nNeglect any charging or polarization effects from the dielectric when the sphere is present; the sphere retains its initial charge $Q$ throughout. Fundamental constants: $e = 1.602177\\\\times 10^{-19}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{C}$, $h = 6.626070\\\\times 10^{-34}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{J\\\\,\\\\cdot\\\\,s}$, $c = 2.997925\\\\times 10^8\\\\,\\\\mathrm{m/s}$, $\\\\varepsilon_0 = 8.854187\\\\times 10^{-12}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{F/m}$, $1\\\\,\\\\mathrm{eV} = 1.602177\\\\times 10^{-19}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{J}$.\\n\\nCalculate numerically the unique angular velocity $\\\\omega$ (in $\\\\mathrm{rad/s}$) that must be set for the cone so the sphere maintains steady, horizontal, circular motion at the stated height.\

A classical nanosphere of mass $m = 1.000 \\\\times 10^{-18}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{kg}$ and charge $q = -1.602 \\\\times 10^{-16}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{C}$ is rigidly attached to a non-conducting hoop of radius $R = 1.000 \\\\times 10^{-4}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{m}$. The hoop is oriented vertically in the $xz$-plane, centered at the origin, and forced to rotate with constant angular velocity $\\\\Omega = 1.000 \\\\times 10^{3}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{rad/s}$ about the $z$-axis; that is, the hoop itself rotates while remaining in the $xz$-plane, and the nanosphere co-rotates with the hoop at fixed radius. The only degree of freedom of the nanosphere is its angular position $\\\\theta \\\\in [0,2\\\\pi)$ around the hoop, measured from the lowest point of the hoop ($z = -R$) upwards in the direction of increasing $z$ (so the $z$-coordinate of the sphere is $z(\\\\theta) = R \\\\cos \\\\theta$). \\n\\nThe entire system is placed in a uniform gravitational field $\\\\mathbf{g} = -g \\\\, \\\\hat{z}$, where $g = 100.0\\\\,\\\\mathrm{m/s}^2$, and subjected to a uniform static magnetic field $\\\\mathbf{B} = B_0\\\\,\\\\hat{y}$ with $B_0 = 1.000\\\\,\\\\mathrm{T}$. There is no electric field except that the laboratory frame contains a long, uniformly charged wire along the $y$-axis, with linear charge density $\\\\lambda = -1.000 \\\\times 10^{-15}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{C/m}$. The system is in classical thermal equilibrium at absolute temperature $T = 300.0\\\\,\\\\mathrm{K}$. Friction is negligible, but the nanosphere is coupled to a heat bath by stochastic collisions so that its distribution over $\\\\theta$ in the laboratory frame is Boltzmann-like for the total energy including all inertial (centrifugal), mechanical potential, and electromagnetic effects. \\n\\nRelevant constants: Boltzmann constant $k_{\\\\mathrm{B}} = 1.3806 \\\\times 10^{-23}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{J/K}$, vacuum permittivity $\\\\epsilon_0 = 8.8542 \\\\times 10^{-12}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{F/m}$. \\n\\nAssume the following: (i) The nanosphere remains fixed relative to the hoop at every $\\\\theta$ as the hoop rotates, acquiring tangential velocity $\\\\mathbf{v}(\\\\theta)=\\\\Omega R\\\\left[\\\\sin \\\\theta\\\\,\\\\hat{x}-\\\\cos\\\\theta\\\\,\\\\hat{z}\\\\right]$ at each point. (ii) The total potential energy $U(\\\\theta)$ relevant for the Boltzmann distribution includes gravitational, centrifugal, electrostatic, and all velocity-dependent electromagnetic energy terms for a charged particle in a rotating frame. (iii) The electrostatic potential energy due to the charged wire is $U_{\\\\mathrm{wire}}(\\\\theta) = q V_{\\\\mathrm{wire}}(\\\\rho(\\\\theta))$ with $V_{\\\\mathrm{wire}}(\\\\rho) = (\\\\lambda/2\\\\pi\\\\epsilon_0)\\\\ln(R_0/\\\\rho)$, where $R_0 = 1.000\\\\,\\\\mathrm{m}$ and $\\\\rho(\\\\theta) = \\\\sqrt{R^2\\\\cos^2\\\\theta + R^2\\\\sin^2\\\\theta} = R$ is the distance in the $xz$-plane from the wire at the origin. \\n\\nCalculate the thermal expectation value $\\\\langle z \\\\rangle$ of the vertical position of the nanosphere, where $\\\\displaystyle \\\\langle z \\\\rangle = \\\\frac{\\\\int_0^{2\\\\pi} R \\\\cos\\\\theta\\\\, e^{-U(\\\\theta)/k_{\\\\mathrm{B}}T}\\\\,d\\\\theta}{\\\\int_0^{2\\\\pi} e^{-U(\\\\theta)/k_{\\\\mathrm{B}}T}\\\\,d\\\\theta}$, accurate to three significant digits and expressed in SI units.\

A solid, perfectly spherical particle of radius $r = 10.0\\\\ \\\\mu\\\\mathrm{m}$ and mass $m = 5.25 \\\\times 10^{-12}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{kg}$ is made of a type-I superconducting material with uniform density $\\\\rho_s$ and is electrically neutral ($q=0$). The particle is fully immersed in a non-conducting, incompressible fluid of density $\\\\rho_f = 997.0\\\\ \\\\mathrm{kg/m}^3$ and dynamic viscosity $\\\\eta = 0.89 \\\\times 10^{-3}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{Pa\\\\cdot s}$, contained within a hemispherical rigid bowl of inner radius $R = 5.00\\\\ \\\\mathrm{cm}$. The bowl is stationary in the laboratory frame and is open to the atmosphere. The axis of symmetry of the bowl is aligned along the vertical $z$-axis. The system is placed in a uniform gravitational field $\\\\vec{g} = -g \\\\hat{z}$, where $g = 9.80665\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m/s^2}$.\\n\\nAt the center of the bowl (position $\\\\rho=0$, $z=0$), a finite cylindrical solenoid of length $L = 20.0\\\\ \\\\mathrm{cm}$, radius $a = 2.00\\\\ \\\\mathrm{cm}$, and $n = 1000.0\\\\ \\\\mathrm{turns/m}$ is placed co-axially along the $z$-axis. The solenoid carries a steady direct current $I$. The solenoid\u2019s axis coincides with that of the bowl.\\n\\nThe external magnetic field produced by the solenoid is given, for $\\\\rho \\\\geq a$, by:\\n\\\\begin{align*}\\nB_z(\\\\rho,z) &= \\\\frac{\\\\mu_0 n I}{2} (\\\\cos\\\\alpha_2 - \\\\cos\\\\alpha_1) \\\\\\\\\\nB_{\\\\rho}(\\\\rho,z) &= \\\\frac{\\\\mu_0 n I}{4 \\\\pi \\\\rho} \\\\bigg[(z-L/2)\\\\cos\\\\alpha_1 - (z+L/2)\\\\cos\\\\alpha_2 + L \\\\bigg]\\n\\\\end{align*}\\nwhere $\\\\cos\\\\alpha_1 = \\\\frac{z+L/2}{\\\\sqrt{\\\\rho^2 + (z+L/2)^2}}$, $\\\\cos\\\\alpha_2 = \\\\frac{z-L/2}{\\\\sqrt{\\\\rho^2 + (z-L/2)^2}}$, $\\\\rho$ is the cylindrical radial coordinate, and $z$ is the height above the bowl\u2019s lowest point. You may neglect the field inside $\\\\rho < a$.\\n\\nThe particle, being superconducting and in the Meissner state, perfectly expels all incident magnetic flux. The total magnetic potential energy of the sphere is thus\\n\\\\[\\nU_B = \\\\frac{2 \\\\pi r^3}{3\\\\mu_0} \\\\left| \\\\vec{B}_{\\\\text{ext}}(\\\\vec{r}) \\\\right|^2,\\n\\\\]\\nwhere $\\\\vec{B}_{\\\\text{ext}}$ is the local net magnetic field at the sphere\u2019s location.\\n\\nAt equilibrium, the superconducting sphere moves (without friction) to a position where the net force along the surface of the bowl vanishes. The buoyant force acts vertically upward, with magnitude $F_{\\\\text{buoy}} = \\\\rho_f V g$ (where $V = \\\\frac{4}{3}\\\\pi r^3$ is the particle's volume), and acts strictly opposite to gravity. The normal force from the bowl ensures the particle stays on the surface. The only relevant force components for equilibrium are those tangent to the bowl\u2019s surface, i.e., along $\\\\hat{\\\\theta}$ in spherical coordinates (with $\\\\theta$ measured from the vertical $+z$ axis).\\n\\nTake the particle\u2019s density to be $\\\\rho_s = 3120\\\\ \\\\mathrm{kg/m^3}$. Neglect all electrostatic and hydrodynamic drag effects. Assume the magnetic field of the solenoid is the dominant source of external field, and that the presence of the superconducting sphere does not measurably alter the field at its own location (London penetration depth is negligible compared to $r$).\\n\\nGiven these conditions, the sphere is placed upon the bowl surface at the polar angle $\\\\theta_0 = \\\\pi/3$. Its coordinates are thus $\\\\rho_0 = R \\\\sin \\\\theta_0$, $z_0 = -R \\\\cos \\\\theta_0$.\\n\\n\\\\textbf{Constants:}\\n\\\\begin{align*}\\n&\\\\mu_0 = 4\\\\pi \\\\times 10^{-7}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{T \\\\cdot m/A}\\\\\\\\\\n&g = 9.80665\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m/s^2}\\\\\\\\\\n&\\\\pi \\\\approx 3.141593\\n\\\\end{align*}\\nAll other constants as defined above.\\n\\n\\\\textbf{Final Question:} \\n\\n\\\\emph{What is the magnitude of the current $I$ (in amperes) that must be supplied through the solenoid such that the superconducting sphere rests in static equilibrium at $\\\\theta_0 = \\\\pi/3$ on the bowl, i.e., so that the sum of the magnetic, gravitational, and buoyant force components tangent to the spherical bowl surface vanishes at this specific position? Give your answer for $I$ in SI base units accurate to at least three significant digits.}\

A solid hemisphere of radius $R$ and total mass $M$ is fabricated with a radially symmetric density profile $\\\\rho_s(r) = \\\\rho_{s,0} (1 + \\\\beta (r/R)^2)$, where $r$ is the distance from the symmetry axis and $\\\\beta$ is a constant. The hemisphere is fully submerged in a stationary, incompressible, uniform conducting fluid of density $\\\\rho_f$ and dynamic viscosity $\\\\eta$. The fluid contains free electrons of number density $n_e$ and the electron-neutral collision frequency is $\\\\nu_c$, so its (scalar) electrical conductivity is $\\\\sigma_f = n_e e^2 / (m_e \\\\nu_c)$, with $e$ the elementary charge and $m_e$ the electron mass. The flat face of the hemisphere rests on an infinite, frictionless, perfectly conducting horizontal plane at $z=0$, permitting the hemisphere to rotate freely about a horizontal axis (the $y$-axis) passing through a fixed point $P$ at the center of its base (i.e., the center of its flat face is the pivot).\\n\\nThe entire apparatus is centered within an external, uniform, time-invariant magnetic field $\\\\mathbf{B}_0 = B_0 \\\\hat{\\\\mathbf{z}}$.
