At time $t=0$, the center of mass of the hemisphere (located at height $z_{\\\\mathrm{cm}}$ above the base) is displaced by a small angle $\\\\theta_{y,0}$ about the $y$-axis (small angle: $\\\\sin \\\\theta \\\\approx \\\\theta$), and has an initial angular velocity $\\\\omega_{y,0}$. Gravity acts downwards with acceleration $g$.\\n\\nAt $t=0$, a spatially uniform electric field $\\\\mathbf{E}_0 = E_0 \\\\hat{\\\\mathbf{x}}$ is instantaneously applied throughout the fluid volume (perpendicular to $\\\\mathbf{B}_0$). This induces eddy currents in the fluid, which exert a torque on the hemisphere via the Lorentz force. Assume the geometry is such that the dominant eddy current torque on the hemisphere about $P$ at $t=0$ is \\n\\\\[\\n    \\\\tau_{\\\\mathrm{em}} = - K_{\\\\mathrm{em}} R^3 \\\\sigma_f E_0 B_0\\n\\\\]\\nwhere $K_{\\\\mathrm{em}}$ is a dimensionless geometric factor (given below).\\n\\nIn addition, the rotation of the hemisphere in the conducting fluid (in the presence of $\\\\mathbf{B}_0$) produces a magnetohydrodynamic drag torque about $P$ at $t=0$ given by\\n\\\\[\\n    \\\\tau_{\\\\mathrm{drag}} = - C_d(\\\\mathrm{Ha}) \\\\eta R^5 \\\\omega_{y,0}\\n\\\\]\\nwhere $C_d(\\\\mathrm{Ha}) = C_0 (1 + \\\\alpha_{\\\\mathrm{Ha}} \\\\mathrm{Ha})$ is a dimensionless drag coefficient, $C_0$ and $\\\\alpha_{\\\\mathrm{Ha}}$ are dimensionless constants, and the Hartmann number is\\n\\\\[\\n    \\\\mathrm{Ha} = B_0 R \\\\sqrt{\\\\frac{\\\\sigma_f}{\\\\eta}}.\\n\\\\]\\n\\nThe gravitational torque about $P$ at $t=0$ is\\n\\\\[\\n    \\\\tau_{g,\\\\mathrm{eff}} = - M g (z_{\\\\mathrm{cm}} - z_{\\\\mathrm{base}}) \\\\theta_{y,0}\\n\\\\]\\nwhere $z_{\\\\mathrm{base}} = 0$. Archimedes' principle applies: the hemisphere experiences a buoyant torque from the displaced fluid, with effective net weight $M_{\\\\mathrm{eff}} = M - M_{\\\\mathrm{disp}}$, where $M_{\\\\mathrm{disp}} = (2/3) \\\\pi R^3 \\\\rho_f$ is the mass of displaced fluid. (Assume the center of buoyancy coincides with the hemisphere's geometric center of volume at height $z_{\\\\mathrm{cv}} = 3R/8$.)\\n\\nThe moment of inertia of the hemisphere about the $y$-axis through the base is\\n\\\\[\\n    I_y = \\\\frac{4\\\\pi}{3} \\\\rho_{s,0} R^5 \\\\left(\\\\frac{1}{5} + \\\\frac{\\\\beta}{7}\\\\right).\\n\\\\]\\n\\nAll physical constants and parameter values are provided below.\\n\\n\\\\textbf{Constants:}\\n\\\\begin{align*}\\nR &= 5.00 \\\\times 10^{-2}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m} \\\\\\\\\\n\\\\rho_{s,0} &= 7.80 \\\\times 10^3\\\\ \\\\mathrm{kg}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{m}^{-3} \\\\\\\\\\n\\\\beta &= 0.500 \\\\qquad \\\\text{(dimensionless)}\\\\\\\\\\n\\\\eta &= 1.20 \\\\times 10^{-5}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{Pa}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{s} \\\\\\\\\\n\\\\rho_f &= 9.50 \\\\times 10^2\\\\ \\\\mathrm{kg}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{m}^{-3} \\\\\\\\\\nn_e &= 2.50 \\\\times 10^{21}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}^{-3} \\\\\\\\\\n\\\\nu_c &= 1.00 \\\\times 10^{13}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{s}^{-1} \\\\\\\\\\nE_0 &= 1.20 \\\\times 10^{-2}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{V}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{m}^{-1}\\\\\\\\\\nB_0 &= 16.0\\\\ \\\\mathrm{T} \\\\\\\\\\ng &= 9.80665\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{s}^{-2} \\\\\\\\\\n\\\\theta_{y,0} &= 2.00 \\\\times 10^{-3}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{rad} \\\\\\\\\\n\\\\omega_{y,0} &= -5.00 \\\\times 10^{-2}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{rad}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{s}^{-1} \\\\\\\\\\nC_0 &= 2.80 \\\\qquad \\\\text{(dimensionless)}\\\\\\\\\\n\\\\alpha_{\\\\mathrm{Ha}} &= 0.150 \\\\qquad \\\\text{(dimensionless)}\\\\\\\\\\nK_{\\\\mathrm{em}} &= 0.310 \\\\qquad \\\\text{(dimensionless)} \\\\\\\\\\ne &= 1.602176634 \\\\times 10^{-19}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{C} \\\\\\\\\\nm_e &= 9.1093837 \\\\times 10^{-31}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{kg}\\n\\\\end{align*}\\n\\n\\\\textbf{Questions:}\\n\\n\\\\textbf{Using the above data and assumptions, compute the magnitude of the initial angular acceleration}\\n\\\\[|\\n    \\\\alpha_y(t=0)|\\n\\\\]\\nof the hemisphere (about the $y$-axis through $P$), in $\\\\mathrm{rad}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{s}^{-2}$, \\n\\\\textbf{including the effects of gravity, buoyancy, eddy current interaction, and fluid (magnetohydrodynamic) drag.}\\n\\n\\\\textbf{Give your answer numerically with three significant digits and SI units.}\\n\

A solid, uniform conducting disc of mass $M = \\\\SI{50.0}{\\\\kilogram}$ and radius $R = \\\\SI{0.500}{\\\\meter}$ rotates about its central axis ($z$-axis) in a vacuum chamber. Its moment of inertia is $I = \\\\frac{1}{2} M R^2$. The apparatus orbits in the equatorial plane of a neutron star at a distance $r = \\\\SI{1.00e5}{\\\\meter}$ from the star's center. The neutron star has mass $M_{\\\\text{NS}} = 1.40\\\\,M_\\\\odot$ (where $M_\\\\odot = \\\\SI{1.989e30}{\\\\kilogram}$) and angular momentum $J_{\\\\text{NS}} = \\\\SI{1.00e40}{\\\\kilogram\\\\,\\\\meter^2\\\\,\\\\per\\\\second}$, aligned with the disc's axis. The gravitational constant is $G = 6.67430\\\\times10^{-11}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m^3\\\\,kg^{-1}\\\\,s^{-2}}$ and the speed of light is $c = \\\\SI{2.99792458e8}{\\\\meter\\\\per\\\\second}$. The frame-dragging (Lense-Thirring) angular velocity at orbital radius is $\\\\Omega_{\\\\text{LT}} = \\\\frac{2 G J_{\\\\text{NS}}}{c^2 r^3}$. The disc's own angular velocity is $\\\\omega(t)$, and $\\\\Omega_{\\\\text{orb}} = \\\\sqrt{G M_{\\\\text{NS}}/r^3}$ is the local Keplerian orbital angular velocity.\\n\\nA torque acts on the disc due to gravitomagnetic (GM) coupling: $\\\\tau_{\\\\text{GM}} = \\\\eta_{\\\\text{GM}} (\\\\Omega_{\\\\text{LT}} - \\\\omega)$, with $\\\\eta_{\\\\text{GM}} = \\\\SI{1.50e-3}{\\\\kilogram\\\\,\\\\meter^2\\\\,\\\\per\\\\second}$. (Direction: positive about $+z$).\\n\\nA single radial spoke runs from the disc center to its rim and is made of a piezoelectric material with length $\\\\ell = R$, cross-sectional area $A_{\\\\text{spoke}} = \\\\SI{1.00e-4}{\\\\meter^2}$, linear mass density $\\\\lambda = \\\\SI{2.00}{\\\\kilogram\\\\per\\\\meter}$, and piezoelectric voltage coefficient $g_{33} = \\\\SI{0.0250}{\\\\volt\\\\meter\\\\per\\\\newton}$. The spoke is perfectly rigidly attached to the disc with negligible slip. Assume a uniform, static magnetic field $\\\\mathbf{B} = B_0 \\\\hat{z}$ permeates the setup, with $B_0 = \\\\SI{2.00}{\\\\tesla}$.\\n\\nAs the disc rotates with angular velocity $\\\\omega$, these effects occur:\\n\\n1. **Motional EMF across disc:**\\n\\n\\\\[\\n\\\\mathcal{E}_{\\\\text{mot}} = \\\\frac{1}{2} B_0 \\\\omega R^2\\n\\\\]\\n\\n2. **Piezoelectric voltage across spoke:** The centrifugal force per unit length is $dF = \\\\lambda r \\\\omega^2 dr$, producing a total tension in the spoke of $F_{\\\\text{cent}} = \\\\int_0^R \\\\lambda r \\\\omega^2 dr = \\\\frac{1}{2} \\\\lambda \\\\omega^2 R^2$. The voltage generated is:\\n\\n\\\\[\\nV_{\\\\text{pz}} = g_{33} \\\\frac{F_{\\\\text{cent}}}{A_{\\\\text{spoke}}}\\n\\\\]\\n\\n3. **Electromagnetic (Lorentz) braking:** The combined voltage ($\\\\mathcal{E}_{\\\\text{mot}} + V_{\\\\text{pz}}$) drives a current $I$ radially from center to rim through the spoke and into a series external $LRC$ circuit ($R_{\\\\text{LRC}} = \\\\SI{10.0}{\\\\ohm}$, $L = \\\\SI{50.0}{\\\\milli\\\\henry}$, $C = \\\\SI{10.0}{\\\\micro\\\\farad}$). Assume steady-state ($t \\\\to \\\\infty$) so transients have vanished and only the resistor is relevant. The current is:\\n\\n\\\\[\\nI = \\\\frac{\\\\mathcal{E}_{\\\\text{mot}} + V_{\\\\text{pz}}}{R_{\\\\text{LRC}}}\\n\\\\]\\n\\nThe Lorentz force on each infinitesimal element $dr$ of the spoke is $dF = I B_0 dr$, so the torque about the disc axis is:\\n\\n\\\\[\\n\\\\tau_{\\\\text{EM}} = \\\\int_0^R r (I B_0) dr = I B_0 \\\\frac{R^2}{2}\\n\\\\]\\n\\n(This opposes $\\\\omega$.)\\n\\n4. **Drag torque from residual gas:**\\n\\n\\\\[\\n\\\\tau_{\\\\text{drag}} = -\\\\gamma_D \\\\omega,\\\\quad \\\\gamma_D = \\\\SI{5.00e-4}{\\\\kilogram\\\\,\\\\meter^2\\\\per\\\\second}\\n\\\\]\\n\\nInitially, the disc is at rest ($\\\\omega(0) = 0$). At $t=0$, a relativistic particle of rest mass $m_0 = \\\\SI{1.672e-27}{\\\\kilogram}$ and total energy $E_{\\\\text{part}} = \\\\SI{10.0}{\\\\giga\\\\electronvolt}$ ($1\\\\ \\\\mathrm{GeV} = 1.60218 \\\\times 10^{-10}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{J}$) travels parallel to the disc plane and strikes the rim tangentially, sticking perfectly inelastically. The particle's speed is $v = c \\\\sqrt{1 - \\\\left(\\\\frac{m_0 c^2}{E_{\\\\text{part}}}\\\\right)^2}$ and its instantaneous angular momentum about the disc axis at impact is $L_{\\\\text{part}} = R \\\\times \\\\gamma m_0 v$ (with $\\\\gamma = E_{\\\\text{part}}/(m_0 c^2)$). The disc gains this angular momentum: $I \\\\omega(0^+) = L_{\\\\text{part}}$.\\n\\nAssume the disc\u2013spoke assembly is perfectly rigid, the rim impact does not damage the disc, and that gravitational, mechanical, and electrical effects beyond those described can be neglected. Frame-dragging, electromagnetic, drag, and gravitomagnetic torques act continuously as described above, but all orbital and gravitational redshift corrections to $B_0$ are to be ignored.\\n\\n**Question:**\\n\\nDetermine the unique steady-state (terminal) angular velocity $\\\\omega_{\\\\text{term}}$ (in $\\\\mathrm{rad/s}$, to three significant digits) attained by the disc long after the particle collision, i.e., $t \\\\to \\\\infty$, under the combined influence of all torques and circuit effects specified above. (Give your answer numerically in $\\\\mathrm{rad/s}$.)\

Consider a vertically oriented, hermetically sealed, rigid cylindrical chamber of height $H = 0.150\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$ and inner radius $R = 0.040\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$, with its axis aligned along the $z$-direction ($0 \\\\leq z \\\\leq H$), in a uniform gravitational field of magnitude $g = 9.80\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m/s}^2$ pointing in the $-\\\\hat{z}$ direction. The chamber's lower base at $z=0$ has a precisely machined circular opening of radius $r_0 = 0.010\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$, into which is tightly fitted a solid, perfectly elastic, incompressible metal plug of height $d = 0.020\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$ (so the plug's faces are flush with the chamber's inner base and extend $d$ below the base). The plug remains stationary due to a locking mechanism, and the cylindrical chamber walls and the chamber base are perfectly rigid and thermally conducting. All chamber and plug surfaces are ideal and impermeable to gas.\\n\\nThe chamber is initially evacuated and in thermal contact with a reservoir at temperature $T_0 = 300\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K}$. The following procedure is performed:\\n\\n1. The chamber is isothermally filled (slowly, from the side) with an ideal, monoatomic gas of molar mass $M = 0.0400\\\\ \\\\mathrm{kg/mol}$ (e.g., argon) until the absolute pressure everywhere inside the chamber is $P_0 = 1.50 \\\\times 10^5\\\\ \\\\mathrm{Pa}$ and the temperature remains $T_0$. The external atmospheric pressure is $P_{\\\\rm atm} = 1.00 \\\\times 10^5\\\\ \\\\mathrm{Pa}$.\\n\\n2. The chamber is sealed and disconnected from the reservoir. The locking mechanism is removed so the plug can move vertically but cannot rotate or leak gas.\\n\\n3. The chamber is then gently heated, so that the temperature of the gas increases uniformly and quasi-statically to a final value $T_f = 600\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K}$.\\n\\nThroughout, the metal plug is assumed perfectly rigid in shape except for the vertical direction ($z$), where it compresses elasticly under net force, with Young's modulus $E = 1.00 \\\\times 10^{11}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{Pa}$ and mass $m_p = 0.200\\\\ \\\\mathrm{kg}$. Its cross-sectional area is $A_p = \\\\pi r_0^2$.\\n\\nNeglect the mass of the gas and the buoyancy of the plug in the air below the chamber. The external pressure below the plug is $P_{\\\\rm atm}$ at all times. The coefficient of linear thermal expansion of the plug is $\\\\alpha_p = 1.20 \\\\times 10^{-5}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K}^{-1}$ and its specific heat is so large that its temperature always equals that of the gas.\\n\\nAssume all materials are ideal and ignore friction.\\n\\n\\\\textbf{Given:} $R=0.040\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$, $H=0.150\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$, $r_0=0.010\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$, $d=0.020\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$, $E=1.00 \\\\times 10^{11}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{Pa}$, $T_0=300\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K}$, $T_f=600\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K}$, $M=0.0400\\\\ \\\\mathrm{kg/mol}$, $P_0=1.50 \\\\times 10^5\\\\ \\\\mathrm{Pa}$, $P_{\\\\rm atm}=1.00 \\\\times 10^5\\\\ \\\\mathrm{Pa}$, $m_p=0.200\\\\ \\\\mathrm{kg}$, $\\\\alpha_p=1.20 \\\\times 10^{-5}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K}^{-1}$, $g=9.80\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m/s}^2$. Universal gas constant $R_u = 8.314\\\\ \\\\mathrm{J/(mol\\\\cdot K)}$.\\n\\n\\\\textbf{Problem:} After the system reaches equilibrium at $T_f$, what is the final vertical displacement $\\\\Delta h$ (in $\\\\mathrm{mm}$, rounded to two decimal places) of the top face of the metal plug relative to its initial position at $T_0$? (A positive $\\\\Delta h$ means the plug moves upward into the chamber; negative means downward, toward the exterior.)\

A flexible, heavy, conducting chain of total length $L = 2.00 \\\\, \\\\text{m}$ and non-uniform linear mass density $\\\\lambda(s) = \\\\lambda_0(1 + \\\\beta s)$, where $s$ is measured from the free end ($s=0$) to the trailing end ($s=L$), is initially at rest, draped over the highest point of a solid, uniform, conducting cylindrical pulley of radius $R = 0.150 \\\\, \\\\text{m}$ and mass $M_p = 10.0 \\\\, \\\\text{kg}$. The chain is released from rest at $t = 0$ so that $y_0 = 1.00 \\\\, \\\\text{m}$ of its length hangs vertically on the left side ($s \\\\in [0, y_0]$), while the remainder ($s \\\\in (y_0, L]$) lies vertically on the right side, both sides almost touching but not in contact except at the rim; the midpoint of the pulley is exactly at $s = y_0$. The chain and pulley are on a train accelerating horizontally to the right with acceleration $a_0 = 3.00 \\\\, \\\\text{m/s}^2$. The chain and pulley are situated in a uniform, static magnetic field $\\\\vec{B}_0$ of magnitude $B_0 = 1.50 \\\\, \\\\text{T}$, which is everywhere aligned perpendicular to the page (i.e., parallel to the pulley's axle). Assume the chain hangs vertically on both sides at $t=0$ (immediately after release), with no horizontal motion yet. All frictional and electromagnetic braking torque are negligible at the initial instant ($t=0$), as the system is at rest. The chain does not slip on the pulley, and the radius of the chain itself is negligible compared to the pulley's radius. Use $\\\\lambda_0 = 0.500 \\\\, \\\\text{kg/m}$ and $\\\\beta = 0.025 \\\\, \\\\text{m}^{-1}$. The vertical direction is $+\\\\hat{y}$ upward, and gravity has magnitude $g = 9.81 \\\\, \\\\text{m/s}^2$.\\n\\nThe pulley is a solid cylinder (centered at the midpoint between the chain's two suspended segments), and its moment of inertia is $I = (1/2)M_p R^2$. Ignore air resistance and all contact friction at $t=0$. The train's pseudo-force is to be fully included in the effective force balance in the non-inertial (train) frame. \\n\\nAt the instant immediately after release ($t=0^+$), both the left and right arms of the chain are vertical, and the chain just begins to move. Compute the \\\\\\\\emph{vertical jerk} (i.e., $j_y = \\\\dot{a}_y$), the time derivative of the vertical acceleration of the chain's center of mass, at $t = 0$, in SI units $(\\\\text{m/s}^3)$.\\n\\nGive your answer for $j_y$ in $\\\\text{m/s}^3$ with three significant digits.\

A spherical droplet of quark-gluon plasma (QGP) of radius $R_0 = 2.00 \\\\times 10^{-9}\\\\,\\\\text{m}$ and density $\\\\rho_{\\\\mathrm{QGP}} = 2.00 \\\\times 10^{18}\\\\,\\\\text{kg}\\\\,\\\\text{m}^{-3}$ is instantaneously created at rest at the origin ($z = 0$) in the laboratory frame. The droplet has an initial net electric charge $q_0 = +8e$, where $e = 1.602 \\\\times 10^{-19}\\\\,\\\\text{C}$. Immediately at $t=0$, it is imparted a velocity $\\\\vec{v}_0 = +0.800c\\\\,\\\\hat{k}$ along the $+z$ axis, where $c = 2.998 \\\\times 10^8\\\\,\\\\text{m}\\\\,\\\\text{s}^{-1}$. For $z > 0$, space is a vacuum with negligible external fields. For $z < 0$, the droplet propagates in a uniform, cold plasma which exerts a resistive drag force of magnitude $F_{\\\\text{drag}} = k_d v$, always antiparallel to the droplet\u2019s instantaneous velocity, with $k_d = 3.00 \\\\times 10^{-16}\\\\,\\\\text{kg}\\\\,\\\\text{s}^{-1}$. Simultaneously, a uniform and constant magnetic field $\\\\vec{B} = B_0\\\\,\\\\hat{i}$ fills all $z < 0$ with $B_0 = 1.00 \\\\times 10^5\\\\,\\\\text{T}$. The QGP droplet radiates isotropically as a perfect black body ($\\\\epsilon = 1.00$) with Stefan\u2013Boltzmann law power $P = \\\\sigma_{SB}A T^4$, where $A = 4\\\\pi R^2$ is the droplet\u2019s surface area, $\\\\sigma_{SB} = 5.670 \\\\times 10^{-8}\\\\,\\\\text{W}\\\\,\\\\text{m}^{-2}\\\\,\\\\text{K}^{-4}$, and its temperature $T$ evolves according to its specific heat capacity $C_V = c_v M$ with $c_v = 1.00 \\\\times 10^7\\\\,\\\\text{J}\\\\,\\\\text{kg}^{-1}\\\\,\\\\text{K}^{-1}$ (constant) and $M$ the instantaneous mass. Neglect all mass loss over the process. Assume the QGP remains spherical and homogeneous throughout, and relativistic effects are fully accounted for in its motion. The Lorentz force $\\\\vec{F}_{B}$ acts on the droplet only for $z < 0$. The droplet\u2019s internal temperature at creation is $T_0 = 5.00 \\\\times 10^{12}\\\\,\\\\text{K}$; its motion and cooling continue until its temperature drops to the critical hadronization value $T_c = 1.70 \\\\times 10^{12}\\\\,\\\\text{K}$ at which point it instantly ceases moving and radiating.\\\\n\\\\nCalculate the total arc length $S$ (in meters, to three significant figures) traversed by the center of mass of the QGP droplet from $t=0$ until $T = T_c$. Give your answer in SI units.\

A long, solid, electrically isolated cylindrical rod made of a type-I superconductor is initially at rest in its own rest frame $\\\\mathcal{S}'$ and has the following proper characteristics: mass $m_0 = 2.00\\\\ \\\\mathrm{kg}$, length $L_0 = 1.00\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$, and radius $r_0 = 1.00\\\\ \\\\mathrm{cm}$. Its initial and uniform temperature is $T_i = 1.50\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K}$, and its superconducting critical temperature is $T_c = 9.20\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K}$. The rod is then accelerated along the $z$-axis and moves at a constant speed $v_0 = 0.800c$ relative to the laboratory inertial frame $\\\\mathcal{S}$, where $c = 2.99792458 \\\\times 10^8\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m/s}$.\\\\\\n\\\\\\nThe rod enters, at $z=0$, a region $|z| \\\\ll L_0$ of static, spatially non-uniform magnetic field: $\\\\vec{B}(z) = B_0\\\\,\\\\text{sech}^2\\\\left(\\\\frac{z}{H}\\\\right) \\\\hat{x}$ in $\\\\mathcal{S}$, with $B_0 = 5.00\\\\ \\\\mathrm{T}$ and $H = 0.500\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$; $\\\\vec{E} = 0$ in $\\\\mathcal{S}$ throughout. The material's temperature-dependent critical magnetic field is $B_c(T) = B_{c0} (1 - (T/T_c)^2)$ with $B_{c0} = 0.200\\\\ \\\\mathrm{T}$. Neglect demagnetizing effects.\\\\\\n\\\\\\nThe superconducting state is lost (i.e., the sample quenches) at the first coordinate $z=z_q$ where, in the rod's instantaneous comoving frame $\\\\mathcal{S}'$, the transverse (to $\\\\vec{v}$) magnetic field satisfies $B'_\\\\perp(z_q) = B_c(T_i)$. The Lorentz transformation for magnetic field yields the transverse field in $\\\\mathcal{S}'$ as $B'_\\\\perp = \\\\gamma(v_0) B_x(z)$, where $\\\\gamma(v_0) = 1/\\\\sqrt{1-v_0^2/c^2}$.\\\\\\n\\\\\\nBeyond $z>z_q$, the rod is a normal conductor. As it moves (at $v_0\\\\hat{z}$) through the spatially varying $\\\\vec{B}(z)$, it experiences a motional electromotive force (emf) around its cross section, given by\\n\\\\[ \\\\mathcal{E}(z) = \\\\oint_{\\\\partial A} \\\\left( \\\\vec{v} \\\\times \\\\vec{B}(z) \\\\right)\\\\cdot d\\\\vec{\\\\ell} = 2\\\\pi r_0 v_0 B_x(z) \\\\] \\nwhere $A = \\\\pi r_0^2$ is the rod's cross-sectional area perpendicular to $z$ and $\\\\partial A$ its boundary.\\\\\\n\\\\\\nThe induced eddy currents in the rod form an effective closed loop (circumference $2\\\\pi r_0$) with self-inductance $L_s = 1.00 \\\\times 10^{-7}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{H}$ and resistance $R_n = 5.00 \\\\times 10^{-5}\\\\ \\\\Omega$ (both constant during the process). At $t=0$ (corresponding to $z=z_q$), the induced current is zero: $I(0)=0$. After the rod passes beyond the field region (as $z\\\\to+\\\\infty$), the current decays until the system is again at $I=0$.\\\\\\n\\\\\\nAll energy dissipated by Joule heating in the laboratory frame, given by $\\\\Delta Q = \\\\int_0^\\\\infty I^2(t) R_n dt$, is assumed to be instantaneously and homogeneously converted to the rod's internal energy in its own (proper) frame. The rod's electronic specific heat per unit mass is $c_v(T) = \\\\gamma_{el} T$ with $\\\\gamma_{el} = 10.0\\\\ \\\\mathrm{J} \\\\cdot \\\\mathrm{kg}^{-1} \\\\cdot \\\\mathrm{K}^{-2}$, and all other contributions, including latent heat, phonons, and thermal radiation, are negligible.\\\\\\n\\\\\\nAssume relativistic corrections as specified above for field transformations but neglect any delay or anisotropy in thermalization; take all energy calculated in the laboratory frame as immediately increasing the rod's proper internal energy.\\\\\\n\\\\\\nGiven these data, calculate the rod's final proper temperature $T_f$ after it has fully traversed the field region ($z \\\\to +\\\\infty$ and the current has decayed), and express the result \\\\\\\\boxed{T_f~[\\\\mathrm{K}]} with three significant figures.\

A solid cylindrical rod made of a high-purity niobium alloy (mass $m = 0.600\\\\ \\\\mathrm{kg}$, length $L = 0.800\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$, radius $r = 5.28 \\\\times 10^{-3}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$, and uniform cross-section $A_c = \\\\pi r^2$) is released from rest at position $z = 0$ at time $t = 0$, descending vertically under gravity ($z$ increases downwards, with $z = 0$ at the top of the region of interest) between two ideally frictionless, perfectly conducting rails inside a vacuum chamber. The rods' length is always perpendicular to $z$, and it remains parallel to the rails at all times. \\n\\nThe environment is a blackbody at uniform temperature $T_{\\\\mathrm{env}} = 4.20\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K}$, with radiative exchange occurring only between the rod (surface area $A_{\\\\mathrm{surf}} = 2\\\\pi r L$) and the walls. The view factor is unity. The rails do not contribute any electrical or thermal interaction\u2014edddy currents are confined to the rod, and all current returns via the rod-rail interface. There is no mechanical or electrical friction anywhere in the system (specifically: $\\\\mu_k = 0$). \\n\\nA spatially non-uniform vertical magnetic field (oriented $\\\\mathbf{B} = B(z)\\\\,\\\\mathbf{e}_x$, always perpendicular to velocity) is imposed:\\n\\\\[\\n  B(z) = B_0 \\\\left( \\\\frac{z}{z_p} \\\\right) \\\\exp \\\\left(1 - \\\\frac{z}{z_p}\\\\right), \\\\qquad \\\\text{with} \\\\quad B_0 = 2.50\\\\ \\\\mathrm{T}, \\\\; z_p = 2.00\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}, \\\\; \\\\text{and}\\\\; B(0) = 0.\\n\\\\]\\n\\nThe rod's temperature $T(t)$ is spatially uniform at all times (lumped-capacitance approximation). Initial values are\\n\\\\[\\n  z(0) = 0, \\\\quad v(0) = 0, \\\\quad T(0) = 77.0\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K},\\n\\\\]\\nwhere $v(t) = \\\\mathrm{d}z/\\\\mathrm{d}t$.\\n\\nThe rod experiences only two forces: gravity, $+mg$, and Lenz-damping due to motional (induced) current. No additional non-inertial (Coriolis) effects are present, since the velocity is purely vertical and Earth's rotation along $z$ is negligible. The equation of motion is therefore:\\n\\\\[\\n  m \\\\frac{\\\\mathrm{d}v}{\\\\mathrm{d}t} = m g - \\\\frac{L^2 B(z)^2}{R(T)} v(t)\\n\\\\]\\n\\nThe current $I = (L B(z) v)/R(T)$ induced in the rod causes resistive Joule heating, raising its temperature, while blackbody emission cools it. The temperature evolution is modeled as:\\n\\\\[\\n  m c_p(T) \\\\frac{\\\\mathrm{d}T}{\\\\mathrm{d}t} = \\\\frac{L^2 B(z)^2}{R(T)} v(t)^2 - \\\\sigma_{SB} \\\\epsilon A_{\\\\mathrm{surf}} \\\\big[ T(t)^4 - T_{\\\\mathrm{env}}^4 \\\\big]\\n\\\\]\\nwith $\\\\epsilon = 0.15$ (emissivity), and Stefan\u2013Boltzmann constant $\\\\sigma_{SB} = 5.670 \\\\times 10^{-8}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{W}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{m}^{-2}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{K}^{-4}$.\\n\\nThe rod's total electrical resistance is\\n\\\\[\\n  R(T) = \\\\frac{L}{A_c}\\\\,\\\\rho(T),\\n\\\\]\\nwhere $\\\\rho(T)$ is the Bloch\u2013Gr\u00fcneisen resistivity for niobium:\\n\\\\[\\n  \\\\rho(T) = \\\\rho_{\\\\mathrm{res}} + C_{\\\\mathrm{BG}} \\\\left( \\\\frac{T}{\\\\Theta_D} \\\\right)^5 \\\\int_0^{\\\\Theta_D/T} \\\\frac{x^5}{(e^x - 1)(1-e^{-x})}\\\\, \\\\mathrm{d}x\\n\\\\]\\nwith parameters:\\n- Residual resistivity: $\\\\rho_{\\\\mathrm{res}} = 1.0 \\\\times 10^{-9}\\\\ \\\\Omega\\\\,\\\\mathrm{m}$\\n- Bloch\u2013Gr\u00fcneisen constant: $C_{\\\\mathrm{BG}} = 1.51 \\\\times 10^{-7}\\\\ \\\\Omega\\\\,\\\\mathrm{m}$\\n- Debye temperature: $\\\\Theta_D = 275\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K}$\\n\\nFor simplicity, use the following table of $\\\\rho(T)$ values:\\n\\\\begin{align*}\\n  \\\\text{At}\\\\ T = 4.2\\\\,\\\\mathrm{K}: &\\\\quad \\\\rho(4.2) = 1.13 \\\\times 10^{-9}\\\\ \\\\Omega\\\\,\\\\mathrm{m} \\\\\\\\\\n  T = 30.0\\\\,\\\\mathrm{K}: &\\\\quad \\\\rho(30) = 3.33 \\\\times 10^{-9}\\\\ \\\\Omega\\\\,\\\\mathrm{m} \\\\\\\\\\n  T = 77.0\\\\,\\\\mathrm{K}: &\\\\quad \\\\rho(77) = 1.04 \\\\times 10^{-8}\\\\ \\\\Omega\\\\,\\\\mathrm{m}\\n\\\\end{align*}\\nAssume $\\\\rho_{\\\\mathrm{res}}$ is negligible for $T \\\\geq 77~\\\\mathrm{K}$ and interpolate linearly between the above values as needed. For $T > 77\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K}$, use $\\\\rho(T) = \\\\rho(77) \\\\big( T/77.0 \\\\big)$.\\n\\nRegarding heat capacity, use for all $T$:\\n\\\\[\\n  c_p(T) = 265\\\\ \\\\mathrm{J}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{kg}^{-1}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{K}^{-1}.\\n\\\\]\\n\\nConstants for calculations:\\n\\\\begin{align*}\\n  g &= 9.81\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{s}^{-2} \\\\\\\\\\n  \\\\pi &= 3.1416\\n\\\\end{align*}\\n\\n\\\\textbf{Final Task:}\\n\\n\\\\textit{Numerically solve the coupled ODEs for $z(t)$, $v(t)$, and $T(t)$ given above, for the rod released at $z = 0$, $T = 77.0\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K}$, $v = 0$ at $t=0$. Using all the assumptions and data as given, determine the numerically exact value (to three significant digits) of the maximum downward velocity $v_{\\\\mathrm{max}}$ (in units of $\\\\mathrm{m}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{s}^{-1}$) achieved by the rod at any point during its descent, \\\\\\\\textbf{assuming the rod never leaves the region where $B(z) \\\\geq 0$ and that $T(t)$ remains finite at all times}.}\

A solid, cylindrical cobalt-based superalloy flywheel of initial length $L_0 = 0.750\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$ and initial radius $R_0 = 0.050\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$ is rigidly mounted inside a fully autonomous probe. The probe is in a stable, prograde, circular orbit of Boyer-Lindquist coordinate radius $r_p = 8.00\\\\, GM/c^2$ in the equatorial plane ($\\\\theta = \\\\pi/2$) of a Kerr black hole of mass $M = 7.50 \\\\times 10^{30}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{kg}$ and dimensionless spin parameter $a_* = 0.95$. The probe\u2019s orbital velocity (as measured by a local observer at infinity) is $v_p \\\\ll c$ so that non-relativistic kinetic energy formulas are a good approximation in the flywheel's proper frame; the probe\u2019s own frame is adopted as a local proper-inertial (ZAMO) frame, neglecting gravitational redshifts between the probe and the flywheel.  \\n\\nThe flywheel is fabricated from a hypothetical single-phase, high-strength polycrystalline cobalt-based superalloy with the following properties (assumed constant over all relevant temperatures except where noted):\\n\\\\begin{align*}\\n  \\\\rho_m &= 9250\\\\ \\\\mathrm{kg}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{m}^{-3} \\\\\\\\\\n  E &= 220\\\\ \\\\mathrm{GPa} \\\\\\\\\\n  \\\\nu &= 0.32 \\\\\\\\\\n  M_{\\\\mathrm{mol}} &= 0.0591\\\\ \\\\mathrm{kg}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{mol}^{-1} \\\\\\\\\\n  T_C &= 1388\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K} ~ \\\\text{(Curie temperature)} \\\\\\\\\\n  T_M &= 1768\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K} ~ \\\\text{(melting point, fusion latent heat applies)} \\\\\\\\\\n  T_B &= 3200\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K} ~ \\\\text{(boiling point, vaporisation latent heat applies)} \\\\\\\\\\n  L_{\\\\mathrm{mag}} &= 1.8\\\\times 10^4 \\\\ \\\\mathrm{J}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{kg}^{-1} ~ \\\\text{(latent heat of ferromagnetic phase transition at } T_C\\\\text{)} \\\\\\\\\\n  L_{\\\\mathrm{f}} &= 2.5 \\\\times 10^5 \\\\ \\\\mathrm{J}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{kg}^{-1} ~ \\\\text{(latent heat of fusion at } T_M\\\\text{)} \\\\\\\\\\n  L_{\\\\mathrm{v}} &= 6.3 \\\\times 10^6 \\\\ \\\\mathrm{J}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{kg}^{-1} ~ \\\\text{(latent heat of vaporisation at } T_B\\\\text{)}\\n\\\\end{align*}\\n\\nThe specific heat at constant volume $c_V(T)$ of the solid phase is:\\n\\\\begin{cases}\\n  c_V(T) = \\\\gamma T + A T^3 & (T \\\\leq \\\\Theta_D) \\\\\\\\ \\n  c_V(T) = \\\\gamma T + 3R_s & (\\\\Theta_D < T < T_M) \\\\\\\\\\n\\\\end{cases}\\nwhere $\\\\gamma = 0.0815\\\\ \\\\mathrm{J}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{kg}^{-1}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{K}^{-2}$ (electronic term), $\\\\Theta_D = 445\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K}$ (Debye temperature), $R = 8.314\\\\ \\\\mathrm{J}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{mol}^{-1}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{K}^{-1}$, $R_s = R/M_{\\\\mathrm{mol}}$, and $A = \\\\dfrac{12 \\\\pi^4 R_s}{5 \\\\Theta_D^3}$. Treat $c_V$ as remaining $\\\\gamma T + 3R_s$ for all $T$ between $T_M$ and $T_B$ (ignore the small difference between $c_V$ and $c_p$). Latent heats must be included at $T_C$, $T_M$, and $T_B$ (in that order) if crossed.\\n\\nThe flywheel is initially at uniform temperature $T_0 = 15.0\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K}$. It spins at angular velocity $\\\\Omega_0 = 5.00 \\\\times 10^{4}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{rad}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{s}^{-1}$ about its axis.\\n\\nAt time $t=0$, a catastrophic failure occurs: the rotor undergoes an instantaneous, rigid braking event and comes to rest relative to the probe. During this process, all of the following energies are dissipated internally and adiabatically (no heat is exchanged with the probe or environment):\\n\\n1. The entire initial rotational kinetic energy ($U_K$) of the flywheel, $U_K = \\\\frac{1}{2}I\\\\Omega_0^2$, where the moment of inertia $I = \\\\frac{1}{2} M_{\\\\mathrm{rot}} R_0^2$ and $M_{\\\\mathrm{rot}} = \\\\rho_m \\\\pi R_0^2 L_0$ (neglect centrifugal deformation).\\n\\n2. The total elastic stored (centrifugal) strain energy ($U_E$), assuming a solid, closed-end cylinder under plane-strain: $U_E = \\\\mathcal{C}_E(\\\\nu) M_{\\\\mathrm{rot}} R_0^2 \\\\Omega_0^2$, where $\\\\mathcal{C}_E(\\\\nu) = \\\\frac{3-2\\\\nu}{8}$ (units are consistent; do not substitute $E$ in denominator).\\n\\n3. The quantum-vacuum friction heat dissipated ($U_S$) inside the rotor due to the probe\u2019s immersion in an external uniform magnetic field of magnitude $B_{\\\\mathrm{ext}} = 1.20 \\\\times 10^{9}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{T}$: $U_S = \\\\eta V_{\\\\mathrm{rot}} \\\\left(\\\\frac{B_{\\\\mathrm{ext}}}{B_{\\\\mathrm{crit}}}\\\\right)^2 \\\\frac{\\\\hbar \\\\Omega_0^2}{c}$, where $V_{\\\\mathrm{rot}} = \\\\pi R_0^2 L_0$, $\\\\eta = 0.250$ (dimensionless), $B_{\\\\mathrm{crit}} = \\\\frac{m_e^2 c^3}{e \\\\hbar}$ is the Schwinger critical field, $m_e = 9.109 \\\\times 10^{-31}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{kg}$, $e = 1.602 \\\\times 10^{-19}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{C}$, $c = 2.998 \\\\times 10^8\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{s}^{-1}$, and $\\\\hbar = 1.054 \\\\times 10^{-34}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{J}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{s}$.\\n\\nAssume:\\n- During braking, all $U_K$, $U_E$, and $U_S$ are deposited as heat uniformly within the rotor, with no energy exchange to or from the environment.\\n- All phase transitions (Curie, fusion, vaporisation) occur at sharply defined temperatures, and every latent heat is added at the corresponding transition if that transition temperature is surpassed during heating.\\n- No change in rotor shape or mass occurs during the process. Thermal expansion, melting, or boiling do not alter the density or dimensions for the purposes of this analysis.\\n- The flywheel remains entirely on the equatorial plane of the Kerr geometry; frame-dragging, redshift, and relativistic effects are negligible for all energetic calculations, consistent with the local proper (probe) frame.\\n- Ignore all energy losses except where strictly specified above.\\n\\n\\\\textbf{Question:}\\n\\nCalculate the final equilibrium temperature $T_f$ (in $\\\\mathrm{K}$) of the flywheel after all dissipated energy is equilibrated internally. $T_f$ may lie above or below $T_B$, depending on the cumulative heating. (\\\\textit{Your answer should be the unique $T_f$ [in $\\\\mathrm{K}$] defined by $U_K + U_E + U_S = \\\\Delta U_{\\\\mathrm{internal}}$, with all latent heats at $T_C$, $T_M$, and $T_B$ included sequentially if their temperature is crossed.})\

A vertical, thermally and mechanically isolated cylindrical chamber of height $H = 1.00\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$ and \\\\\\\\textbf{internal cross-sectional area} $A = 0.360\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}^2$ contains $n = 5.00$ moles of argon gas (molar mass $M = 39.95\\\\times 10^{-3}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{kg/mol}$, van der Waals constants $a = 1.355\\\\,\\\\mathrm{J\\\\,m}^3/\\\\mathrm{mol}^2$, $b = 3.211\\\\times 10^{-5}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{m}^3/\\\\mathrm{mol}$, and constant $C_{v,m} = 12.47\\\\,\\\\mathrm{J/(mol\\\\,K)}$). The \\\\\\\\textbf{entire top} of the chamber is sealed by a rigid, perfectly insulating plate. The \\\\\\\\textbf{bottom} of the chamber is a frictionless, massless, perfectly conducting \\\\\\\\textbf{movable piston} of area $A = 0.360\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}^2$, which faces atmospheric pressure $P_{\\\\mathrm{atm}} = 1.00\\\\times 10^5\\\\ \\\\mathrm{Pa}$ and is acted on by gravity ($g = 9.81\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m/s}^2$). (Assume the piston is perfectly gas-tight and is the only mobile boundary.)\\\\\\\\\\n\\nAffixed to the piston is the upper plate of a parallel-plate capacitor, with both plates of area $A$ and separated vertically by a variable gap $d$ (where $0 < d \\\\leq H$), so the bottom plate is always flush with the interior cylinder bottom. The capacitor plates are always parallel, horizontal, perfectly conducting, and occupy the entire cross-section of the cylinder (so the plates serve as both gas boundary and capacitor plates\u2014matching exactly the piston and chamber bottoms). The capacitor is connected at all times via ideal wires to a battery which maintains the potential difference $V_0 = 800.0\\\\ \\\\mathrm{V}$. The capacitor is initially \\\\\\\\textbf{empty} (i.e., only gas is present; no dielectric), and the \\\\\\\\textbf{initial plate separation} is $d_i$.\\\\\\\\\\n\\nA thick, rigid dielectric slab of mass $m_s = 2.50\\\\ \\\\mathrm{kg}$, dimensions $A \\\\times d_s$ (where $d_s = d_i$ initially), dielectric constant $\\\\kappa = 6.0$, and specific heat $c_s = 1560\\\\ \\\\mathrm{J/(kg\\\\,K)}$, is suspended outside the system and initially held at the same temperature as the argon, $T_i = 300.0\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K}$.\\\\\\\\\\n\\nThe system is perfectly insulated so no energy or matter enters or leaves the chamber at any stage. All relevant objects (piston, plates, and chamber walls) are massless and have zero heat capacity unless otherwise specified.\\\\\\\\\\n\\n\\\\\\\\textbf{Process:} The battery maintains $V_0$ at all times. At $t=0$, the dielectric slab is gently inserted entirely vertically into the capacitor (between the plates) without touching the walls, so that it completely and snugly fills the plate gap (i.e., $d_f = d_s$ at the end, where $d_f$ is the final plate separation after all mechanical and thermal equilibration). The slab is lowered \\\\\\\\textbf{slowly from above} so that its weight is continuously supported by an external hand (so it acts as a constant-mass object, and its potential energy change is completely transferred to the rest of the system). Full mechanical, thermal, and electromagnetic equilibrium is established in the final state.\\\\\\\\\\n\\nThe battery and the external hand supplying the slab each supply or absorb any energy; both remain at constant temperature (i.e., are infinitely large reservoirs for energy transfer). The only energy exchange allowed is work and electrical energy; no heat or mass leaves or enters the system.\\\\\\\\\\n\\n\\\\\\\\textbf{Assume:}\\n\\\\begin{itemize}\\n    \\\\item The pressure on the gas is the force per unit area exerted on the piston by (i) the gas, (ii) atmospheric pressure outside (1 bar), (iii) the slab weight if present, and (iv) the electrostatic forces produced by the battery-driven capacitor (including the field energy and battery work).\\n    \\\\item The argon obeys the van der Waals equation: $\\\\left[P + a\\\\left( \\\\frac{n}{V} \\\\right)^2 \\\\right] (V - n b) = n R T$ ($R = 8.314\\\\,\\\\mathrm{J/(mol\\\\,K)}$). The relevant pressure $P$ is the mechanical pressure exerted by the gas on the moving piston.\\n    \\\\item The battery has negligible internal resistance: electrical energy delivered to the capacitor goes into field energy and/or is dissipated as heat in situ if required by the first law.\\n    \\\\item Dielectric slab, argon, chamber interior, and plates reach common final temperature $T_f$ after equilibration.\\n    \\\\item All energy transfers are quasi-static and reversible except for lossless mechanical coupling by the external hand.\\n    \\\\item Neglect edge/fringing effects (parallel plate approximation is accurate).\\n    \\\\item Ignore thermal expansion of the slab and any temperature dependence of $\\\\kappa$; the slab always fits snugly between the plates at $d_f$.\\n    \\\\item Heat capacity of argon and slab are both temperature-independent over the relevant range.\\n\\\\end{itemize}\\n\\n\\\\\\\\textbf{Given:}\\n\\\\begin{align*}\\nA &= 0.360\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}^2 \\\\\\\\nH &= 1.00\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m} \\\\\\\\nP_{\\\\mathrm{atm}} &= 1.00 \\\\times 10^5\\\\ \\\\mathrm{Pa} \\\\\\\\nV_0 &= 800.0\\\\ \\\\mathrm{V} \\\\\\\\nd_i &= 0.0300\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m} \\\\\\\\nd_s &= 0.0300\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m} \\\\\\\\nm_s &= 2.50\\\\ \\\\mathrm{kg} \\\\\\\\n\\\\kappa &= 6.0 \\\\\\\\nc_s &= 1560\\\\ \\\\mathrm{J/(kg\\\\,K)} \\\\\\\\nM &= 39.95 \\\\times 10^{-3}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{kg/mol} \\\\\\\\na &= 1.355\\\\ \\\\mathrm{J\\\\,m}^3/\\\\mathrm{mol}^2 \\\\\\\\nb &= 3.211 \\\\times 10^{-5}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}^3/\\\\mathrm{mol} \\\\\\\\nC_{v,m} &= 12.47\\\\ \\\\mathrm{J/(mol\\\\,K)} \\\\\\\\nn &= 5.00 \\\\\\\\nT_i &= 300.0\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K} \\\\\\\\ng &= 9.81\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m/s}^2\\n\\\\end{align*}\\n\\n\\\\\\\\textbf{Question:} After complete insertion of the slab and full equilibrium, \\\\\\\\textbf{what is the final common temperature $T_f$ (in K) of the argon-dielectric system?}\\\\\\\\\\n\\n(\\\\\\\\textit{Give your answer to three significant digits, boxed, together with appropriate SI units. Justify all steps symbolically before numerical substitution.})\

A perfectly flexible uniform chain of total mass $m = 18.0~\\\\mathrm{kg}$ and length $L = 12.0~\\\\mathrm{m}$ rests fully coiled atop a frictionless platform of mass $M = 38.0~\\\\mathrm{kg}$ at initial height $H = 31.0~\\\\mathrm{m}$ above the ground. At time $t = 0$, the platform is released from rest and descends vertically under the action of gravity, but its downward acceleration is held constant at $a = 1.90~\\\\mathrm{m/s}^2$ by an external, precisely controlled mechanism. The platform's motion is not influenced by the changing load of the chain. As the platform descends, the chain unwraps at a constant rate (as measured in the ground frame): at any time $t$, the length of chain hanging straight down from the platform is $\\\\ell(t) = (L/T) t$, where $T$ is the total time required for the full chain to uncoil, and $\\\\ell(0) = 0$. The uncoiling rate $L/T$ is constant, and $T$ is explicitly given: $T = 4.00~\\\\mathrm{s}$. Assume the hanging chain always remains vertical, and neglect air resistance.\\n\\nAt time $t_1 = T/2 = 2.00~\\\\mathrm{s}$ (when exactly half the chain by length and mass is hanging), an ideal, instantaneous explosion splits the hanging portion exactly at its midpoint. Each resulting fragment, of mass $m/4$ and length $L/4$, receives an additional horizontal velocity $\\\\Delta v = 7.20~\\\\mathrm{m/s}$ in the $+x$ and $-x$ directions, respectively, in the ground frame, perpendicular to gravity. Immediately after the explosion, the remainder of the chain on the platform is fixed rigidly to it; the explosion exerts no impulse or recoil on the platform or the secured chain. The vertical velocities of all parts remain unchanged at the instant of the explosion.\\n\\nGiven $g = 9.81~\\\\mathrm{m/s^2}$, calculate the horizontal distance $\\\\Delta x$ in meters between the landing points of the two chain fragments on the ground. Express your final answer as $\\\\boxed{\\\\Delta x = ~~~\\\\mathrm{m}}$.\

A solid homogeneous disk of mass $M = 6.20~\\\\mathrm{kg}$ and radius $R = 0.210~\\\\mathrm{m}$ is rigidly fixed to rotate frictionlessly on a horizontal axle through its center. A flexible, massless rope is wound $n=5$ times around the disk's perimeter, so that when the free end is pulled vertically downward by a compact mass $m = 1.30~\\\\mathrm{kg}$, the rope maintains taut contact and the disk rotates without slip. The system starts from rest, with the mass positioned $h = 3.00~\\\\mathrm{m}$ vertically above the ground. Neglect the mass of both rope and coil in all calculations.\\n\\nFirmly attached to the rope at a point immediately below the disk is a rigid rectangular copper coil with $N=1500$ identical turns, each of area $A=a b$ where $a=0.140~\\\\mathrm{m}$ and $b=0.070~\\\\mathrm{m}$. The coil's total electrical resistance is $R = 12.0~\\\\Omega$ and its self-inductance is $L = 32.0~\\\\mathrm{mH}$. As the mass descends, the coil moves vertically, always remaining aligned horizontally (its plane is normal to $\\\\hat{z}$), and maintains pure translation relative to the ground. Initially, the center of the coil is at height $z = h$ above the ground.\\n\\nThe coil passes through a vertically non-uniform, axisymmetric magnetic field given by $\\\\vec{B}(z) = \\\\gamma z ~\\\\hat{z}$, where $\\\\gamma = 1.50~\\\\mathrm{T/m}$ is a spatial constant gradient. There is no uniform component of the field. The system is in vacuum and all frictional, air, or mechanical losses except electrical are negligible. On reaching $z=0$, the compact mass gently contacts the ground without bounce and the coil's motion and current subsequently decay freely due to the inductor and resistor; no external forces act on the coil or disk after contact.\\n\\nAssume standard gravity $g = 9.81~\\\\mathrm{m/s}^2$. Universal constants: $\\\\mu_0 = 4\\\\pi \\\\times 10^{-7}~\\\\mathrm{T \\\\cdot m/A}$, $\\\\varepsilon_0 = 8.85 \\\\times 10^{-12}~\\\\mathrm{F/m}$.\\n\\nThe initial system is at rest with no current; at the end, both the disk and coil may possess nonzero rotational and translational kinetic energy, while the circuit may still carry current and thus have magnetic energy stored.\\n\\n\\\\\\\\boxed{\\\\textbf{Calculate the total thermal energy in Joules ($\\\\mathrm{J}$) dissipated in the coil resistance $R$ from the moment the mass is released at $z=h$ until all coil current has fully decayed to zero at $z=0$, accounting for all electromagnetic induction, rotational and translational kinetic and potential energies, nonuniform $\\\\vec{B}(z)$, inductor self-energy, rope/disk mechanics, and assuming the mass, disk, rope, and coil have exactly the stated properties. Give your final answer numerically in SI units, boxed.}}\

A vertical cylindrical vessel of inner radius $R = 0.500\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$ and height $h = 1.00\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$ is exactly filled with liquid sodium, which has mass density $\\\\rho_0 = 927.0\\\\ \\\\mathrm{kg\\\\, m^{-3}}$ at the reference temperature $T_{\\\\mathrm{ref}} = 400.0\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K}$. The top circular end of the cylinder is a perfectly absorbing/plain blackbody surface (emissivity $\\\\epsilon = 1.00$), exposed to ambient radiation from the cosmic microwave background at temperature $T_{\\\\mathrm{CMB}} = 2.725\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K}$. The bottom and lateral wall surfaces are ideal thermal insulators. The sodium column rotates steadily about its axis, the velocity field (in cylindrical coordinates $r,\\\\varphi,z$) being maintained by a mechanical drive that exerts a steady external torque on the fluid such that\\n\\\\[\\n\\\\mathbf{v}(r) = \\\\Omega_0 r \\\\left(1 - \\\\frac{r^2}{R^2}\\\\right) \\\\hat{\\\\boldsymbol{\\\\varphi}}\\n\\\\]\\nwith $\\\\Omega_0 = 10.0\\\\ \\\\mathrm{rad/s}$.\\n\\nSimultaneously, a time-varying but spatially uniform external magnetic field is imposed along the cylinder axis:\\n\\\\[\\n\\\\mathbf{B}_{\\\\mathrm{ext}}(t) = B_0 \\\\sin(\\\\omega t) \\\\hat{\\\\mathbf{z}}\\n\\\\]\\nwhere $B_0 = 0.200\\\\ \\\\mathrm{T}$ and $\\\\omega = 1.00\\\\ \\\\mathrm{rad/s}$. The vessel is a perfect electrical insulator at all boundaries: no conduction path exists for induced electric currents through the top, bottom, or side walls. The sodium is an ohmic conductor with temperature-dependent conductivity\\n\\\\[\\n\\\\sigma(T) = \\\\frac{\\\\sigma_{\\\\mathrm{ref}}}{1 + \\\\alpha_c (T-T_{\\\\mathrm{ref}})}\\n\\\\]\\nwhere $\\\\sigma_{\\\\mathrm{ref}} = 1.00 \\\\times 10^7\\\\ \\\\mathrm{S\\\\,m^{-1}}$ and $\\\\alpha_c = 2.50 \\\\times 10^{-3}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K}^{-1}$. The kinematic viscosity is\\n\\\\[\\n\\\\nu(T) = \\\\nu_{\\\\mathrm{ref}} \\\\exp\\\\left(\\\\frac{A_{\\\\nu}}{T}\\\\right)\\n\\\\]\\nwith $\\\\nu_{\\\\mathrm{ref}} = 7.50 \\\\times 10^{-7}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m^2\\\\,s^{-1}}$ and $A_{\\\\nu} = 780.0\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K}$. The specific heat at constant pressure is $c_p = 1380.0\\\\ \\\\mathrm{J\\\\,kg^{-1}\\\\,K^{-1}}$, assumed temperature-independent, and the Stefan\u2013Boltzmann constant is $\\\\sigma_{SB} = 5.670374 \\\\times 10^{-8}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{W\\\\, m^{-2}\\\\,K^{-4}}$.\\n\\nAssume the following (all are to be used):\\n\\n- Thermal and electrical effects of the vessel walls are negligible: no heat transfer or current flow occurs at any boundary except for blackbody radiation from the upper circular surface.\\n- The sodium undergoes no mass loss and is homogeneous at all times.\\n- The mechanical drive maintains the velocity profile by supplying the exact power lost to viscous dissipation, and this entire power is transformed to heat within the sodium.\\n- The electrical boundary conditions ensure that only displacement (not conduction) currents can traverse the vessel boundaries; all induced electric fields and currents reside inside the sodium volume (i.e., the system behaves like a finite, fully insulated, ohmic medium).\\n- The fluid\u2019s mass density $\\\\rho_0$ remains constant for all $T$.\\n- The magnetic Reynolds number is so small that all magnetic induction effects and the $\\\\mathbf{v} \\\\times \\\\mathbf{B}$ term are negligible compared to motional EMF from $\\\\partial \\\\mathbf{B}_{\\\\mathrm{ext}}/\\\\partial t$ alone.\\n- Heat dissipation is exclusively by blackbody emission from the top surface, of area $A = \\\\pi R^2$; conduction/convection/other losses are zero.\\n\\nThe sodium eventually attains a steady-state uniform temperature $T_{\\\\mathrm{ss}}$ at which the combined power dissipated by viscous and Joule heating equals the net radiated power. The vessel starts at $T_{\\\\mathrm{ref}}$ and reaches $T_{\\\\mathrm{ss}}$; the associated increase in the system\u2019s total rest mass is given by\\n\\\\[\\n\\\\Delta M_{\\\\mathrm{rest}} = \\\\frac{M_{\\\\mathrm{Na}} c_p \\\\left(T_{\\\\mathrm{ss}} - T_{\\\\mathrm{ref}}\\\\right)}{c^2}\\n\\\\]\\nwhere $M_{\\\\mathrm{Na}} = \\\\rho_0 \\\\pi R^2 h$ and $c = 2.99792458 \\\\times 10^8\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m/s}$.\\n\\nUsing all the above, and taking and showing all temperature dependencies fully into account, calculate the final steady-state temperature $T_{\\\\mathrm{ss}}$ (in kelvin) attained by the sodium. Give your answer numerically to three significant digits.\\n\\n**Final question:**\\n\\nWhat is the steady-state temperature $T_{\\\\mathrm{ss}}$ of the sodium, in $\\\\mathrm{K}$?\

Consider a solid cylindrical rod of high-purity aluminum, used as a moving bridge completing an electrical circuit between two parallel, perfectly conducting, fixed rails. The rails and rod are located in the equatorial plane at Schwarzschild coordinate radius $r$ in the spacetime of a nonrotating black hole of mass $M$. The rails are rigid, frictionless, non-expanding, and massless. The rod moves strictly radially inward under gravity. The electromagnetic environment is defined as follows: at the center of coordinates $(r=0)$, a stationary, axially symmetric, classical point magnetic dipole of moment $\\\\vec{\\\\mu}$ is aligned along the $z$-axis and does not vary over time. Assume that the Schwarzschild spacetime is weakly curved in the region $r_i \\\\gg r_s$, so that electromagnetic field formulas in local proper frames are valid, and redshift corrections only affect observable quantities as described below.\\n\\nThe rod at $r$ has proper length $L$, uniform radius $a$, and uniform mass density $\\\\rho_m$ (assume negligible mass-energy change from thermal expansion). At all times, the rod retains thermal, electrical, and mechanical equilibrium; Joule heating is the only non-gravitational energy transfer, and the rod loses energy only by isotropic black-body radiation into the vacuum. The rod and rails together form a closed circuit of total resistance $R(T)$ (rod only; rails and contact resistance are exactly zero) and fixed self-inductance $L_{\\\\mathrm{c}}$, explicitly given and independent of position or temperature. Thermal and electrical properties of aluminum are well approximated by $\\\\rho_e(T) = \\\\rho_{\\\\mathrm{res}}$ (temperature-independent) and $C_m(T) = C_{m,0}$ (also temperature-independent, neglecting quantum and phonon effects for these temperature and energy ranges), with all parameters below.\\n\\nThe circuit is oriented so that it encloses precisely the magnetic flux through a region of area $A(r)$ normal to the local $z$-direction, bounded by the two rails at constant $z$ and the moving rod at position $r$. The system starts at Schwarzschild coordinate radius $r = r_i$ with Schwarzschild coordinate velocity $v = dr/dt = 0$. When released at proper time $\\\\tau=0$, the rod falls radially inward, inducing a motional EMF $\\\\mathcal{E}_\\\\mathrm{prop}$ in its local proper frame, which drives a current $I(\\\\tau)$ governed by the relativistic R-L circuit law. The induced current produces a Lorentz force $F_B$, opposing the rod's motion. In the local proper frame at radius $r$, the equations of motion are:\\n\\n1. Relativistic energy conservation:\\n\\n\\\\[\\n\\\\frac{dE}{d\\\\tau} = - F_B \\\\left| v_{\\\\mathrm{prop}} \\\\right|,\\n\\\\]\\nwhere $E$ is the rod's total energy as measured at infinity,\\n\\\\[\\nE(r, v_{\\\\mathrm{prop}}) = \\\\frac{m_0 c^2}{\\\\sqrt{1 - \\\\dfrac{r_s}{r} - \\\\dfrac{v_{\\\\mathrm{prop}}^2}{c^2}}},\\n\\\\]\\nand $v_{\\\\mathrm{prop}}$ is the local proper radial velocity.\\n\\n2. The motional EMF in the rod's proper frame is:\\n\\\\[\\n\\\\mathcal{E}_\\\\mathrm{prop}(r, v_{\\\\mathrm{prop}}) = B_{z,\\\\mathrm{prop}}(r) \\\\, L \\\\, v_{\\\\mathrm{prop}},\\n\\\\]\\nwhere $B_{z,\\\\mathrm{prop}}(r)$ is the local $z$-component of the magnetic field from the dipole, evaluated at the rod location (using the flat-space dipole formula),\\n\\\\[\\nB_{z,\\\\mathrm{prop}}(r) = \\\\frac{\\\\mu_0}{4\\\\pi} \\\\frac{2 \\\\mu}{r^3}.\\n\\\\]\\n\\n3. The rod carries current $I(\\\\tau)$ from the R-L circuit law,\\n\\\\[\\nL_{\\\\mathrm{c}} \\\\frac{dI}{d\\\\tau} + R(T) I = \\\\mathcal{E}_\\\\mathrm{prop}(r, v_{\\\\mathrm{prop}}).\\n\\\\]\\n\\n4. The braking Lorentz force (in the local rest frame) is\\n\\\\[\\nF_B(r, I) = I \\\\cdot L \\\\cdot B_{z,\\\\mathrm{prop}}(r).\\n\\\\]\\n\\n5. The rod's temperature $T(\\\\tau)$ evolves by energy balance,\\n\\\\[\\n\\\\left[m_0 C_{m,0}\\\\right] \\\\frac{dT}{d\\\\tau} = I^2 R(T) - \\\\varepsilon_r \\\\sigma_{SB} A_s T^4,\\n\\\\]\\nwhere $A_s = 2\\\\pi a L + 2\\\\pi a^2$ is the total rod area.\\n\\n6. The rod experiences isotropic black-body cooling to the vacuum, with gravitational redshift correction: the effective radiative cooling power per proper time $P_{\\\\mathrm{cool}}$ is boosted in the local frame at radius $r$ by a factor $1/\\\\sqrt{1 - r_s/r}$ compared to power as measured at infinity, so emission is as in flat space in the local frame, and all calculations are carried out in the rod frame.\\n\\nPhysical and material parameters (exact for this problem):\\n\\\\begin{align*}\\n&G = 6.674 \\\\times 10^{-11} \\\\; \\\\mathrm{m}^3/\\\\mathrm{kg}/\\\\mathrm{s}^2, \\\\\\\\\\n&c = 2.998 \\\\times 10^8 \\\\; \\\\mathrm{m/s}, \\\\\\\\\\n&\\\\mu_0 = 4\\\\pi \\\\times 10^{-7} \\\\; \\\\mathrm{N/A}^2, \\\\\\\\\\n&\\\\sigma_{SB} = 5.670 \\\\times 10^{-8} \\\\; \\\\mathrm{W}/\\\\mathrm{m}^2/\\\\mathrm{K}^4, \\\\\\\\\\n&\\\\varepsilon_r = 0.09, \\\\quad L_{\\\\mathrm{c}} = 1.0 \\\\times 10^{-6}\\\\; \\\\mathrm{H}, \\\\\\\\\\n&\\\\rho_m = 2700\\\\; \\\\mathrm{kg/m}^3, \\\\quad \\\\rho_{\\\\mathrm{res}} = 3.0 \\\\times 10^{-11}\\\\; \\\\Omega \\\\cdot \\\\mathrm{m}, \\\\\\\\\\n&M = 1.4 \\\\times 10^{31} \\\\; \\\\mathrm{kg}, \\\\quad \\\\mu = 2.5 \\\\times 10^{23} \\\\; \\\\mathrm{A} \\\\cdot \\\\mathrm{m}^2, \\\\\\\\\\n&L = 1.0\\\\; \\\\mathrm{m}, \\\\quad a = 5.0 \\\\times 10^{-3}\\\\; \\\\mathrm{m}, \\\\\\\\\\n&C_{m,0} = 900 \\\\; \\\\mathrm{J}/\\\\mathrm{kg}/\\\\mathrm{K}, \\\\\\\\\\n&R(T) = \\\\rho_{\\\\mathrm{res}} L/(\\\\pi a^2), \\\\quad A_s = 2\\\\pi a L + 2\\\\pi a^2, \\\\\\\\\\n&r_s = 2GM/c^2, \\\\quad r_i = 5.0\\\\times 10^5\\\\; \\\\mathrm{m}, \\\\quad r_f = 9.0\\\\times 10^4\\\\; \\\\mathrm{m}, \\\\\\\\\\n&m_0 = \\\\rho_m \\\\pi a^2 L, \\\\\\\\\\n&T(0) = 20.0\\\\; \\\\mathrm{K}, \\\\quad I(0) = 0.0\\\\; \\\\mathrm{A}, \\\\quad v_{\\\\mathrm{prop}}(0) = 0.\\n\\\\end{align*}\\n\\n**Assumptions:**\\n- The rod's volume, mass, and area remain fixed; all expansion and contraction are ignored (\\\\( \\\\alpha_L = 0 \\\\)).\\n- The rod falls freely but is decelerated by the Lorentz force from the induced current; rail geometry does not change.\\n- The total resistance is precisely that of the rod; rails and contacts are ideal.\\n- The effects of quantum corrections, mechanical stress, and spacetime curvature on electromagnetic fields and emission are negligible for the radial range considered ($r_i \\\\gg r_s$).\\n- All quantities are evaluated in the rod's local proper frame, with all proper-time derivatives as shown; coordinate and proper times are related by $d\\\\tau/dt = \\\\sqrt{1 - r_s/r - v_{\\\\mathrm{prop}}^2/c^2}$.\\n\\n\\n**Final Question:**\\n\\nCompute the total energy (in joules) dissipated as Joule heating in the rod during its entire fall from coordinate radius $r_i$ to $r_f$, that is,\\n\\\\[\\nQ_J = \\\\int_{\\\\tau=0}^{\\\\tau_f} I(\\\\tau)^2 R(T(\\\\tau)) \\\\, d\\\\tau, \\\\qquad \\\\text{where $r(\\\\tau_f) = r_f$}.\\n\\\\]\\nGive your answer in joules, rounded to three significant digits.\

A solid uniform disk of niobium ($^{93}_{41}\\\\mathrm{Nb}$) of radius $R=0.500\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$ and thickness $d=2.00\\\\ \\\\mathrm{mm}$ ($0.00200\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$) is mounted to rotate freely about its central axis (the $z$-axis). It is initially at rest in vacuum at a uniform temperature $T_0=2.00\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K}$. Niobium has density $\\\\rho_{\\\\mathrm{Nb}} = 8570\\\\ \\\\mathrm{kg}/\\\\mathrm{m}^3$, molar mass $M_{u,\\\\mathrm{Nb}} = 92.906\\\\ \\\\mathrm{g}/\\\\mathrm{mol}$, Debye temperature $\\\\Theta_{D,\\\\mathrm{Nb}} = 275\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K}$, zero-temperature upper critical field $B_{c2}(0) = 0.410\\\\ \\\\mathrm{T}$, critical temperature $T_c = 9.25\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K}$, and normal-state resistivity $\\\\rho_n = 1.50 \\\\times 10^{-8}\\\\ \\\\Omega\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{m}$. The BCS-like electronic heat capacity is $C_{es}(T) = 85.5\\\\ \\\\mathrm{J}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{mol}^{-1}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{K}^{-1} \\\\times \\\\exp(-1.85 T_c/T)$, and the phonon heat capacity is given by the Debye model $C_{ph,\\\\mathrm{Nb}}(T) = N_A k_B (12\\\\pi^4/5)(T/\\\\Theta_{D,\\\\mathrm{Nb}})^3$ for $0 < T < T_c$, where $N_A = 6.022\\\\times10^{23}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{mol}^{-1}$ and $k_B = 1.381 \\\\times 10^{-23}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{J}/\\\\mathrm{K}$. \\n\\nA solid uniform sphere of osmium ($^{190}_{76}\\\\mathrm{Os}$), radius $r_s = 3.00\\\\ \\\\mathrm{cm}$ ($0.0300\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$), mass density $\\\\rho_{\\\\mathrm{Os}} = 22590\\\\ \\\\mathrm{kg}/\\\\mathrm{m}^3$, molar mass $M_{u,\\\\mathrm{Os}} = 190.23\\\\ \\\\mathrm{g}/\\\\mathrm{mol}$, and Debye temperature $\\\\Theta_{D,\\\\mathrm{Os}} = 500\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K}$, is prepared at $T_0$ with its center-of-mass velocity $\\\\vec{v}_0 = v_0 \\\\hat{y}$, $v_0 = 100.0\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}/\\\\mathrm{s}$, and center at position $\\\\vec{r}_0 = R\\\\hat{x}$, so it moves tangentially to the disk's rim. The sphere carries a net surface charge $q_s = -10.0\\\\ \\\\mu\\\\mathrm{C}$, **uniformly distributed over its surface and fixed to the sphere** at all times, and possesses a permanent magnetic dipole $\\\\vec{\\\\mu}_s = \\\\mu_s \\\\hat{y}$, $\\\\mu_s = 0.100\\\\ \\\\mathrm{A}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{m}^2$, rigidly aligned with its velocity. \\n\\nAt $t=0$ the sphere collides **perfectly inelastically** with the rim ($x=R,\\\\ y=0$), sticking so its center is at $(R,0,0)$ in the disk plane for all $t>0$. It rotates with the disk; after collision the charge and magnetic moment remain rigidly attached at this point, rotating with the composite body. The **moment of inertia of the sphere about the rotation axis** is $I_s = \\\\frac{2}{5} m_s r_s^2 + m_s R^2$, where $m_s$ is the sphere mass. The disk's moment of inertia about the same axis is $I_d = \\\\frac{1}{2} M_d R^2$, where $M_d$ is the mass of the disk.\\n\\nThe entire system is immersed in a **static, uniform, external magnetic field** $\\\\vec{B}_{\\\\mathrm{ext}} = B_0 \\\\hat{z}$, $B_0 = 0.300\\\\ \\\\mathrm{T}$, within the superconducting vortex (mixed) state: $B_{c1}(T) < B_0 < B_{c2}(T)$ for all $T_0 \\\\leq T < T_c$. The temperature-dependent upper critical field is $B_{c2}(T) = B_{c2}(0)[1 - (T/T_c)^2]$.\\n\\n**After the collision, the rotating system loses energy via:** \\n(1) **Flux-flow dissipation** in the superconductor: the dissipative torque is \\n\\\\[ \\\\tau_{ff}(T,\\\\omega) = \\\\frac{1}{4} \\\\frac{\\\\Phi_0 B_0 \\\\rho_n}{d} R^4 \\\\frac{\\\\omega}{B_{c2}(T)}, \\\\]\\nwhere $\\\\omega$ is the angular speed, $d$ is the disk thickness, and $\\\\Phi_0 = h/(2e)$. \\n(2) **Electric dipole radiation** from the rotating surface charge (treated as a point charge $q_s$ on a rigid arm of length $R$): \\n\\\\[ P_E(\\\\omega) = \\\\frac{q_s^2 R^2 \\\\omega^4}{6 \\\\pi \\\\epsilon_0 c^3}. \\\\]\\n(3) **Magnetic dipole radiation** from the rotating $\\\\vec{\\\\mu}_s$ fixed at radius $R$: \\n\\\\[ P_M(\\\\omega) = \\\\frac{\\\\mu_0}{6 \\\\pi c^3} \\\\mu_s^2 \\\\omega^4. \\\\]\\n(4) **Gravitational wave emission** from the rotating point mass $m_s$ on the rim: \\n\\\\[ P_{GW}(\\\\omega) = \\\\frac{32 G m_s^2 R^4 \\\\omega^6}{5 c^5}. \\\\]\\n\\n**Assumptions:**\\n- The sphere and disk make perfect thermal contact at all times; any dissipated energy is instantly and evenly distributed. \\n- The sphere charge and magnetic moment remain at fixed radius $R$, rotating with the system; their own internal heat capacities are as given by the Debye model ($C_{V,\\\\mathrm{Os}}(T) = N_A k_B (12\\\\pi^4/5)(T/\\\\Theta_{D,\\\\mathrm{Os}})^3$).\\n- The entire apparatus is thermally isolated (no heat exchange with the environment).\\n- The only dissipative mechanisms are the four loss channels (1)-(4) above. All other losses are negligible.\\n- The flux-flow torque formula is valid up to $T = T_c - 0$, and the system transitions abruptly to the normal state at $T_c$ (i.e., the evolution is halted at $T_c$).\\n\\n**Given constants**: $G = 6.674\\\\times10^{-11}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{N}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{m}^2\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{kg}^{-2}$; $c = 2.998\\\\times10^8\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}/\\\\mathrm{s}$; $\\\\epsilon_0 = 8.854\\\\times10^{-12}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{F}/\\\\mathrm{m}$; $\\\\mu_0 = 4\\\\pi\\\\times10^{-7}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{T}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{m}/\\\\mathrm{A}$; $e = 1.602\\\\times10^{-19}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{C}$; $h = 6.626 \\\\times 10^{-34}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{J}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{s}$. All physical constants not listed above may be taken as standard.\\n\\n**Task:**\\n\\nLet $\\\\theta_f$ be the total angle (in radians) that the composite disk-sphere system rotates from the instant after collision ($t=0^+$) until the temperature first attains $T_c$ and all superconducting dissipation ceases. **Calculate numerically** the value of $\\\\theta_f$, using all details and formulas specified above. Give your answer to three significant figures, in radians.\

A vertical, frictionless, perfectly insulated cylindrical chamber of fixed height \\\\( H = 2.000~\\\\mathrm{m} \\\\) and cross-sectional area \\\\( A = 0.2800~\\\\mathrm{m}^2 \\\\) contains a tight-moving, massless piston, initially clamped at height \\\\( x_i = 0.8190~\\\\mathrm{m} \\\\) above the chamber base. \\n\\nBelow the piston is an ideal monatomic gas (specific heat ratio \\\\( \\\\gamma = \\\\frac{5}{3} \\\\), molar heat capacity at constant volume \\\\( C_V = \\\\frac{3}{2}R \\\\)), with \\\\( n = 10.00 \\\\) moles at temperature \\\\( T_i = 280.0~\\\\mathrm{K} \\\\) and pressure equal to the external atmosphere, \\\\( P_{\\\\mathrm{atm}} = 1.013\\\\times 10^5~\\\\mathrm{Pa} \\\\). Above the piston is a direct physical connection to external ambient air, kept always at \\\\( P_{\\\\mathrm{atm}} \\\\) regardless of the elevator motion (the piston moves against a large atmospheric reservoir with negligible density gradient across the relevant heights and pressure unaffected by chamber movement).\\n\\nAt time \\\\( t=0 \\\\), the clamp is released, and simultaneously the entire elevator (including chamber and external air connections) accelerates smoothly upward with a constant acceleration \\\\( a = 3.500~\\\\mathrm{m/s}^2 \\\\). Gravitational acceleration is \\\\( g = 9.800~\\\\mathrm{m/s}^2 \\\\). The piston is massless, frictionless, and perfectly conducts mechanical force, and the gas remains always in thermodynamic equilibrium with itself, undergoing a quasi-static adiabatic process until a new equilibrium is reached. The chamber stays perfectly insulated throughout. The volume above the piston is always connected to \\\\( P_{\\\\mathrm{atm}} \\\\); the gas is perfectly sealed below the piston. Ignore the mass and inertia of the piston and chamber walls. The only forces on the gas are due to atmospheric pressure above and gravity (or pseudo-force) in the non-inertial frame. Take the zero of gravitational potential energy at the chamber base\u2014potential energy is defined in the non-inertial frame with effective acceleration \\\\( g' = g + a \\\\).\\n\\n**Constants:** Universal gas constant \\\\( R = 8.314~\\\\mathrm{J/(mol\\\\cdot K)} \\\\).\\n\\n**Question:**\\n\\nAfter equilibrium is re-established, what is the total change \\\\( \\\\Delta U_{\\\\mathrm{tot}} \\\\) in the sum of (i) the internal energy of the gas and (ii) the gravitational potential energy of the gas (relative to the base, in the effective field \\\\( g' \\\\)), between the initial (before acceleration, piston clamped) and final (after acceleration and re-equilibration, piston at new height) states?\\n\\nExpress your answer as:\\n\\\\[\\n\\\\boxed{\\\\Delta U_{\\\\mathrm{tot}} = \\\\text{\\\\color{red}{\\\\rule{4cm}{0.4pt}}}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{J}}\\n\\\\]\\nwhere a positive value means an increase in the combined energy of the gas (internal plus potential) from initial to final state.\

A rigid horizontal pipe of length $L = 12.0\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$ connects two very large open reservoirs. The upstream reservoir (A) maintains a free surface at a height $h_A = 2.30\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$ above the central axis of the pipe inlet, while the downstream reservoir (B) is aligned such that its free surface is at the same vertical level as the pipe outlet (i.e., $h_B = 0$). Both reservoirs are open to atmospheric pressure $p_0 = 1.013 \\\\times 10^{5}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{Pa}$. The pipe is perfectly smooth, has no fittings, and is oriented horizontally from $x=0$ (inlet) to $x=L$ (outlet). The pipe radius varies along its length according to $r(x) = r_0 e^{-\\\\alpha x}$, with $r_0 = 0.0400\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$ and $\\\\alpha = 0.0850\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}^{-1}$. Water of constant density $\\\\rho = 998\\\\ \\\\mathrm{kg\\\\,m^{-3}}$ and dynamic viscosity $\\\\eta = 1.00 \\\\times 10^{-3}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{Pa\\\\,s}$ flows steadily from A to B. Assume incompressible, Newtonian, laminar flow obeying the no-slip boundary condition at the wall, and neglect all entrance, exit, and kinetic energy losses.\\\\n\\\\n(a) Derive, then determine numerically, the total steady volumetric flow rate $Q$ (in $\\\\mathrm{m^3\\\\,s^{-1}}$) from A to B.\\\\n\\\\n(b) Using your result for $Q$, compute the total viscous power dissipated within the pipe, defined as \\\\[ P_{\\\\mathrm{diss}} = \\\\int_0^L \\\\int_{0}^{2\\\\pi} \\\\eta \\\\left( r \\\\frac{\\\\partial v}{\\\\partial r} \\\\bigg|_{r = r(x)} \\\\right) r(x) \\\\, d\\\\theta \\\\, dx, \\\\] where $v$ is the axial fluid velocity. Express your final answer for $P_{\\\\mathrm{diss}}$ numerically with three significant digits, in SI units of $\\\\boxed{\\\\mathrm{W}}$.\\\\n\\\\nYou may assume that the pressure drop driving the flow is entirely due to hydrostatic difference between A and B (i.e., $\\\\Delta p = \\\\rho g h_A$), and you must verify that the Reynolds number does not exceed $2100$ at any point along the pipe to ensure the validity of the laminar regime. Use $g = 9.80665\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m\\\\,s^{-2}}$. If the laminar assumption is violated, state so and use the largest value of $Q$ for which $Re \\\\leq 2100$ everywhere. Give only your final answer for $P_{\\\\mathrm{diss}}$ in $\\\\boxed{\\\\mathrm{W}}$.\

A parallel-plate capacitor consists of two perfectly conducting rectangular plates of length $L_p = 0.400\\\\,\\\\mathrm{m}$ and width $W_p = 0.300\\\\,\\\\mathrm{m}$, separated by a uniform vertical gap $d = 2.00 \\\\times 10^{-3}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{m}$. The plates are mounted horizontally with the lower plate fixed and the upper plate supported by non-conductive, frictionless guide rails, maintaining exact parallelism. The capacitor is maintained at a constant potential difference $V_0 = 450.0\\\\,\\\\mathrm{V}$ by an ideal power supply. \\n\\nA dielectric slab of uniform rectangular shape, dielectric constant $\\\\kappa = 5.60$, length $L_s = 0.220\\\\,\\\\mathrm{m}$ (along the axis of insertion), width $W_s = 0.300\\\\,\\\\mathrm{m}$, and thickness $d$ (fitting perfectly within the plate gap), and mass $M_s = 0.401\\\\,\\\\mathrm{kg}$, is inserted into the capacitor such that a distance $x = 0.150\\\\,\\\\mathrm{m}$ (measured from the edge of the plates) of the slab protrudes between the plates at equilibrium. The dielectric is fully supported from below by a frictionless, horizontal table that bears its entire weight; thus, no vertical forces from the cord, plates, or gravity act on the slab in the direction of insertion. Edge or fringe-field effects at the boundaries of the plates and the dielectric are ignored; the electric field is assumed to be uniform everywhere between the plates except where the dielectric terminates. \\n\\nA massless, inextensible cord is attached to the exposed edge of the slab and runs horizontally, exactly parallel to the plane of the plates and colinear with the slab's insertion axis. The cord passes over a massless, frictionless pulley fixed at the same vertical height as the capacitor, then vertically downward to suspend a right circular cylinder. The pulley has negligible rotational inertia and the cord does not slip. \\n\\nThe suspended cylinder is fully submerged and hangs at rest in still, pure water of density $\\\\rho_w = 998\\\\,\\\\mathrm{kg\\\\,m^{-3}}$. The cylinder has mass $m_c = 0.640\\\\,\\\\mathrm{kg}$, uniform density $\\\\rho_c = 1100\\\\,\\\\mathrm{kg\\\\,m^{-3}}$ (so the radius must be inferred), and length $\\\\ell_c = 0.320\\\\,\\\\mathrm{m}$ (axis oriented vertically). All other forces, including hydrodynamic drag, surface tension, air buoyancy, friction, and viscosity, are negligible. \\n\\nUniversal constants: $g = 9.80665\\\\,\\\\mathrm{m\\\\,s^{-2}}$, $\\\\varepsilon_0 = 8.854187817 \\\\times 10^{-12}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{F\\\\,m^{-1}}$. \\n\\n**Assumptions:**\\n\\n- The vertical weight of the slab is fully supported by the table and does not affect horizontal forces (no vertical or friction forces from the plates or cord).  \\n- The cord runs strictly parallel to the plates in the insertion direction, ensuring purely horizontal tension on the slab.  \\n- Both the plates and the slab have widths $W_p = W_s = 0.300\\\\,\\\\mathrm{m}$ and thickness matching exactly to $d$; all edge effects, fringing electric fields, and non-uniformities at boundaries are ignored.\\n- The only horizontal forces acting on the slab are the electrostatic force due to the capacitor, the horizontal cord tension, and an applied external force $\\\\vec{F}_\\\\mathrm{ext}$ acting opposite to the direction of electrostatic force.  \\n- The cord is massless, does not stretch or sag, and the pulley is ideal.  \\n- The system is in exact static equilibrium.\\n\\n**Final Question:** \\n\\nDetermine the magnitude of the required external horizontal force $F_\\\\mathrm{ext}$ (in newtons), acting opposite to the capacitor's electrostatic force on the slab, that must be applied to the slab (parallel to and exactly colinear with the insertion axis) in order to keep the entire system (slab, cord, cylinder, and all supporting apparatus) in strict static equilibrium as described. \\n\\nExpress your answer to four significant figures in newtons ($\\\\mathrm{N}$) and box it:\\n\\n\\\\[ \\\\boxed{\\\\phantom{0000.0000~\\\\mathrm{N}}} \\\\]\

A double compound pendulum consists of two uniform, rigid rods made of a perfectly conducting, non-magnetic material, connected in series and able to swing freely in the vertical $x$--$z$ plane under gravity, as follows:\\n\\n\\\\begin{itemize}\\n  \\\\item \\\\textbf{Rod 1}: Length $L_1 = 1.20\\\\,\\\\mathrm{m}$, mass $m_1 = 2.50\\\\,\\\\mathrm{kg}$, pivoted at a fixed, frictionless point $O$ at the origin $\\\\vec{r}_O = (0,0,0)$. Its upper end is attached at $O$; it hangs vertically at equilibrium.\\n  \\\\item \\\\textbf{Rod 2}: Length $L_2 = 0.75\\\\,\\\\mathrm{m}$, mass $m_2 = 1.10\\\\,\\\\mathrm{kg}$, attached via a frictionless hinge to the free end of Rod\\\\ 1. Both rods are thin (diameter negligible).\\n\\\\end{itemize}\\n\\nThe system starts from rest at $t=0$, with both rods aligned vertically downward in the $-z$ direction ($\\\\theta_1 = 0$, $\\\\theta_2 = 0$), in the $x$--$z$ plane. Neglect air resistance.\\n\\nA uniform, constant magnetic field $\\\\vec{B} = (0, +1.80, 0)\\\\,\\\\mathrm{T}$ is applied in the $+y$ direction (i.e., perpendicular to the $x$--$z$ plane of motion).\\n\\nAt $t=0^+$, an external current pulse $I = 42.0\\\\,\\\\mathrm{A}$ is imposed for a duration $\\\\Delta t = 6.50 \\\\times 10^{-3}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{s}$ as follows:\\n\\n\\\\begin{itemize}\\n  \\\\item The current enters at $O$, flows down Rod 1 from $(0,0,0)$ to $(0,0,-L_1)$, then immediately continues along Rod 2 from $(0,0,-L_1)$ to $(L_2\\\\sin\\\\alpha, 0, -L_1 - L_2\\\\cos\\\\alpha)$, where $\\\\alpha$ is the instantaneous angle of Rod 2 with respect to the negative $z$-axis (equal to 0 during the impulse).\\n  \\\\item The return segment consists of an ideal, massless, resistance-free wire running along the line in the $x$--$z$ plane directly from the free end of Rod 2 back to point $O$; during the impulse, both rods remain at $\\\\theta_1 = \\\\theta_2 = 0$ (impulse approximation).\\n  \\\\item The circuit's total (external) resistance is exactly $R = 0.600\\\\,\\\\Omega$, located in the supply (not the rods).\\n\\\\end{itemize}\\n\\nThe rods\u2019 own resistance and inductance are negligible so the current is strictly $I$ during $\\\\Delta t$.\\n\\n\\\\textbf{Precisely define:}\\n- $\\\\theta_1$ is the angle between Rod 1 and the $-z$ axis (positive when rotating toward $+x$).\\n- $\\\\theta_2$ is the angle between Rod 2 and the extension of Rod 1, both measured in the $x$--$z$ plane.\\n\\nYou may take:\\n\\\\begin{align*}\\n  g &= 9.80665\\\\,\\\\mathrm{m/s^2} \\\\\\\\\\n  I_{\\\\text{rod, end}} &= \\\\frac{1}{3} m L^2 \\\\text{\\\\ (mass moment of inertia of a uniform rod about end)}\\n\\\\end{align*}\\n\\n\\\\textbf{Neglect all inductive effects and background potential energies.} Assume that, due to the impulse approximation, the positions of the rods do not change appreciably during the pulse; all gravitational potential energy is minimal at $t=0$, so the subsequent kinetic energy equals the total mechanical energy imparted by the magnetic force from the pulse.\\n\\n\\\\vspace{.5em}\\n\\\\textbf{Question:}\\n\\n\\\\emph{Immediately after the current pulse has ended ($t=0^+$), what is the total kinetic energy $K_{\\\\max}$ (in joules) imparted to the double pendulum (sum of all translational and rotational energies of both rods), given the setup and assumptions above? Calculate $K_{\\\\max}$ numerically to three significant digits, specify correct SI units, and box your final answer as $\\\\boxed{\\\\;\\\\cdots\\\\;\\\\mathrm{J}}$.}\\n\

A horizontally-aligned, rigid cylindrical pipe of proper length $L_0 = 125.0\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$ and inner radius $R = 8.50 \\\\times 10^{-3}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{m}$ is securely mounted parallel to the direction of motion inside a high-speed train traveling at a constant velocity $v = 0.800\\\\,c$ (where $c = 2.99792458 \\\\times 10^8\\\\,\\\\mathrm{m \\\\ s^{-1}}$) relative to inertial ground frame $S$. The pipe is completely filled with a Newtonian incompressible fluid of density $\\\\rho = 1040\\\\,\\\\mathrm{kg\\\\ m^{-3}}$ and dynamic viscosity $\\\\eta = 1.60 \\\\times 10^{-3}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{Pa\\\\cdot s}$, and is capped at both ends with perfectly sealed, frictionless pistons.\\\\n\\\\nA constant pressure difference $\\\\Delta P = 5.00 \\\\times 10^4\\\\,\\\\mathrm{Pa}$ is maintained between the two pistons as measured in the train\u2019s rest frame $S'$. Assume the following:\\\\n\\\\n\\\\begin{enumerate}\\\\n  \\\\item The pressure difference $\\\\Delta P$ applies between the ends of the pipe as measured over the proper length $L_0$ in $S'$.\\\\n  \\\\item The fluid exhibits fully developed, steady, axisymmetric laminar (Poiseuille) flow in $S'$, justified by maintaining the Reynolds number $Re < 1500$ (check that your computed velocity is consistent with this condition; if not, return $\\\\bar v_f = 0$ by physical argument).\\\\n  \\\\item No relativistic corrections to the internal fluid dynamics are required in $S'$, as $\\\\bar v_f \\\\ll c$ and there are no internal relativistic effects; all relativistic transformations between $S'$ and $S$ must, however, be rigorously applied for lengths, velocities, and times.\\\\n  \\\\item The reference frame $S$ (ground frame) observes all kinematic and decay processes, including length contraction and time dilation, relative to the pipe and fluid moving at $v$.\\\\n  \\\\item All pipe, piston, and fluid components are idealized as absolutely rigid and perfectly uniform for the purposes of this analysis, and entrance/exit, compressibility, gravitational, and end effects are negligible.\\\\n  \\\\item At time $t=0$ in $S$, a negatively charged muon ($q=-e$, $e = 1.602 \\\\times 10^{-19}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{C}$, $m_\\\\mu = 1.8835316 \\\\times 10^{-28}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{kg}$, proper mean lifetime $\\\\tau_0 = 2.197\\\\,\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{s}$) is created instantaneously at rest at the pipe's left entrance (downstream end) in the ground frame $S$. Immediately, it is taken up by the fluid so that in $S'$ it co-moves precisely with the fluid\u2019s mean axial velocity $\\\\bar v_f$ (calculated below), starting at the left-end inlet. Neglect any drag, stochastic, or acceleration time lag.\\\\n  \\\\item The muon\u2019s motion is purely axial along the pipe\u2019s central axis; all forces other than fluid advection and decay are neglected.\\\\n  \\\\item Assume the muon is a point particle for all hydrodynamic purposes, and ignore all electromagnetic and quantum effects.\\\\n  \\\\item For all Lorentz transformations, use exact relativistic velocity addition and contraction/dilation formulas where required.\\\\n\\\\end{enumerate}\\\\n\\\\n\\\\textbf{Relevant formulas:}\\\\n\\\\n\\\\begin{align*}\\\\n&\\\\text{Mean (axial) fluid velocity in Poiseuille flow:}\\\\quad \\\\bar v_f = \\\\frac{\\\\Delta P \\\\, R^2}{8\\\\eta L_0} \\\\quad \\\\text{(in } S' \\\\text{, over full length $L_0$)} \\\\\\\\[1.5ex]\\\\n&\\\\text{Lorentz contraction of the pipe as seen from $S$:}\\\\quad L = \\\\frac{L_0}{\\\\gamma}\\\\,,\\\\quad \\\\gamma = \\\\frac{1}{\\\\sqrt{1-v^2/c^2}}\\\\\\\\[1.5ex]\\\\n&\\\\text{Relativistic velocity addition: If $u'$ in $S'$ along $v$, then in $S$}\\\\quad u = \\\\frac{u' + v}{1 + (u' v)/c^2}\\\\\\\\[1.5ex]\\\\n&\\\\text{Muon mean lifetime in $S$:}\\\\quad \\\\tau = \\\\gamma_\\\\mu\\\\, \\\\tau_0 \\\\,,\\\\quad \\\\gamma_\\\\mu = \\\\frac{1}{\\\\sqrt{1-u^2/c^2}}\\\\\\\\[1.5ex]\\\\n&\\\\text{Transit time through the contracted pipe in $S$:}\\\\quad t_{\\\\mathrm{transit}} = \\\\frac{L}{u}\\\\\\\\[1.5ex]\\\\n&\\\\text{Muon survival probability:}\\\\quad P = \\\\exp\\\\left(-\\\\frac{t_{\\\\mathrm{transit}}}{\\\\tau}\\\\right)\\\\n\\\\end{align*}\\\\n\\\\n\\\\textbf{Given constants:}\\\\n\\\\begin{align*}\\\\nL_0 &= \\\\times 10^8\\\\,\\\\mathrm{m\\\\ s^{-1}} \\\\\\\\\\\\n\\\\rho &= 1040\\\\,\\\\mathrm{kg\\\\ m^{-3}}\\\\\\\\\\\\n\\\\eta &= 1.60 \\\\times 10^{-3}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{Pa\\\\cdot s}\\\\\\\\\\\\n\\\\Delta P &= 5.00 \\\\times 10^4\\\\,\\\\mathrm{Pa}\\\\\\\\\\\\n\\\\tau_0 &= 2.197\\\\,\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{s} = 2.197 \\\\times 10^{-6}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{s} \\\\\\\\\\\\nm_\\\\mu &= 1.8835316 \\\\times 10^{-28}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{kg} \\\\\\\\\\\\ne &= 1.602 \\\\times 10^{-19}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{C} \\\\\\\\\\\\n\\\\end{align*}\\\\n\\\\n\\\\textbf{Tasks:}\\\\n\\\\n\\\\begin{enumerate}[label=(\\\\alph*)]\\\\n  \\\\item Calculate the mean fluid speed $\\\\bar v_f$ in the train frame $S'$ by applying Poiseuille's law with the provided parameters.\\\\n  \\\\item Evaluate the Reynolds number $Re = \\\\frac{2R
