A vertical, right-cylindrical vessel of radius $R = 0.300\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$ and height $H = 0.900\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$ is completely filled with an incompressible, non-viscous liquid of density $\\\\rho_l = 1000\\\\ \\\\mathrm{kg/m^3}$ to initial depth $h_0 = 0.750\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$. The vessel is hermetically sealed and is rigidly mounted inside a large elevator. At $t=0$, the elevator begins moving vertically such that its upward acceleration varies with time: $a(t) = a_0 \\\\sin(\\\\omega t)$, where $a_0 = 4.50\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m/s^2}$, $\\\\omega = 2.60\\\\ \\\\mathrm{rad/s}$, and $t$ in seconds. Throughout, the vessel is simultaneously rotated about its vertical axis at angular speed $\\\\Omega = 6.00\\\\ \\\\mathrm{rad/s}$. The atmospheric pressure is $P_{\\\\mathrm{atm}} = 1.013\\\\times 10^5\\\\ \\\\mathrm{Pa}$, and $g = 9.81\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m/s^2}$.\\n\\nA circular, rigid, frictionless shelf of radius $r_s = 0.240\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$ is affixed horizontally and coaxially inside the vessel at height $L = 0.250\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$ above the vessel's bottom, blocking all liquid beneath it. The shelf is supported radially from the vessel wall and does not rotate relative to the vessel. At rest, the shelf is fully submerged. A block of mass $m = 0.400\\\\ \\\\mathrm{kg}$ is placed at radius $r_b = 0.220\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$ on the shelf and is constrained by a pin to remain stationary relative to the shelf (no sliding in any direction, no vertical or radial motion).\\n\\nAssume:\\n- The liquid above the shelf forms a paraboloidal surface due to rotation, but there is always sufficient vertical clearance to ensure the block remains fully submerged throughout.\\n- The liquid below the shelf is completely isolated and exerts no force on the block or shelf.\\n- The shelf is impermeable, horizontal (parallel to the vessel base), and negligible mass.\\n- The vessel and liquid are in dynamic equilibrium with negligible viscous effects.\\n- The pressure immediately below the shelf equals the liquid pressure at that depth.\\n\\nAt time $t_1 = 24.0\\\\ \\\\mathrm{s}$:\\n- The temperature throughout the system is $T = T_0 + \\\\beta t_1$, with $T_0 = 300\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K}$ and $\\\\beta = 1.25\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K/s}$.\\n\\nMounted outside the vessel is a balanced Wheatstone bridge with four resistors arranged as follows:\\n- $R_1$: a fixed wire of resistivity $\\\\rho_r = 2.00\\\\times 10^{-7}\\\\ \\\\Omega \\\\cdot \\\\mathrm{m}$, length $l_1 = 0.250\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$, cross-sectional area $A = 1.50\\\\times 10^{-7}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}^2$, with temperature coefficient $\\\\alpha_r = 4.10\\\\times 10^{-3}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K}^{-1}$.\\n- $R_2$: a fixed, ideal resistor $R_2 = 7.00\\\\ \\\\Omega$ (zero T-coefficient).\\n- $R_3$: a slide-wire of resistivity $\\\\rho_s = 1.60\\\\times 10^{-7}\\\\ \\\\Omega \\\\cdot \\\\mathrm{m}$, total length $l_3 = 0.700\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$, cross-sectional area $A_3 = 1.50\\\\times 10^{-7}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}^2$, with same $\\\\alpha_s = 4.10\\\\times 10^{-3}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K}^{-1}$.\\n- $R_4$: an ideal, fixed resistor $R_4 = 5.00\\\\ \\\\Omega$ (zero T-coefficient).\\nLet $x$ denote the balance-point on the slide-wire $R_3$ (i.e., $R_3(x) = R_3^{\\\\mathrm{tot}}(T)\\\\, x/l_3$).\\n\\n$\\\\quad$\\n\\n\\\\textbf{Question:}\\n\\nAt time $t_1 = 24.0\\\\ \\\\mathrm{s}$:\\n\\n\\\\begin{enumerate}\\n  \\\\item[(a)] Calculate the net normal force $N$ (in newtons) exerted by the shelf on the block. (Take all buoyancy and non-inertial effects into account; the shelf is horizontal and stationary in the rotating, accelerating frame. Express $N$ as the magnitude of the upward force.)\\n  \\\\item[(b)] Simultaneously, determine the value of $x$ (in meters, $0 \\\\leq x \\\\leq l_3$) at which the Wheatstone bridge balances (i.e., for which current through the galvanometer is zero).\\n\\\\end{enumerate}\\n\\nExpress your answer as the sum $S = N + x$ (to three significant digits, in SI units),\\n\\n\\\\[\\n\\\\boxed{S = N + x\\\\quad[\\\\mathrm{units:\\\\ N\\\\,+\\\\,m}]}\\n\\\\]\\nwhere $N$ and $x$ are defined above. Provide only the final summed value.\

A thin, rigid, uniformly charged circular ring of total mass $M = 8.000\\\\ \\\\mathrm{kg}$, total charge $Q = 2.000 \\\\times 10^{-3}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{C}$, and fixed radius $R = 0.500\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$ is initially at rest in free space (no gravity or external forces). The ring's axis of symmetry is the $z$-axis, centered at the origin.\\n\\nFrom $t = 0$, a constant external torque $\\\\tau_0 = 3.200\\\\ \\\\mathrm{N\\\\cdot m}$ is applied about the $z$-axis for $t_1 = 5.00\\\\ \\\\mathrm{s}$, causing the ring to spin up without changing its center-of-mass position. At $t = t_1$, the torque is rapidly (instantaneously) switched off, and simultaneously an arc segment of the ring subtending an angle $\\\\theta = \\\\frac{\\\\pi}{3}$ at the center (measured from $\\\\varphi=0$ to $\\\\varphi=\\\\frac{\\\\pi}{3}$ in the $xy$ plane) is detached from the ring. The mass and charge distribute proportionally with arc length, so the arc has mass $\\\\Delta m$ and charge $\\\\Delta q$ given by:\\n\\\\[\\n\\\\Delta m = \\\\frac{\\\\theta}{2\\\\pi}M,\\n\\\\quad \\\\Delta q = \\\\frac{\\\\theta}{2\\\\pi}Q.\\n\\\\]\\nThe detached arc and the remaining major segment (both still in their respective arc shapes of common radius $R$) are each rigid bodies and remain non-interacting after $t_1$; they inherit the angular velocity of the ring immediately before detachment. Detachment is ideally impulsive but without any external force or torque (i.e., total linear and angular momentum are both strictly conserved relative to the inertial laboratory frame at all times).\\n\\nAssume:\\n- The system's center-of-mass velocity was zero prior to detachment and remains so afterward.\\n- After detachment, both fragments move with constant center-of-mass velocities and rotate at constant angular velocities about their own centers of mass.\\n- Ignore all fields due to one fragment acting upon the other after separation (no mutual forces or torques).\\n- Ignore any higher multipole radiation (quadrupole, etc.) and relativistic corrections; only electric dipole radiation from each independent moving rigid body is to be included.\\n- The instantaneous position vector of charge element $dq$ on each fragment is always measured relative to the fixed laboratory origin.\\n\\nLet $T = 10.00\\\\ \\\\mathrm{s}$ be the duration over which you must compute the effect.\\n\\n**Constants:**\\n\\\\begin{align*}\\n\\\\epsilon_0 &= 8.854187817\\\\times 10^{-12}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{F/m} \\\\\\\\\\n& c = 2.99792458 \\\\times 10^8\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m/s} \\\\\\\\\\n& \\\\pi = 3.141592654\\n\\\\end{align*}\\n\\n**Question:**\\n\\n\\\\bigskip\\n\\n\\\\textbf{Calculate the total energy $E_{\\\\mathrm{dip}}$ (in joules) radiated by dipole electromagnetic emission from both charged fragments over the interval $[t_1,\\\\; t_1 + T]$. Include the summed contributions of both rigid bodies\u2019 motion, accounting for both their rotation and translation, as described above.}\\n\\n\\\\[\\n\\\\boxed{E_{\\\\mathrm{dip}}\\\\ \\\\Big/\\\\ \\\\mathrm{J}}\\n\\\\]\\n\\nGive your answer rounded to three significant digits.\

A conducting rod of length $L = 0.65\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$ and mass $m = 0.22\\\\ \\\\mathrm{kg}$ can slide without friction along two fixed, perfectly conducting vertical rails separated horizontally by $L$ and spanning from $y = 0$ at the top to $y = 1.30\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$ at the bottom. The system is inside an elevator accelerating upward with constant acceleration $a = 5.00\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m/s}^2$ in a uniform gravitational field $g_0 = 9.80665\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m/s}^2$. A resistor of resistance $R = 1.80\\\\ \\\\Omega$ connects the rails at $y = 1.30\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$. At $t = 0$, the rod is held at rest at position $y_0 = 0$ (top), then released and allowed to slide \\u201cdownward\\u201d (toward decreasing $y$). The $y$-axis is positive upward, with $y = 0$ at the top, $y = 1.30\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$ at the bottom. Throughout the region between the rails, there exists a static magnetic field $\\\\vec{B}(y) = B_0 e^{-k y} \\\\hat{z}$, where $\\\\hat{z}$ is perpendicular \\u201cout of the page\\u201d (i.e., following the right-hand rule with the $x$-axis pointing right and $y$-axis upward), with\\n\\n\\\\[\\nB_0 = 0.50\\\\ \\\\mathrm{T}, \\\\qquad k = 0.80\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}^{-1}\\n\\\\]\\n\\nYou may assume:\\n- The rod remains horizontal and always perpendicular to the rails, and moves strictly in the $y$-direction.\\n- Electrical contact is perfect at all times.\\n- The total circuit resistance is $R$; contact and rod resistances are negligible.\\n- The magnetic field is as given for all $0 \\\\leq y \\\\leq 1.30\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$.\\n- Air resistance and mechanical friction are absent.\\n- The elevator walls do not exert any vertical forces except via the normal reaction and via the rails.\\n- The only forces acting on the rod in the vertical direction are gravity, the elevator's inertial (fictitious) force, and the force due to the induced current in the external magnetic field.\\n\\n(1) Derive the equation of motion for the rod, accounting for all real and inertial forces, and the magnetic braking force resulting from the induced current.\\n\\n(2) The rod is released from rest at $y_0 = 0$ at time $t = 0$ and travels downward to $y = 1.30\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$ under the effective gravity and magnetic braking. Numerically determine the total time $\\\\Delta t$ (in seconds) it takes the rod to reach $y = 1.30\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$.\\n\\n\\\\[\\n\\\\boxed{\\\\Delta t = \\\\; ?\\\\;\\\\mathrm{s}}\\n\\\\]\\n\\n(All parameters needed for a unique and complete calculation are given above. Express your final answer numerically to three significant figures.)\

A biochemical reactor design is under consideration, integrating physical chemistry, thermodynamics, enzyme kinetics, and reactor engineering elements:\\n\\n**Buffer Preparation and Temperature Correction**\\nYou are to prepare 1.000 L of a Tris buffer solution. You add precisely 50.00 mmol of pure Tris base ($\\\\mathrm{Tris}$, MW = $121.14~\\\\mathrm{g}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{mol}^{-1}$) and 25.00 mmol of standardized aqueous HCl (1.000 mol\u00b7L$^{-1}$), then dilute the mixture to exactly 1.000 L with deionized water at $T_1 = 298.15~\\\\mathrm{K}$ (25.00\u00b0C). Tris has a conjugate acid dissociation constant with $\\\\mathrm{p}K_{a,\\\\mathrm{Tris}}(T_1) = 8.070$ at $T_1$ and the standard molar enthalpy of dissociation, referenced to $T_1$, is $\\\\Delta H^{\\\\circ}_{\\\\text{diss,Tris}} = +47.60~\\\\mathrm{kJ}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{mol}^{-1}$ (assume this value is constant over the temperature range studied).\\n\\nAfter the buffer is prepared, the solution is quickly and isobarically heated to $T_2 = 310.00~\\\\mathrm{K}$ (36.85\u00b0C). Assume all solutions behave ideally ($\\\\gamma_i=1$), and that the ionic strength is low enough for standard-state assumptions to hold ($I < 0.10$ M). The standard state is $1~\\\\mathrm{mol}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{L}^{-1}$ at both temperatures. Ignore activity and liquid-junction potentials.\\n\\n**A. Calculate the precise pH of the buffer at $T_2$ (rounded to three decimal places), accounting for the temperature dependence of $K_a$ via the integrated van\u2019t Hoff equation:**\\n\\n$$\\n\\\\ln\\\\left(\\\\frac{K_{a,2}}{K_{a,1}}\\\\right) = -\\\\frac{\\\\Delta H^{\\\\circ}_{\\\\text{diss}}}{R}\\\\left(\\\\frac{1}{T_2}-\\\\frac{1}{T_1}\\\\right)\\n$$\\n\\nand $\\\\mathrm{p}K_{a,2} = -\\\\log_{10} K_{a,2}$. Assume $p[\\\\mathrm{H}^+] = $ pH and use the Henderson\u2013Hasselbalch expression.\\n\\n**Chromatographic Peak Injection**\\nA bolus of a dipeptide, Gly-L-Tyr ($S$), is injected onto an HPLC column. The injection is mathematically instantaneous, and the column yields $N=25\\\\,000$ theoretical plates. The mobile phase is the Tris buffer from above, delivered at a constant volumetric flow rate, $F = 1.000~\\\\mathrm{mL}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{min}^{-1}$. Precisely $n_S = 10.00~\\\\mathrm{nmol}$ (exact) substrate is loaded, and the analyte's retention time is $t_R = 8.00~\\\\mathrm{min}$. The elution peak is a perfect Gaussian and there is no extra-column or injection dispersion. **For all calculations, use the following plate theory conventions:**\\n- The temporal standard deviation $\\\\sigma_t = t_R/\\\\sqrt{N}$.\\n- The baseline peak width is $w_b = 4\\\\sigma_t$.\\n- The peak height at the detector is $h = n_S/(F \\\\times w_b)$ (where $F$ in L\u00b7min\u207b\u00b9, $w_b$ in min, $h$ in mol\u00b7L\u207b\u00b9).\\nAssume a simple flow-through design: the mobile phase stream at the peak apex defines the entering substrate concentration $[S]_0$ to the reactor.\\n\\n**IMER and Enzyme Kinetics**\\nThe outlet of the HPLC column is connected directly to a plug-flow reactor (PFR) containing an immobilized hydrolase. The enzyme loading is quantified by a measured solution-equivalent enzyme concentration $[E]_T = 5.00\\\\times 10^{-5}~\\\\mathrm{mol}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{L}^{-1}$. All immobilization- and mass-transfer-related effects are negligible: the bulk kinetic law applies throughout the PFR. The entire system, including PFR, operates isothermally at $T_2$.\\n\\nThe hydrolytic conversion $S\\\\rightarrow P$ is irreversible and follows the Michaelis\u2013Menten mechanism. The intrinsic (pH-independent) kinetic constants are:\\n- $K_{M,\\\\text{intr}} = 1.50\\\\times 10^{-4}~\\\\mathrm{mol}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{L}^{-1}$\\n- The catalytic turnover number under optimal conditions is determined by transition-state theory,\\n\\n$$\\nk_{\\\\text{cat,max}} = \\\\frac{k_B T_2}{h} \\\\exp\\\\left(\\\\frac{\\\\Delta S^{\\\\ddagger}}{R}\\\\right) \\\\exp\\\\left(-\\\\frac{\\\\Delta H^{\\\\ddagger}}{RT_2}\\\\right)\\n$$\\n\\nwhere $\\\\Delta H^{\\\\ddagger} = +45.00~\\\\mathrm{kJ}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{mol}^{-1}$ and $\\\\Delta S^{\\\\ddagger} = -30.00~\\\\mathrm{J}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{mol}^{-1}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{K}^{-1}$. Use strictly these values at $T_2$.\\n\\nEnzyme activity is pH-dependent, governed by two ionizable residues in the active site (one acid, one base):\\n- $\\\\mathrm{p}K_{aE1} = 6.50$ (acidic, required to be deprotonated for activity \u2014 $K_{aE1}$)\\n- $\\\\mathrm{p}K_{aE2} = 8.50$ (basic, required to be protonated for activity \u2014 $K_{aE2}$)\\n\\nThe effective turnover and Michaelis constants at pH $= pH_{T_2}$ are:\\n\\n$$\\nk_{\\\\text{cat,eff}} = \\\\frac{k_{\\\\text{cat,max}}}{1 + \\\\dfrac{[\\\\mathrm{H}^+]}{K_{aE1}} + \\\\dfrac{K_{aE2}}{[\\\\mathrm{H}^+]}} \\\\\\\\\\nK_{M,\\\\text{eff}} = K_{M,\\\\text{intr}} \\\\frac{1 + \\\\nfrac{[\\\\mathrm{H}^+]}{K_{aS}}}{1 + \\\\nfrac{[\\\\mathrm{H}^+]}{K_{aES}}}\\n$$\\n\\nwhere the substrate's phenolic proton has $\\\\mathrm{p}K_{aS} = 10.00$, which shifts to $\\\\mathrm{p}K_{aES} = 9.50$ in the ES complex; $K_{aS}$ and $K_{aES}$ are the corresponding acid dissociation constants ($10^{-\\\\mathrm{p}K_a}$). Treat all equilibrium constants as dimensionless with reference to the $1~\\\\mathrm{mol}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{L}^{-1}$ standard state.\\n\\n**Plug-Flow Reactor Design**\\nThe entering substrate concentration is $[S]_0$ (peak apex, as above). The liquid flow rate through the PFR is constant and equal to the HPLC flow ($F = 1.000~\\\\mathrm{mL}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{min}^{-1}$). The reactor operates at steady-state and liquid is incompressible.\\n\\nThe mole balance for a single-pass, irreversible Michaelis\u2013Menten PFR is:\\n$$\\nV_{\\\\text{PFR}} = F \\\\int_{[S]_0}^{[S]_f} \\\\frac{d[S]}{v}\\n$$\\nwith $v = \\\\dfrac{k_{\\\\text{cat,eff}} [E]_T [S]}{K_{M,\\\\text{eff}} + [S]}$, $[S]_f = [S]_0(1 - X_S)$, and target fractional conversion $X_S = 0.9900$.\\n\\n**Constants (use precisely):**\\n- $R = 8.314462~\\\\mathrm{J}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{mol}^{-1}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{K}^{-1}$\\n- $k_B = 1.380649\\\\times10^{-23}~\\\\mathrm{J}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{K}^{-1}$\\n- $h = 6.62607015\\\\times10^{-34}~\\\\mathrm{J}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{s}$\\n- $\\\\log_{10} e = 0.4342945$\\n\\n**Required:**\\nCalculate the **exact internal volume of reactor liquid, $V_{\\\\mathrm{PFR}}$, in $\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{L}$ (microliters)** required to achieve $X_S=0.9900$ conversion for the chromatographic peak apex parcel, under the described conditions at $T_2$, using all conventions, constants, and formulas as above. **Give your answer as a single value, rounded to the nearest integer, and report only $V_{\\\\mathrm{PFR}}~[\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{L}]$**.\

A sealed microfluidic reactor with a total internal volume $V_{\\\\text{reactor}} = 15.00~\\\\mu\\\\text{L}$ comprises a gas-tight headspace ($V_{\\\\text{g}}$) and a single-phase liquid solution ($V_{\\\\ell}$). \\n\\nAt $T = 313.15~\\\\text{K}$, the reactor is filled so that $V_{\\\\ell} = 10.00~\\\\mu\\\\text{L}$ (liquid), $V_{\\\\text{g}} = 5.00~\\\\mu\\\\text{L}$ (headspace). The liquid phase contains a binary solvent mixture prepared from heavy water ($m_{\\\\text{D}_2\\\\text{O}} = 6.00~\\\\text{mg}$, $M_{\\\\text{D}_2\\\\text{O}} = 20.03~\\\\text{g}~\\\\text{mol}^{-1}$, $\\\\varepsilon_{r,\\\\mathrm{D}_2\\\\mathrm{O}} = 76.5$) and deuterated acetonitrile ($m_{\\\\mathrm{CD}_3\\\\mathrm{CN}} = 4.00~\\\\text{mg}$, $M_{\\\\mathrm{CD}_3\\\\mathrm{CN}} = 44.07~\\\\text{g}~\\\\text{mol}^{-1}$, $\\\\varepsilon_{r,\\\\mathrm{CD}_3\\\\mathrm{CN}} = 36.0$), with densities $\\\\rho_{\\\\text{D}_2\\\\text{O}} = 1.105~\\\\text{g}~\\\\text{mL}^{-1}$ and $\\\\rho_{\\\\mathrm{CD}_3\\\\mathrm{CN}} = 0.990~\\\\text{g}~\\\\text{mL}^{-1}$. Assume ideal mixing by mass and calculate all mole and volume fractions accordingly.\\n\\nThe reactor is equilibrated with $P_{\\\\text{NO}_2} = 0.1000~\\\\text{bar}$ of pure NO$_2$(g) (molar mass $M_{\\\\text{NO}_2}= 46.01~\\\\text{g}~\\\\text{mol}^{-1}$) in the headspace. Immediately upon closure, chemical reactions in the liquid phase proceed as:\\n\\n\\\\[ 2~\\\\text{NO}_2(\\\\ell) + \\\\text{D}_2\\\\text{O}(\\\\ell) \\\\rightleftharpoons \\\\text{DNO}_3(\\\\ell) + \\\\text{DNO}_2(\\\\ell) \\\\quad (1) \\\\]\\nDNO$_3$ is a strong acid (fully dissociated: D$^+$ + NO$_3^-$), while DNO$_2$ is a weak acid with dissociation constant $K_a = 5.60\\\\times10^{-4}$ at 313.15~K:\\n\\\\[ \\\\text{DNO}_2 \\\\rightleftharpoons \\\\text{D}^+ + \\\\text{NO}_2^- \\\\qquad (K_a) \\\\]\\nPhotolysis of NO$_3^-$ is induced by a collimated, monochromatic UV source ($\\\\lambda = 254.0~\\\\text{nm}$, photon flux $I_0 = 1.00 \\\\times 10^{-6}~\\\\text{mol}~\\\\text{photons}~\\\\text{m}^{-2}\\\\text{s}^{-1}$, uniformly irradiating the entire $A = 9.61~\\\\text{mm}^2$ cross-section of the $b = 1.000~\\\\text{mm}$ liquid light path). The photolysis reaction is:\\n\\\\[ \\\\text{NO}_3^- + h\\\\nu \\\\longrightarrow \\\\text{products~(do~not~affect~ionic~charge~balance)}\\\\qquad (2) \\\\]\\nQuantum yield $\\\\Phi = 0.1000$; molar absorptivity $\\\\varepsilon = 1900~\\\\text{L}~\\\\text{mol}^{-1}~\\\\text{cm}^{-1}$. Assume optically thin conditions (less than 10% absorption across $b$).\\n\\nOther data and assumptions:\\n1. The partial pressure of NO$_2$(g) in the headspace remains constant at $0.1000~\\\\text{bar}$ for the duration of the experiment due to a large external reservoir.\\n2. Henry's law for NO$_2$ in the solvent mixture at $313.15~\\\\text{K}$: $k_H = 0.0280~\\\\text{mol}~\\\\text{L}^{-1}~\\\\text{bar}^{-1}$.\\n3. Disproportionation in (1) is second-order in [NO$_2$(aq)]: $\\\\text{Rate}_{\\\\text{disp}} = k_{\\\\text{disp}}[\\\\text{NO}_2(\\\\ell)]^2$ with $k_{\\\\text{disp}} = 1.00 \\\\times 10^6~\\\\text{L}~\\\\text{mol}^{-1}~\\\\text{s}^{-1}$.\\n4. The steady-state is defined: the rate of NO$_3^-$ formation by (1) equals the rate of its destruction by photolysis. Photolysis occurs only for dissolved NO$_3^-$.\\n5. For photolysis at low absorbance, the rate per reactor is: $r_{\\\\text{photo}} = \\\\Phi \\\\varepsilon b I_0 [\\\\text{NO}_3^-]$. Ensure units are consistent using SI as needed.\\n6. Charge neutrality and mass balance must be applied to calculate free $[\\\\text{NO}_2^-]$.\\n7. Activity coefficients for ions are required. Use the Davies equation:\\n   $\\\\log_{10}(\\\\gamma_i) = -A z_i^2 \\\\left( \\\\frac{\\\\sqrt{I}}{1+\\\\sqrt{I}} - 0.3 I \\\\right)$,\\n   where $I$ is ionic strength in mol~L$^{-1}$, $z_i$ is the charge. \\n8. $A$ (Debye\u2013H\u00fcckel parameter) is given by $A=A_0\\\\left(\\\\frac{\\\\varepsilon_{r,0} T_0}{\\\\varepsilon_{r,\\\\text{mix}}T}\\\\right)^{3/2}$ with $A_0=0.509~\\\\text{L}^{1/2}~\\\\text{mol}^{-1/2}$ ($\\\\varepsilon_{r,0}=78.4$, $T_0=298.15~\\\\text{K}$).\\n9. The dielectric constant $\\\\varepsilon_{r,\\\\text{mix}}$ is a mole-fraction-weighted average of the two solvents.\\n10. Standard state: $c^\\\\circ = 1~\\\\text{mol}~\\\\text{L}^{-1}$.\\n11. The system is isothermal, and the activity of the neutral solutes and solvents is unity. \\n12. All concentrations are to be calculated in the liquid phase.\\n13. Physical constants: $R = 8.3145~\\\\text{J}~\\\\text{mol}^{-1}~\\\\text{K}^{-1}$; Avogadro's number $N_A = 6.022\\\\times10^{23}~\\\\text{mol}^{-1}$.\\n\\n**Task:**\\n\\nCalculate the steady-state molar concentration of free nitrite anion, $[\\\\text{NO}_2^-]$, in the liquid solution under these conditions. Express your answer as a decimal value in units of millimoles per liter (mmol~L$^{-1}$), to three significant figures.\\n\\n(For purposes of calculation, you may neglect any minor volume change from NO$_2$ dissolution, and may assume all other minor ions are absent. You must account for ionic strength and use the iterated values of activity coefficients and charge balance consistently. All required relationships, definitions, and constants are given above.)\

A photochemical experiment is performed to quantify the yield of isomerized product $P$ generated from the photoinduced \\\\textit{cis-trans} isomerization of Compound $A$ (a substituted azobenzene) in the presence of a heavy-atom quencher $Q$ (1-iodohexane). The experiment is carried out as follows:\\\\\\\\\\n\\n\\\\textbf{Experimental System and Definitions:}\\n\\\\begin{itemize}\\n  \\\\item A $2.00~\\\\mathrm{mL}$ solution is prepared with initial concentrations $[A]_0 = 2.50 \\\\times 10^{-5}~\\\\mathrm{mol}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{L}^{-1}$ and $[Q]_0 = 0.0750~\\\\mathrm{mol}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{L}^{-1}$ in an $85{:}15$ by mass glycerol/water mixture.\\n  \\\\item The entire $2.00~\\\\mathrm{mL}$ is contained in a standard $1.00~\\\\mathrm{cm}$ pathlength quartz cuvette ($A_{\\\\mathrm{beam}} = 0.800~\\\\mathrm{cm}^2$), and the solution is rapidly stirred and maintained at $T = 303.15~\\\\mathrm{K}$ so it is well-mixed at all times. \\n  \\\\item The solution is uniformly irradiated from the front face with a collimated lamp of Gaussian spectral irradiance:\\n    \\\\[\\n      I_0(\\\\lambda) = \\\\frac{P_{\\\\mathrm{total}}}{A_{\\\\mathrm{beam}} \\\\sigma_{\\\\lambda} \\\\sqrt{2\\\\pi}}\\\\exp\\\\left[-\\\\frac{(\\\\lambda - \\\\lambda_{\\\\mathrm{peak}})^2}{2\\\\sigma_{\\\\lambda}^2}\\\\right],\\n    \\\\]\\n    where $P_{\\\\mathrm{total}} = 0.125~\\\\mathrm{W}$, $\\\\lambda_{\\\\mathrm{peak}} = 365.0~\\\\mathrm{nm}$, $\\\\sigma_{\\\\lambda} = 15.0~\\\\mathrm{nm}$.\\\\\\\\\\n  \\\\item Compound $A$ absorbs as a Gaussian:\\n    \\\\[\\n      \\\\varepsilon_A(\\\\lambda) = \\\\varepsilon_{\\\\mathrm{max}}\\\\exp\\\\left[-\\\\frac{(\\\\lambda - \\\\lambda_{\\\\mathrm{abs}})^2}{2\\\\sigma_{\\\\mathrm{abs}}^2}\\\\right]\\n    \\\\]\\n    with $\\\\varepsilon_{\\\\mathrm{max}} = 3.50 \\\\times 10^4~\\\\mathrm{L}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{mol}^{-1}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{cm}^{-1}$, $\\\\lambda_{\\\\mathrm{abs}} = 360.0~\\\\mathrm{nm}$, $\\\\sigma_{\\\\mathrm{abs}} = 25.0~\\\\mathrm{nm}$.\\\\\\\\\\n  \\\\item The irradiation time is $t = 120.0~\\\\mathrm{s}$.\\\\\\\\\\n  \\\\item The absorption spectrum of $A$ lies entirely in $\\\\lambda \\\\in [280,460]~\\\\mathrm{nm}$.\\n\\\\end{itemize}\\n\\n\\\\textbf{Kinetic Scheme:}\\n\\\\begin{itemize}\\n  \\\\item Upon absorption, $A$ becomes excited ($A^*$). $A^*$ is removed by the competing pathways:\\n    \\\\begin{align*}\\n      & (1)~\\\\text{Fluorescence:} &&A^* \\\\xrightarrow{k_f} A + h\\\\nu \\\\\\\\\\n      & (2)~\\\\text{Isomerization:} &&A^* \\\\xrightarrow{k_{\\\\mathrm{rxn}}} P \\\\\\\\\\n      & (3)~\\\\text{Intrinsic ISC:} &&A^* \\\\xrightarrow{k_{\\\\mathrm{ISC}}^0} A^{**} \\\\\\\\\\n      & (4)~\\\\text{Diffusive Quenching:} &&A^* + Q \\\\xrightarrow{k_{q}} A + Q \\\\\\\\\\n      & (5)~\\\\text{Heavy-Atom ISC:} &&A^* + Q \\\\xrightarrow{k_{\\\\mathrm{HA}}} A^{**} + Q\\n    \\\\end{align*}\\n    where $A^{**}$ is the triplet state.\\n\\n  \\\\item All triplet $A^{**}$ irreversibly returns to the ground state via non-photochemical decay:\\n    \\\\[\\n      A^{**} \\\\to A\\\\qquad [\\\\text{first order, } k_T = 2.00\\\\times10^4~\\\\mathrm{s}^{-1}]\\n    \\\\]\\n    No product $P$ forms from the triplet and both $A$ and $Q$ remain at near-initial concentrations throughout ($[A] \\\\approx [A]_0$, $[Q] \\\\approx [Q]_0$; low conversion applies).\\n\\\\end{itemize}\\n\\n\\\\textbf{Kinetic and Thermodynamic Parameters:}\\n\\\\begin{itemize}\\n  \\\\item The natural fluorescence lifetime of $A^*$ (in the absence of quenching and ISC) is $\\\\tau_f^0 = 1.85~\\\\mathrm{ns}$, so $k_f = 1/\\\\tau_f^0$.\\n  \\\\item Intrinsic ISC rate: $k_{\\\\mathrm{ISC}}^0 = 2.20 \\\\times 10^7~\\\\mathrm{s}^{-1}$.\\n  \\\\item Heavy-atom ISC rate: $k_{\\\\mathrm{HA}} = 1.75 \\\\times 10^8~\\\\mathrm{L}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{mol}^{-1}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{s}^{-1}$.\\n  \\\\item Isomerization Eyring parameters: $\\\\Delta H^\\\\ddagger = 28.50~\\\\mathrm{kJ}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{mol}^{-1}$, $\\\\Delta S^\\\\ddagger = -15.0~\\\\mathrm{J}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{mol}^{-1}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{K}^{-1}$.\\n  \\\\item Transmission coefficient for the transition state ($\\\\kappa$) is $1$.\\n\\\\end{itemize}\\n\\n\\\\textbf{Solvent and Transport Properties:}\\n\\\\begin{itemize}\\n  \\\\item Viscosity $\\\\eta(T)$ is given by $\\\\eta(T) = A_\\\\eta\\\\exp\\\\left(\\\\frac{B_\\\\eta}{T - T_0}\\\\right)$, with $A_\\\\eta = 2.15\\\\times10^{-4}~\\\\mathrm{Pa}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{s}$, $B_\\\\eta = 910.0~\\\\mathrm{K}$, $T_0 = 140.0~\\\\mathrm{K}$.\\n  \\\\item Hydrodynamic radii: $r_A = 0.72~\\\\mathrm{nm}$, $r_Q = 0.38~\\\\mathrm{nm}$ (these must be converted to SI units for rate calculations).\\n  \\\\item Diffusion coefficients: $D_A = \\\\frac{k_B T}{6 \\\\pi \\\\eta r_A},~D_Q = \\\\frac{k_B T}{6 \\\\pi \\\\eta r_Q}$.\\n  \\\\item Diffusion-limited quenching rate constant: $k_{q} = 4 \\\\pi N_A (D_A + D_Q)(r_A + r_Q)$; $N_A$ is Avogadro's number.\\n\\\\end{itemize}\\n\\n\\\\textbf{Procedure and Optical Considerations:}\\n\\\\begin{itemize}\\n  \\\\item Use the Beer\u2013Lambert law accounting for the exponential attenuation of the photon flux along the optical path: for $l=1.00~\\\\mathrm{cm}$, average over the depth (integrate over $x$ from $0$ to $l$) to get the total photons absorbed per second.\\n  \\\\item Assume the quantum yield of product ($\\\\Phi_P$) is set by the fraction of $A^*$ precursors reacting via isomerization, with the steady-state approximation for $[A^*]$.\\n  \\\\item All constants and calculations should use SI units unless stated otherwise.\\n  \\\\item Fundamental physical constants:\\n    \\\\begin{itemize}\\n      \\\\item Planck's constant: $h = 6.62607015 \\\\times 10^{-34}~\\\\mathrm{J}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{s}$\\n      \\\\item Speed of light: $c = 2.99792458 \\\\times 10^8~\\\\mathrm{m}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{s}^{-1}$\\n      \\\\item Boltzmann constant: $k_B = 1.380649 \\\\times 10^{-23}~\\\\mathrm{J}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{K}^{-1}$\\n      \\\\item Avogadro's number: $N_A = 6.02214076\\\\times10^{23}~\\\\mathrm{mol}^{-1}$\\n      \\\\item Gas constant: $R = 8.31446~\\\\mathrm{J}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{mol}^{-1}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{K}^{-1}$\\n    \\\\end{itemize}\\n\\\\end{itemize}\\n\\n\\\\textbf{Required Calculation:}\\n\\\\\\\\\\nCalculate the final concentration of product $[P]_f$ (in $\\\\mathrm{mol}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{L}^{-1}$) at the end of $120.0~\\\\mathrm{s}$, using all information above.\\\\\\\\\\n\\\\textit{Notes:}\\n\\\\begin{itemize}\\n  \\\\item Assume ideal solution behavior and low photoconversion, so $[A]$ and $[Q]$ remain constant, and absorption by $P$ and $A^{**}$ is negligible.\\n  \\\\item Show all steps symbolically, but only the numerical value for $[P]_f$ is required in your answer.\\n\\\\end{itemize}\

### Thermodynamic and Kinetic Analysis of Dynamic Luminescence Quenching by Chromate: Quantitative Determination of First Harmonic Response\\n\\n**Background:**\\n\\nA thermostated reaction cell contains 100.0\\\\,mL of a 20.00\\\\,% (v/v) methanol\u2013water mixture, buffered by 0.1000\\\\,mol\\\\,L$^{-1}$ acetic acid ($\\\\mathrm{CH_3COOH}$) and 0.1500\\\\,mol\\\\,L$^{-1}$ sodium acetate ($\\\\mathrm{CH_3COONa}$). To this is added a single, flat, disk-shaped pellet of pure $\\\\mathrm{Ag_2CrO_4}$ ($\\\\mathrm{m_{pellet} = 0.5000\\\\ g}$, molar mass = 331.73\\\\,g\\\\,mol$^{-1}$), which is allowed to equilibrate with the solution under a $\\mathrm{N_2}$ atmosphere at atmospheric pressure. The pellet is vastly in excess such that the solution always saturates with respect to $\\\\mathrm{Ag_2CrO_4(s)}$ over the time period of interest.\\n\\nA europium(III) probe complex, $\\\\mathrm{Eu(III)-(R)-L}$, is dissolved to a concentration of $7.00 \\\\times 10^{-6}$\\\\,mol\\\\,L$^{-1}$, well below quenching saturation. The solution initially contains negligible chromate anion before the pellet is added. At time $t=0$, a temperature modulation $T(t) = T_0 + \\\\Delta T \\\\sin(\\\\omega t)$ is initiated, with $T_0 = 298.15$\\\\,K, $\\\\Delta T = 0.0800$\\\\,K, and $\\\\omega = 0.0500$\\\\,rad\\\\,s$^{-1}$.\\n\\n**Key Solution Properties and Constants:**\\n\\n* Ionic strength at $T_0$, before dissolution: $I_0 = \\\\frac{1}{2}\\\\sum c_iz_i^2 = 0.1250$\\\\,mol\\\\,L$^{-1}$ (from buffer only).\\n* Upon dissolution, $\\\\mathrm{Ag_2CrO_4(s)} \\\\rightleftharpoons 2 Ag^+(aq) + CrO_4^{2-}(aq)$, producing $2x$\\\\,mol\\\\,L$^{-1}$ $Ag^+$ and $x$\\\\,mol\\\\,L$^{-1}$ $CrO_4^{2-}$.\\n* Assume $I$ (for calculating activity coefficients) is fixed at 0.1250\\\\,mol\\\\,L$^{-1}$ and does not appreciably change upon limited dissolution.\\n* Use the Davies equation: $\\\\log_{10}(\\\\gamma_i) = -A z_i^2 \\\\left( \\\\frac{\\\\sqrt{I}}{1 + \\\\sqrt{I}} - 0.3 I \\\\right)$, with $A = 0.600$\\\\,L$^{1/2}$\\\\,mol$^{-1/2}$.\\n\\n* Solubility product at $T_0$: $K_{sp}^{\\\\circ} = 1.20 \\\\times 10^{-12}$ ($a_{Ag^+}^2 a_{CrO_4^{2-}}$), with $a_{j} = [j]\\\\gamma_j$.\\n* Standard enthalpy of dissolution: $\\\\Delta H_{sp}^{\\\\circ} = +65.5$\\\\,kJ\\\\,mol$^{-1}$.\\n* Molar mass $M_{Ag_2CrO_4} = 331.73$\\\\,g\\\\,mol$^{-1}$.\\n\\n* Chromate acid\u2013base: $CrO_4^{2-}(aq) + H^+(aq) \\\\rightleftharpoons HCrO_4^-(aq)$ with $pK_{a,2}^{\\\\circ} = 6.495$ at $T_0$, $\\\\Delta H_{a2}^{\\\\circ} = -5.90$\\\\,kJ\\\\,mol$^{-1}$.\\n* Acetic acid dissociation: $CH_3COOH \\\\rightleftharpoons CH_3COO^- + H^+$, $K_{a,AcOH}^{\\\\circ} = 1.80 \\\\times 10^{-5}$, $\\\\Delta H_{a,AcOH}^{\\\\circ} = -0.400$\\\\,kJ\\\\,mol$^{-1}$.\\n\\n* $g_{lum}$ depends on $[CrO_4^{2-}]$: $g_{lum}([CrO_4^{2-}]) = g_{lum,0} \\\\exp(-k_{chiral}[CrO_4^{2-}])$\\n  * $g_{lum,0} = -0.0850$\\n  * $k_{chiral} = 1.50 \\\\times 10^4$\\\\,L\\\\,mol$^{-1}$\\n\\n* Transient response: $[CrO_4^{2-}]$ relaxes towards its (instantaneous, temperature-dependent) equilibrium value $x_{eq}(t)$ following $\\\\tau_{relax} = 50.0$\\\\,s: $\\\\frac{dx}{dt} = -\\\\frac{1}{\\\\tau_{relax}}(x - x_{eq}(t))$\\n* Acid\u2013base equilibrium between $CrO_4^{2-}$ and $HCrO_4^-$ is always instantaneously established.\\n\\n* Universal gas constant: $R = 8.3145$\\\\,J\\\\,mol$^{-1}$\\\\,K$^{-1}$\\n\\n**Claims and Conventions:**\\n1. $Ag_2CrO_4$ is always present in excess; solution always equilibrates to its solubility product for any $T$.\\n2. The $\\\\mathrm{Eu(III)-(R)-L}$ probe does not affect $Ag_2CrO_4$ solubility.\\n3. Neglect complexation of $Ag^+$ by methanol or acetate, and ignore photoreactions; $Ag^+$ does not precipitate further. Assume all ions' activities are as computed from the fixed $I_0$.\\n4. All neutral species have activity coefficient $1$.\\n5. $pH$ is fully buffered and set entirely by $[CH_3COOH]$/$[CH_3COO^-]$ and $K_{a,AcOH}(T)$, with negligible chromate impact.\\n6. Initial $[CrO_4^{2-}] = 0$, before pellet addition.\\n7. The total solution volume stays precisely at 100.0\\\\,mL throughout.\\n\\n**Mathematical Definition:**\\nLet $g_{lum}(t)$ be the laboratory-measured observable after modulation is started, with initial equilibration complete. For harmonic analysis, define the (complex) first harmonic amplitude of $g_{lum}(t)$ as\\n\\\\[\\n|g_{lum}(\\\\omega)| = \\\\frac{2}{T_{mod}} \\\\left| \\\\int_0^{T_{mod}} g_{lum}(t) e^{-i\\\\omega t}\\\\,dt \\\\right|\\\\ ,\\\\quad T_{mod} = \\\\frac{2\\\\pi}{\\\\omega}\\n\\\\]\\n\\n**Task:**\\n\\nCalculate the numerical value of $|g_{lum}(\\\\omega)|$ (dimensionless), the modulus of the first harmonic amplitude of the dissymmetry signal, expressed to 3 significant figures. Present only this value (no units).\

A graduate student investigates the ionic conductivity resulting from the controlled radical polymerization of deuterated vinyl acetate (vinyl acetate-d$_3$, $\\\\mathrm{CD_3COOCH{=}CH_2}$) in anhydrous 1,4-dioxane ($\\\\varepsilon_r = 2.21$ at $25^\\\\circ\\\\mathrm{C}$). The reaction employs potassium tert-butoxide (KOtBu) as both initiator and in-situ chain transfer agent, following this overall scheme:\\n\\n\\\\[\\\\begin{align*}\\n\\\\text{Initiation:} & \\\\quad \\\\mathrm{KOtBu} \\\\xrightarrow{\\\\Delta} \\\\mathrm{K^+} + \\\\mathrm{tBuO}^- \\\\\\\\\\n& \\\\qquad \\\\mathrm{tBuO}^- + M \\\\longrightarrow \\\\mathrm{Polymer\\\\ chain} - \\\\mathrm{O^-} + \\\\mathrm{K^+} \\\\\\\\\\n\\\\text{Propagation:} & \\\\quad \\\\mathrm{Polymer\\\\ chain{-}CH_2^\\\\bullet} + M \\\\longrightarrow \\\\mathrm{Polymer\\\\ chain{-}CH_2{-}CH_2^\\\\bullet} \\\\\\\\\\n\\\\text{Chain\\\\ transfer:} & \\\\quad \\\\mathrm{Polymer\\\\ radical} + \\\\mathrm{KOtBu} \\\\rightarrow \\\\mathrm{Polymer_tBu} + \\\\mathrm{tBuO}^\\\\bullet \\\\\\\\\\n\\\\end{align*}\\\\]\\n\\nThe procedure is as follows:\\n- The initial solution is prepared by dissolving $n_\\\\mathrm{M,0} = 1.500$ mol vinyl acetate-d$_3$ and $n_{\\\\mathrm{KOtBu},0} = 0.0250$ mol KOtBu in dry 1,4-dioxane to yield a total volume $V_\\\\mathrm{init} = 1.000$ L at $T_\\\\mathrm{poly} = 343.15$ K.\\n- Polymerization proceeds with stirring at $343.15$ K until precisely $96.0\\\\%$ of the monomer is converted ($p = 0.960$). The polymerization is then rapidly quenched.\\n- Upon quenching, the mixture contains: poly(vinyl acetate-d$_3$), residual unreacted KOtBu, and byproducts. All polymer and associated counterions (including any K$^+$ from KOtBu lost to chain-capping) precipitate completely and are quantitatively separated by filtration\u2014the filtrate is assumed to contain only unreacted, fully dissociated KOtBu in 1,4-dioxane, with no additional ionic species present.\\n- The filtrate is then quantitatively diluted with pure 1,4-dioxane at $25.00^\\\\circ \\\\mathrm{C}$ to a final total volume $V_\\\\mathrm{final} = 1.000$ L.\\n- The electrical conductivity $\\\\kappa$ of this final solution at $T_\\\\mathrm{meas} = 298.15$ K is measured.\\n\\nGiven:\\n- All KOtBu is assumed fully dissociated in dioxane; but due to the low dielectric constant, ion pairing occurs and must be corrected using the Fuoss\u2013Kraus model for 1:1 electrolytes:\\n\\n\\\\[\\\\alpha = \\\\frac{1}{1 + \\\\frac{A_{IP}}{\\\\sqrt{c}}\\\\exp\\\\left(\\\\frac{B_{IP}}{\\\\sqrt{c}}\\\\right)} \\\\quad \\\\text{with}\\\\quad c = [\\\\mathrm{KOtBu}] \\\\text{ after all dilutions and precipitation (in mol L$^{-1}$)} \\\\]\\n- Only free (unpaired) ions contribute to the conductivity, per: $\\\\kappa = \\\\alpha \\\\cdot \\\\Lambda_m^0 \\\\cdot c$, where $\\\\Lambda_m^0$ is the limiting molar conductivity\\n- Limiting molar ionic conductivities in 1,4-dioxane at $298.15$ K:\\n  - $\\\\lambda^0_{\\\\mathrm{K}^+} = 39.0 \\\\times 10^{-4}$ S m$^2$ mol$^{-1}$\\n  - $\\\\lambda^0_{\\\\mathrm{tBuO}^-} = 31.0 \\\\times 10^{-4}$ S m$^2$ mol$^{-1}$\\n- Ion pairing coefficients for KOtBu in 1,4-dioxane at $298.15$ K:\\n  - $A_{IP} = 3.15$ L$^{1/2}$ mol$^{-1/2}$\\n  - $B_{IP} = 2.50$\\n- Partial molar volumes (assume constant through conversion):\\n  - Vinyl acetate-d$_3$: $\\\\bar{V}_M = 85.0$ cm$^3$ mol$^{-1}$\\n  - Poly(vinyl acetate-d$_3$) repeat unit: $\\\\bar{V}_{RU} = 79.0$ cm$^3$ mol$^{-1}$\\n  - KOtBu: $\\\\bar{V}_S = 92.0$ cm$^3$ mol$^{-1}$\\n- The chain transfer to KOtBu obeys the Mayo\u2013Walling relation with transfer constant $C_S = 0.420$: the residual [KOtBu] after conversion $p$ is given by\\n\\n\\\\[\\n\\\\frac{[S]_\\\\mathrm{final}}{[S]_0} = (1-p)^{C_S}\\\\,, \\\\qquad [S]_0 = n_{\\\\mathrm{KOtBu},0}/V_\\\\mathrm{init}\\n\\\\]\\n\\n- The final [KOtBu] must account for both consumption by chain transfer and the final volume.\\n- The volume expansion/contraction due to reaction is fully accounted for via partial molar volumes; after filtration and quantitative dilution, the solution is returned to exactly 1.000 L.\\n\\n**Constants:**\\n- $N_A = 6.02214 \\\\times 10^{23}$ mol$^{-1}$\\n- $1$ S = $1$ $\\\\Omega^{-1}$ m$^{-1}$\\n\\n**Task:**\\n\\nUsing the above, calculate the final electrical conductivity $\\\\kappa$ (in S m$^{-1}$, SI units) of the post-reaction, post-filtration, fully diluted KOtBu/1,4-dioxane solution, **to four significant figures**.\

A continuous-flow photoreactor is constructed as a uniform, cylindrical tube of *internal length* $L = 1.500\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$ and *internal diameter* $d = 4.00\\\\ \\\\mathrm{cm}$, oriented horizontally. At the inlet, the temperature is $T_{\\\\mathrm{in}} = 400.0\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K}$, rising quadratically along the length according to \\n\\n$$ T(z) = T_{\\\\mathrm{in}} + (T_{\\\\mathrm{out}} - T_{\\\\mathrm{in}}) \\\\left(\\\\frac{z}{L}\\\\right)^2 $$\\nwhere $T_{\\\\mathrm{out}} = 800.0\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K}$, $z$ ($0 \\\\leq z \\\\leq L$) is the axial position.\\n\\nA dilute (trace) concentration of 4-methoxyacetophenone (4-MAP, negligible effect on bulk properties) is dispersed in the gas and exposed to a uniform laser beam along the entire length. The principal photochemical sequence initiated is:\\n\\n\\\\[\\\\begin{align*}\\n\\\\text{4-MAP}\\\\ (S_0) &\\\\xrightarrow{h\\\\nu} \\\\text{4-MAP}\\\\ (S_1) \\\\\\\\\\n\\\\text{4-MAP}\\\\ (S_1) &\\\\xrightarrow{\\\\Phi_{\\\\mathrm{ISC}}} \\\\text{4-MAP}\\\\ (T_1) \\\\\\\\\\n\\\\text{4-MAP}\\\\ (T_1) &\\\\xrightarrow{k_r} \\\\text{Product} \\\\\\\\\\n\\\\text{4-MAP}\\\\ (T_1) &\\\\xrightarrow{k_d} \\\\text{4-MAP}\\\\ (S_0) \\\\\\\\\\n\\\\text{4-MAP}\\\\ (T_1) + \\\\text{Xe} &\\\\xrightarrow{k_q(T)} \\\\text{4-MAP}\\\\ (S_0) + \\\\text{Xe} \\\\\\\\\\n\\\\text{4-MAP}\\\\ (T_1) + \\\\text{Ar} &\\\\xrightarrow{k^{\\\\mathrm{Ar}}_q(T)} \\\\text{4-MAP}\\\\ (S_0) + \\\\text{Ar} \\n\\\\end{align*}\\\\]\\n\\n#### Physical and Kinetic Parameters (use only the data provided; no other sources)\\n* **Molecular radii:** $r_{\\\\mathrm{4-MAP}} = 3.80\\\\times10^{-10}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$, $r_{\\\\mathrm{Xe}} = 2.20\\\\times10^{-10}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$, $r_{\\\\mathrm{Ar}} = 1.88\\\\times10^{-10}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$\\n* **Molar mass (kg / mol):** $M_{\\\\mathrm{4-MAP}} = 0.15017$, $M_{\\\\mathrm{Xe}} = 0.13129$, $M_{\\\\mathrm{Ar}} = 0.03995$\\n* **Harmonic mean reduced mass** (for collisions with 4-MAP): $\\\\mu_{j} = \\\\left(M_{\\\\mathrm{4-MAP}}^{-1} + M_j^{-1}\\\\right)^{-1}$ for $j = \\\\mathrm{Ar}$ or $\\\\mathrm{Xe}$\\n* **Avogadro constant:** $N_A = 6.02214\\\\times10^{23}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{mol}^{-1}$\\n* **Boltzmann constant:** $k_B = 1.38065\\\\times10^{-23}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{J\\\\,K}^{-1}$ \\n* **Gas constant:** $R = 8.31446\\\\ \\\\mathrm{J\\\\,mol}^{-1}\\\\mathrm{K}^{-1}$\\n\\n#### Non-Ideal Gas Equation of State (applies to total mixture at $P_\\\\mathrm{tot}$, not partial pressures)\\n\\nThe molar volume is determined by the Virial equation, truncated at the second term:\\n\\\\[\\\\frac{P_{\\\\mathrm{tot}} V_m(z)}{RT(z)} = 1 + \\\\frac{B_{\\\\mathrm{mix}}(T(z))}{V_m(z)}\\\\]\\nThe mixture second virial coefficient (in $\\\\mathrm{m}^3\\\\,\\\\mathrm{mol}^{-1}$):\\n\\\\[\\nB_{\\\\mathrm{mix}}(T) = X_{\\\\mathrm{Ar}}^2 B_{\\\\mathrm{ArAr}}(T) + 2 X_{\\\\mathrm{Ar}}X_{\\\\mathrm{Xe}} B_{\\\\mathrm{ArXe}}(T) + X_{\\\\mathrm{Xe}}^2 B_{\\\\mathrm{XeXe}}(T)\\n\\\\]\\nwith component virial coefficients $B_{ij}(T) = a_{ij} - b_{ij} \\\\exp(c_{ij}/T)$ and parameters:\\n\\n| Species Pair       | $a_{ij}$ [$\\\\mathrm{m}^3\\\\mathrm{mol}^{-1}$] | $b_{ij}$ [$\\\\mathrm{m}^3\\\\mathrm{mol}^{-1}$] | $c_{ij}$ [K] |\\n|-------------------|---------------------------------------------|---------------------------------------------|-------------|\\n| Ar--Ar            | $4.19\\\\times 10^{-5}$                        | $1.02\\\\times10^{-4}$                         | 119.8       |\\n| Xe--Xe            | $5.10\\\\times 10^{-5}$                        | $1.51\\\\times10^{-4}$                         | 229.0       |\\n| Ar--Xe            | $4.60\\\\times 10^{-5}$                        | $1.25\\\\times10^{-4}$                         | 165.0       |\\n\\n#### Kinetics and Photophysics\\n* The quantum yield for intersystem crossing is **unity:** $\\\\Phi_{\\\\mathrm{ISC}} = 1.00$ (not temperature-dependent), so every absorbed photon populates $T_1$.\\n* The **intrinsic (Xe/Ar-free) triplet lifetime:** $\\\\tau_0 = 2.50\\\\times10^{-6}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{s}$\\n* The **intrinsic product quantum yield:** $\\\\Phi_P^0 = 0.850$ (in Xe/Ar-free conditions)\\n* **First-order decay and product formation rates** are related by $k_r = \\\\Phi_P^0 / \\\\tau_0$ and $k_d = (1-\\\\Phi_P^0)/\\\\tau_0$\\n\\n#### Bimolecular Quenching Rate Constants\\nFor 4-MAP($T_1$) + $j$ collisions ($j$ = Xe or Ar):\\n\\\\[k_q^{(j)}(T) = \\\\mathcal{P}_q^{(j)}(T) \\\\cdot \\\\sigma_{\\\\mathrm{coll}}^{(j)} \\\\cdot \\\\langle v_{\\\\mathrm{rel}}^{(j)}(T) \\\\rangle N_A \\\\]\\nwhere:\\n* **Collision cross section:** $\\\\sigma_{\\\\mathrm{coll}}^{(j)} = \\\\pi(r_{\\\\mathrm{4-MAP}} + r_j)^2$\\n* **Mean relative speed:** $\\\\langle v_{\\\\mathrm{rel}}^{(j)}(T) \\\\rangle = \\\\sqrt{\\\\frac{8 k_B T}{\\\\pi \\\\mu_{j}}}$\\n* **Quenching probability per collision:**\\n    * For Xe: $\\\\mathcal{P}_q^{(\\\\mathrm{Xe})}(T) = \\\\frac{\\\\mathcal{A}_{\\\\mathrm{Xe}}}{k_B T}$, $\\\\mathcal{A}_{\\\\mathrm{Xe}} = 2.600 \\\\times 10^{-23}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{J}$\\n    * For Ar:  $\\\\mathcal{P}_q^{(\\\\mathrm{Ar})}(T) = \\\\frac{\\\\mathcal{A}_{\\\\mathrm{Ar}}}{k_B T}$, $\\\\mathcal{A}_{\\\\mathrm{Ar}} = 3.00 \\\\times 10^{-24}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{J}$\\n\\n**\\\\textit{(All $\\\\mathcal{A}_j$ are given in Joules, NOT area\\\\,\\\\(\\\\cdot\\\\)\\\\,energy units.)}**\\n\\n#### Concentrations (to be used in the kinetic equations; all in $\\\\mathrm{mol}\\\\,\\\\mathrm{m}^{-3}$)\\nAt every $z$, the Xe and Ar concentrations are:\\n\\\\[[\\\\mathrm{Xe}](z) = \\\\frac{X_{\\\\mathrm{Xe}} P_{\\\\mathrm{tot}}}{RT(z)}\\\\frac{V_m^{\\\\mathrm{ideal}}(T(z),P_{\\\\mathrm{tot}})}{V_m(z)}\\\\ ,\\\\quad [\\\\mathrm{Ar}](z) = \\\\frac{X_{\\\\mathrm{Ar}} P_{\\\\mathrm{tot}}}{RT(z)}\\\\frac{V_m^{\\\\mathrm{ideal}}(T(z),P_{\\\\mathrm{tot}})}{V_m(z)}\\\\]\\nwhere $V_m(z)$ is solved self-consistently from the virial equation, and $V_m^{\\\\mathrm{ideal}}(T(z),P_{\\\\mathrm{tot}}) = RT(z)/P_{\\\\mathrm{tot}}$ (use mixture total pressure for all calculations).\\n\\n#### Local Quantum Yield\\nAt each position $z$, assume steady-state local triplet population and no radial gradients:\\n\\\\[\\n\\\\Phi_P(z) = \\\\frac{k_r}{k_r + k_d + k_q^{(\\\\mathrm{Xe})}(T(z))\\\\,[\\\\mathrm{Xe}](z) + k_q^{(\\\\mathrm{Ar})}(T(z))\\\\,[\\\\mathrm{Ar}](z)}\\n\\\\]\\n\\n#### Final Calculation\\n**Compute the volume-averaged product quantum yield for the entire reactor (i.e., the fraction of photons absorbed along the full length which generate product):**\\n\\\\[\\n\\\\langle \\\\Phi_P \\\\rangle_V = \\\\frac{1}{L} \\\\int_0^L \\\\Phi_P(z)\\\\, dz\\n\\\\]\\nReport $\\\\langle \\\\Phi_P \\\\rangle_V$ as a \\n**dimensionless number accurate to three significant figures**.\\n\\n---\\n\\n**Instructions:**\\n* Assume all data above are strictly correct, and all constants must be taken from this problem only.\\n* Use the provided forms for all rate expressions, and apply the total mixture pressure for all calculations as explicitly noted.\\n* Beer-Lambert attenuation, stimulated emission, and diffusion/dispersion effects are negligible for this problem; only axial gradients due to temperature need to be considered.\\n* All integrals and calculations must use *explicit SI units*. Do not cite external data.\\n* Your final answer should be a single, dimensionless number, $\\\\langle \\\\Phi_P \\\\rangle_V$, rounded to three significant digits.\

A research team investigates the thermodynamic and kinetic properties of a binary liquid mixture of acetone ($A$, \\\\ce{CH3COCH3}) and methanol ($B$, \\\\ce{CH3OH}) at atmospheric pressure ($P_{\\\\text{tot}} = 101.325\\\\ \\\\mathrm{kPa}$). The study involves vapor-liquid equilibrium (VLE), outer-sphere electron transfer, and electrochemical measurement, integrating concepts from solution thermodynamics, quantum kinetics, and electrochemistry.\\\\\\\\\\n\\n\\\\textbf{System Description:}\\n\\n- The binary mixture composition is $x_A=0.550$, $x_B=0.450$ (mole fraction, liquid phase).\\n- Total liquid volume is $V = 1.000\\\\ \\\\mathrm{L}$ prior to heating (assume negligible headspace and vaporisation at the measurement temperature for calculation purposes).\\n- The temperature is set to $T=328.00\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K}$.\\n\\n\\\\textbf{Vapor-Liquid Equilibrium:}\\n\\n- The vapor-liquid equilibrium is described by the one-parameter Margules model:\\n\\\\begin{align*}\\n    \\\\ln \\\\gamma_A &= A_{AB} x_B^2 \\\\\\\\\\n    \\\\ln \\\\gamma_B &= A_{AB} x_A^2\\n\\\\end{align*}\\n- $A_{AB} = 0.900$ (dimensionless; valid for $298\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K} \\\\leq T \\\\leq 338\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K}$).\\n- Pure component vapor pressures $P_i^*$ (in $\\\\mathrm{kPa}$) are given via the Antoine equation: $\\\\log_{10}\\\\left( \\\\frac{P_i^*}{\\\\mathrm{kPa}} \\\\right) = C_{i,1} - \\\\frac{C_{i,2}}{T/\\\\mathrm{K} + C_{i,3}}$\\n  \\\\begin{tabular}{cccc}\\n    \\\\text{Component} & $C_{i,1}$ & $C_{i,2}$ & $C_{i,3}$ \\\\\\\\\\n    \\\\ce{CH3COCH3} (A) & $7.1173$ & $1210.595$ & $229.664$ \\\\\\\\\\n    \\\\ce{CH3OH} (B) & $8.0724$ & $1574.990$ & $238.789$\\n  \\\\end{tabular}\\n- The fundamental VLE relationship is:\\n  \\\\begin{align*}\\n    &y_i = \\\\dfrac{x_i\\\\gamma_i P_i^*(T)}{P_{\\\\text{tot}}}\\\\\\\\\\n    &\\\\sum_i y_i = 1\\n  \\\\end{align*}\\n- Mole fractions $x_A,x_B$ are defined for the \\\\emph{liquid} phase, and $y_A,y_B$ for the \\\\emph{vapor} phase.\\n\\n\\\\textbf{Solvent Properties:}\\n\\n- Dielectric constants ($\\\\epsilon_{s}$, dimensionless) and refractive indices ($n$, dimensionless) at $T=328.00\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K}$:\\n  \\\\begin{tabular}{ccc}\\n    \\\\text{Component} & $\\\\epsilon_{s}$ & $n$ \\\\\\\\\\n    \\\\ce{CH3COCH3} (A) & $21.40$ & $1.359$ \\\\\\\\\\n    \\\\ce{CH3OH} (B) & $29.90$ & $1.330$\\n  \\\\end{tabular}\\n- For the mixture, use: $\\\\epsilon_{s,\\\\text{mix}} = x_A\\\\epsilon_{s,A} + x_B\\\\epsilon_{s,B}$, $n_{\\\\text{mix}} = x_A n_A + x_B n_B$.\\n\\n\\\\textbf{Electron Transfer Reaction:}\\n\\nIn this solvent, the reaction\\n\\\\ce{CoCp2^+ + FeCp2 -> CoCp2^{2+} + FeCp2^+}\\n(proceeding in the forward direction) is studied.\\\\\\\\\\n- Initial concentration of CoCp$_2^+$ ($\\\\ce{[CoCp2^+]}_0$): $2.00 \\\\times 10^{-4}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{mol\\\\ L^{-1}}$\\n- Initial concentration of FeCp$_2$ ($\\\\ce{[FeCp2]}_0$): $5.00\\\\times 10^{-2}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{mol\\\\ L^{-1}}$ (in large excess)\\n\\n- The self-exchange reorganization energy (inner-sphere): $\\\\lambda_i = 34.60\\\\ \\\\mathrm{kJ\\\\ mol^{-1}}$\\n- Outer-sphere reorganization energy (Marcus model):\\n  \\\\begin{align*}\\n    \\\\lambda_o = \\\\frac{N_A e^2}{4\\\\pi\\\\epsilon_0}\\\\left(\\\\frac{1}{2r_M} + \\\\frac{1}{2r_F} - \\\\frac{1}{r_{MF}}\\\\right)\\\\left(\\\\frac{1}{n_{\\\\text{mix}}^2} - \\\\frac{1}{\\\\epsilon_{s,\\\\text{mix}}}\\\\right)\\n  \\\\end{align*}\\n    where:\\n        - $r_M = 4.40 \\\\times 10^{-10}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$ (CoCp$_2^+$)\\n        - $r_F = 4.28 \\\\times 10^{-10}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$ (FeCp$_2$)\\n        - $r_{MF} = 1.50 \\\\times 10^{-9}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}$ (contact distance)\\n\\n- Electronic coupling: $|H_{MF}| = 1200\\\\ \\\\mathrm{cm}^{-1}$ (convert to energy: $E = hc\\\\tilde{\\nu}$, where $c = 2.9979\\\\times10^8\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m\\\\ s^{-1}}$)\\n- Marcus rate constant (bimolecular, $\\\\mathrm{M^{-1}s^{-1}}$):\\n  \\\\begin{align*}\\n    k_{ET} = \\\\frac{2\\\\pi}{\\\\hbar} |H_{MF}|^2 \\\\frac{1}{\\\\sqrt{4\\\\pi\\\\lambda k_B T}} \\\\exp\\\\left(-\\\\frac{(\\\\Delta G^{\\\\circ'} + \\\\lambda)^2}{4\\\\lambda k_B T}\\\\right)\\n  \\\\end{align*}\\n  - $\\\\lambda = \\\\lambda_i + \\\\lambda_o$\\n\\nStandard redox potentials: \\n- $E^{\\\\circ}_{\\\\ce{CoCp2^+/CoCp2}}$ (in pure MeCN, at $25^\\\\circ$C): $-0.126\\\\ \\\\mathrm{V\\\\ vs\\\\ Fc^+/Fc}$\\n- $E^{\\\\circ}_{\\\\ce{FeCp2^+/FeCp2}}$ (in pure MeCN): $+0.400\\\\ \\\\mathrm{V\\\\ vs\\\\ Fc^+/Fc}$\\n\\nBorn correction (solvent change to mixture):\\n\\\\begin{align*}\\n    \\\\Delta E_s^{\\\\circ}(X^{z}/X^{z-1}) = \\\\frac{(z^2 - (z-1)^2) e^2 N_A}{8\\\\pi\\\\epsilon_0 F r_X } \\\\left( \\\\frac{1}{\\\\epsilon_{s,\\\\text{mix}}} - \\\\frac{1}{\\\\epsilon_{s,\\\\mathrm{MeCN}}} \\\\right)\\n\\\\end{align*}\\n- Use $r_{\\\\ce{CoCp2^+}} = r_M$, $r_{\\\\ce{FeCp2}} = r_F$, $\\\\epsilon_{s,\\\\mathrm{MeCN}} = 37.5$.\\n- Use $z=2$ for CoCp$_2^{2+}$/CoCp$_2^+$ and $z=1$ for FeCp$_2^+$/FeCp$_2$ couples.\\n\\nThe change in standard free energy is:\\n\\\\begin{align*}\\n    \\\\Delta G^{\\\\circ'} = -F\\\\Big[ E^{\\\\circ*}_{\\\\ce{CoCp2^{2+}/CoCp2^+}} - E^{\\\\circ*}_{\\\\ce{FeCp2^+/FeCp2}} \\\\Big]\\n\\\\end{align*}\\nwhere $E^{\\\\circ*}$ for each couple denotes the solvent-corrected standard potential (including Born correction above).\\n\\n\\\\textbf{Kinetics:}\\n- The reaction is monitored for $t=10.0\\\\ \\\\mathrm{ms}$; assume pseudo-first-order kinetics because $\\\\ce{[FeCp2]^0}\\\\gg \\\\ce{[CoCp2^+]}^0$.\\n- $k_{obs} = k_{ET} \\\\cdot [\\\\ce{FeCp2^0}]$\\n- Relative concentrations for CoCp$_2^+$ and CoCp$_2^{2+}$ at $t$ are:\\n  \\\\begin{align*}\\n    [\\\\ce{CoCp2^+}]_t &= [\\\\ce{CoCp2^+}]_0 e^{-k_{obs} t} \\\\\\\\\\n    [\\\\ce{CoCp2^{2+}}]_t &= [\\\\ce{CoCp2^+}]_0 \\\\left[1 - e^{-k_{obs} t}\\\\right]\\\\end{align*}\\n\\n\\\\textbf{Electrochemistry:}\\n\\nA cell is constructed:\\n\\\\\\\\\\n\\\\ce{Pt(s)} | \\\\ce{CoCp2^{2+}}, \\\\ce{CoCp2^+} (in mixture) || \\\\ce{Ag^+} (0.0100\\\\ \\\\mathrm{mol\\\\ L^{-1}}, in MeCN) | \\\\ce{Ag(s)} \\n\\n- Assume all activity coefficients $\\\\approx 1$, so $a_{\\\\ce{Ag^+}} = c_{\\\\ce{Ag^+}}$.\\n- All volumes $=1.00\\\\ \\\\mathrm{L}$.\\n- Ignore any liquid/vapor loss at $T=328.00\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K}$.\\n- Ignore junction and liquid junction potentials.\\n- The standard potential for Ag$^+$/Ag(s) in pure MeCN: $+0.030\\\\ \\\\mathrm{V\\\\ vs\\\\ Fc^+/Fc}$.\\n\\n- The Nernst equation for the reference ($E_{ref}$, Ag/Ag$^+$) is:\\n  \\\\begin{align*}\\n    E_{ref} = E^{\\\\circ}_{\\\\ce{Ag^+/Ag,MeCN}} - A research team investigates mitochondrial control of root gravitropism in *Arabidopsis thaliana* by quantifying the effect of mitochondrial ATP-synthase kinetics and auxin signaling on the curvature angle ($\\\\theta$) of dark-grown seedling roots.\\n\\nTwo tightly linked genes on chromosome 3 are studied:\\n- $\\\\textbf{ATPG}$ encodes the $\\\\gamma$-subunit of the F$_1$F$_0$-ATP-synthase (mitochondrial ATP synthase).\\n    - Wild-type: $\\\\mathrm{ATPG}^+$\\n    - Mutant: $\\\\mathrm{atpg}^{A}$, a recessive loss-of-function allele causing elevated Michaelis constant ($K_m$) for ATP synthesis.\\n- $\\\\textbf{TIR1}$ encodes a nuclear auxin receptor.\\n    - Wild-type: $\\\\mathrm{TIR1}^+$\\n    - Mutant: $\\\\mathrm{TIR1}^{G}$, a co-dominant gain-of-function allele increasing auxin signaling sensitivity.\\n\\nThe two loci are 18.0 cM apart. The phase of heterozygosity is explicitly $\\\\textbf{coupling}$:\\n- Paternal plant: $[$$\\\\mathrm{ATPG}^+$$\\\\,\\\\mathrm{TIR1}^+$$]$ $/$ $[$$\\\\mathrm{atpg}^{A}$$\\\\,\\\\mathrm{TIR1}^{G}$$]$  (cis)\\n- Maternal plant: $[$$\\\\mathrm{ATPG}^+$$\\\\,\\\\mathrm{TIR1}^+$$]$ $/$ $[$$\\\\mathrm{atpg}^{A}$$\\\\,\\\\mathrm{TIR1}^{G}$$]$ (cis)\\n\\nPlants are self-crossed ($F_1$ selfed) and $F_2$ progeny are analyzed. \\n\\n$F_2$ seedlings are grown on vertical agar (2% w/v sucrose, pH 5.7) in total darkness (0 $\\\\mu$mol photons m$^{-2}$ s$^{-1}$, 23\u00b0C, 5 days) and then reoriented 90\u00b0 to trigger root gravitropism. After 12 h, the steady-state curvature $\\\\theta$ is measured ($\\\\theta = 0$ for unresponsive roots).\\n\\n$\\\\textbf{Key Biophysical and Genetic Data}$\\n\\n1. $\\\\textbf{Mitochondrial ATP Synthesis}$ (statocyte cell):\\n- Each statocyte contains $N_{\\\\text{mito}} = 250$ mitochondria. Each mitochondrion is a cylinder of height $10\\\\, \\\\mu$m and radius $0.5\\\\, \\\\mu$m.\\n- $J_{\\\\text{pump}} = J_{\\\\text{pump, basal}} (1 + \\\\xi\\\\, \\\\Delta U_g)$, where $J_{\\\\text{pump, basal}} = 1.10 \\\\times 10^{-17}$ mol H$^+$ s$^{-1}$ mito$^{-1}$, $g = 9.81$ m s$^{-2}$, $\\\\rho_{\\\\text{amyloplast}}=1.5 \\\\times 10^{3}$ kg m$^{-3}$, $\\\\rho_{\\\\text{cyto}}=1.04 \\\\times 10^{3}$ kg m$^{-3}$, $V_{\\\\text{amyloplast}} = 1.25 \\\\mu$m$^{3}$, $2r_{\\\\text{cell}}=16 \\\\mu$m.\\n- $\\\\Delta U_g = (\\\\rho_{\\\\text{amyloplast}} - \\\\rho_{\\\\text{cyto}}) V_{\\\\text{amyloplast}} g (2r_{\\\\text{cell}})$\\n- Mechanosensitivity: $\\\\xi = 4.0 \\\\times 10^{16}$ J$^{-1}$ (lower flank), $\\\\xi = -0.28 \\\\times 4.0 \\\\times 10^{16}$ J$^{-1}$ (upper flank).\\n\\n2. $\\\\textbf{Proton Circuit Equation}$ (mitoch., steady-state):\\n$$ J_{\\\\text{pump}} = J_{\\\\text{leak}} + n J_{\\\\text{ATP}} $$\\n- Non-ohmic leak: $J_{\\\\text{leak}} = g_{\\\\text{mem}} \\\\exp(\\\\Delta p / V_{\\\\text{leak}})$, $g_{\\\\text{mem}} = 1.0 \\\\times 10^{-20}$ mol H$^+$ s$^{-1}$ mito$^{-1}$, $V_{\\\\text{leak}}= 0.045$ V.\\n- ATP synthase: $J_{\\\\text{ATP}} = V_{\\\\text{max, ATP}} (\\\\Delta p/(K_m+\\\\Delta p)) f_{\\\\text{reg}}$, $n=4.33$, $V_{\\\\text{max, ATP}}= 6.10 \\\\times 10^{-18}$ mol ATP s$^{-1}$ mito$^{-1}$.\\n- $K_m$ values:\\n    \\n\\\\begin{tabular}{lcc}\\nGenotype & $K_m$ (V) & $V_{\\\\text{max, ATP}}$ ($\\\\cdots$) \\\\\\\\ \\\\hline\\n$\\\\mathrm{ATPG}^+\\\\/\\\\mathrm{ATPG}^+$ & 0.150 & 6.10 $\\\\times$ 10$^{-18}$ \\\\\\\\\\n$\\\\mathrm{ATPG}^+\\\\/\\\\mathrm{atpg}^{A}$ & 0.185 & 6.10 $\\\\times$ 10$^{-18}$ \\\\\\\\\\n$\\\\mathrm{atpg}^{A}\\\\/\\\\mathrm{atpg}^{A}$ & 0.295 & 6.10 $\\\\times$ 10$^{-18}$ \\\\\\\\\\n\\\\end{tabular}\\n\\n- $f_{\\\\text{reg}} = \\\\frac{1}{1 + \\\\exp[(\\\\Delta G_{ATP} - \\\\Delta G_{eq})/RT]}$, $R = 8.314$ J mol$^{-1}$ K$^{-1}$, $T=296.15$ K.\\n- $\\\\Delta G_{ATP} = -53.0$ kJ mol$^{-1}$ (ATP hydrolysis in vivo),\\n$\\\\Delta G_{eq} = -n F \\\\Delta p$, $F=96485$ C mol$^{-1}$.\\n\\n3. $\\\\textbf{Auxin Efflux (PIN3)}$:\\n- $V_{\\\\text{PIN}}=V_{\\\\text{PIN,max}}[1-\\\\exp(-\\\\lambda J_{\\\\text{ATP,cell}})]$\\n- $J_{\\\\text{ATP,cell}}=N_{\\\\text{mito}} \\\\cdot J_{\\\\text{ATP}}$\\n- $V_{\\\\text{PIN,max}}$ is set to $1.00$.\\n\\n\\\\begin{tabular}{lcc}\\nTIR1 Genotype & $\\\\lambda$ (mol$^{-1}$ ATP s cell) & $K_\\\\theta$ (\\\\textdegree) \\\\\\\\ \\\\hline\\n$\\\\mathrm{TIR1}^+\\\\/\\\\mathrm{TIR1}^+$ & $5.60\\\\times10^{14}$ & 60 \\\\\\\\\\n$\\\\mathrm{TIR1}^+\\\\/\\\\mathrm{TIR1}^{G}$ & $6.40\\\\times10^{14}$ & 95 \\\\\\\\\\n$\\\\mathrm{TIR1}^{G}\\\\/\\\\mathrm{TIR1}^{G}$ & $7.00\\\\times10^{14}$ & 130 \\\\\\\\\\n\\\\end{tabular}\\n\\n$\\\\lambda$ and $K_\\\\theta$ are independent of ATPG genotype (validated).\\n\\n4. $\\\\textbf{Root Curvature}$:\\n$\\\\theta=K_{\\\\theta}(V_{\\\\text{PIN,L}} - V_{\\\\text{PIN,U}})$\\n\\n5. $\\\\textbf{Mendelian Segregation with Linkage}$:\\nGiven both $F_1$ parents are $[$$\\\\mathrm{ATPG}^+$$\\\\,\\\\mathrm{TIR1}^+$$]$ $/$ $[$$\\\\mathrm{atpg}^A$$\\\\,\\\\mathrm{TIR1}^G$$]$ (cis), and recombination frequency of 18.0%, compute $F_2$ genotype frequencies for all nine two-locus classes:\\n\\\\[\\\\text{ATPG}^i/\\\\text{ATPG}^j;\\\\quad \\\\text{TIR1}^k/\\\\text{TIR1}^\\\\ell,\\\\quad (i,j,k,\\\\ell = +,\\\\ A\\\\ (for\\\\ ATPG),\\\\ +,\\\\ G\\\\ (for\\\\ TIR1))\\\\]\\n\\n--------------------------------\\n$\\\\textbf{Your Task}$:\\n\\nCalculate the $\\\\boxed{\\\\text{mean steady-state root curvature angle }(\\\\theta_K)\\\\ \\\\text{across the entire}~F_2~\\\\text{population (in degrees)}}$, integrating the predicted $\\\\theta$ for each genotype by its precise frequency as determined by the cross, model, and data above. Assume all other biochemistry and environmental variables as specified\u2014no other physiological modifiers are acting.\\n\\n$\\\\textbf{Provide only the final mean } \\\\theta_K \\\\text{ value (in degrees to two significant digits).}$\

A population of diploid yeast cells (\\u201cStrain A\\u201d) is cultured in a well-mixed 1.0 L chemostat at a steady-state temperature of 30$^\\\\circ$C. The chemostat is continuously supplied with sterile minimal media containing glucose at a fixed feed concentration ([Glc]$_f$ = 20.0 mM) and a dilution rate $D = 0.20\\\\ \\\\mathrm{h}^{-1}$. Strain A is engineered such that the only functional hexose transporter is Hxt7 (high-capacity, low-affinity), whose maximum velocity $V_{\\\\max}=600\\\\ \\\\mathrm{pmol\\\\ Glc\\\\ cell^{-1}\\\\ h^{-1}}$ and $K_M=5.0$ mM (Michaelis constant) are known. Each yeast cell has an average cytoplasmic volume of $50.0\\\\ \\\\mathrm{fL}$ ($1\\\\ \\\\mathrm{fL} = 10^{-15}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{L}$) and a total water fraction of 70\\\\%. The average cell mass is $6.0\\\\times10^{-11}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{g}$. Intracellular glucose is rapidly consumed for glycolysis; as a result, the steady-state intracellular glucose concentration is negligible compared to the extracellular value. Assume no catabolite repression or alternative uptake mechanisms. \\n\\nTo investigate adaptation, you introduce into the chemostat at $t=0$ a single diploid yeast cell (\\u201cStrain B\\u201d) that is identical to Strain A except for carrying a tandem gene amplification of HXT7, resulting in a 3-fold increase in $V_{\\\\max}$ (no change in $K_M$). Both strains grow at a maximal rate $\\\\mu_{max}=0.45\\\\ \\\\mathrm{h}^{-1}$, but are limited by glucose uptake according to Monod kinetics: $\\\\mu = \\\\mu_{max}\\\\dfrac{[\\\\mathrm{Glc}]_{ext}}{K_s + [\\\\mathrm{Glc}]_{ext}}$ where $K_s = 0.5$ mM.\\n\\nYou observe the chemostat population for 80 hours, during which time the dilution rate and all feed conditions are constant, and assume the total chemostat volume and cell density remain at steady-state (i.e., $\\\\mu = D$; for simplicity, neglect death, cell aggregation, or mutations aside from the original introduction of Strain B).\\n\\nThe following table gives the initial composition at $t=0$:\\n\\n\\\\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}\\n\\\\hline\\nStrain & Number of cells & Relative fitness\\\\,($W$) \\\\\\\\\\n\\\\hline\\nA & $\\\\mathbf{1.00 \\\\times 10^{10}}$ & $W_A=1.00$ \\\\\\\\\\nB & $1$ & $W_B=\\\\ ?$ \\\\\\\\\\n\\\\hline\\n\\\\end{tabular}\\n\\nThe relative fitness $W$ for each strain is calculated as the ratio of its realized growth rate (as limited by its glucose uptake according to $V_{max}$ and $K_M$) to the dilution rate $D$.\\n\\nAssume the following:\\n- Both strains compete solely for glucose and neither secretes inhibitory metabolites.\\n- There is no lag phase and both strains are equally competent in all respects except glucose uptake.\\n- Glucose is the sole limiting nutrient; steady-state [Glc]$_{ext}$ is set by chemostat equilibrium.\\n- The only change in Strain B is a 3-fold increase in $V_{max}$\\n\\n\\\\textbf{Question:}\\n\\nAfter 80 hours of chemostat culture, what is the total number of Strain B cells in the chemostat? Report your answer as a single integer (rounded down to the nearest whole cell).\

In a controlled experiment, primary human left ventricular cardiomyocytes are cultured in a serum-free, glucose-replete medium (5 mM glucose, 0.2 mM fatty acids, 20 mM HEPES, pH 7.4) under chronic, physiological hypoxia (O$_2$ tension: 1% atmospheric, equilibrated to 2.5 $\\\\times$ 10$^{-6}$ mol\u00b7L$^{-1}$ dissolved in mitochondrial matrix). These cells express two alleles of the cardiolipin synthase gene (official gene symbol: \\\\textbf{CLS1}), one wild-type (CLS1$^{\\\\text{WT}}$) and one heterozygous loss-of-function variant (CLS1$^{\\\\text{R279Q}}$). Cellular mitochondrial content constitutes 32\\\\% of total cell volume; the mean cell has a cytosolic volume of 1400~\\\\mu L and a mitochondrial matrix volume of 650~\\\\mu L. The following schematic summarizes regulatory events:\\n\\n\\\\begin{figure}[h!]\\n\\\\centering\\n\\\\begin{tikzpicture}[node distance=3.3cm, every node/.style={scale=0.92}]\\n  \\\\node (HIF) [draw, rectangle, fill=blue!10] {\\\\textbf{HIF-1$\\\\alpha$}};\\n  \\\\node (CLS1gene) [below of=HIF, yshift=-0.5cm] {\\\\textbf{CLS1 gene}};\\n  \\\\node (mRNA) [below of=CLS1gene, yshift=-0.6cm] {\\\\textbf{CLS1 mRNA}};\\n  \\\\node (protein) [below of=mRNA, yshift=-0.95cm] {\\\\textbf{CLS1 protein (WT or R279Q)}};\\n  \\\\node (PKA) [right of=protein, xshift=2.4cm] {\\\\textbf{Cytosolic PKA}};\\n  \\\\node (cAMP) [right of=PKA, xshift=2.25cm] {\\\\textbf{[cAMP]$_{\\\\text{cyt}}$}};\\n  \\\\node (LACT) [below of=protein, yshift=-1.35cm] {\\\\textbf{Mitochondrial [lactate]}};\\n  \\\\draw[->, thick] (HIF) -- (CLS1gene);\\n  \\\\draw[->, thick] (CLS1gene) -- (mRNA);\\n  \\\\draw[->, thick] (mRNA) -- (protein);\\n  \\\\draw[->, thick, densely dashdotted] (cAMP) -- (PKA) node[midway, above] {\\\\small activates};\\n  \\\\draw[->, thick, densely dashed] (PKA) -- (protein) node[midway, above] {\\\\small phos- \\\\newline phorylates WT only};\\n  \\\\draw[->, thick, dotted] (LACT) -- (protein) node[midway, right] {\\\\small competitive inhibitor};\\n\\\\end{tikzpicture}\\n\\\\caption*{Schematic: HIF-1$\\\\alpha$ stabilization upregulates \\\\textit{CLS1} (Cardiolipin Synthase 1) transcription; cAMP-activated PKA phosphorylates and partially inactivates only the WT isoform of CLS1. Mitochondrial matrix lactate acts as a competitive inhibitor of both enzyme isoforms.}\\n\\\\end{figure}\\n\\nAll experimental rates are specified per liter of mitochondrial matrix. Only two CLS1 isoforms are produced (from WT and R279Q alleles); both function as independent homodimers in the matrix, coupling no heterodimers. The cardiac-specific regulatory logic is:\\n\\\\begin{itemize}\\n  \\\\item Chronic hypoxia stabilizes HIF-1$\\\\alpha$, which transcriptionally upregulates \\\\textit{CLS1} mRNA via a known Hill function.\\n  \\\\item HIF-1$\\\\alpha$ is synthesized at constant rate $k_{\\\\text{syn,HIF}}$, and undergoes O$_2$-dependent first-order degradation: $v_{\\\\text{deg}} = k_{\\\\text{deg,max}} \\\\cdot [\\\\text{HIF}] \\\\cdot \\\\frac{[\\\\text{O}_2]}{K_{M,\\\\text{O}_2} + [\\\\text{O}_2]}$.\\n  \\\\item Both CLS1$^{\\\\text{WT}}$ and CLS1$^{\\\\text{R279Q}}$ are expressed at identical rates post-transcription, yielding equivalent steady-state mRNA and protein levels per allele.\\n  \\\\item PKA in the cytosol phosphorylates and partially inactivates only CLS1$^{\\\\text{WT}}$. Fraction of phosphorylated (inactive) CLS1$^{\\\\text{WT}}$ at steady state follows Michaelis-Menten kinetics: $f_{\\\\text{phos}} = \\\\frac{[\\\\text{cAMP}]}{K_{\\\\text{cAMP}} + [\\\\text{cAMP}]}$.\\n  \\\\item CLS1$^{\\\\text{R279Q}}$ is fully resistant to phosphorylation.\\n  \\\\item In the presence of mitochondrial matrix lactate, both isoforms display competitive inhibition, with $K_i$ provided per isoform.\\n\\\\end{itemize}\\n\\n\\\\textbf{Physicochemical and Biochemical Parameters:}\\n\\\\begin{table}[h!]\\n\\\\centering\\n\\\\renewcommand{\\\\arraystretch}{1.14}\\n\\\\begin{tabular}{|c|l|c|}\\n\\\\hline\\n\\\\textbf{Parameter} & \\\\textbf{Description} & \\\\textbf{Value} \\\\\\\\\\n\\\\hline\\n$[\\\\text{O}_2]_{\\\\text{matrix}}$  & Mitochondrial matrix O$_2$ conc. & $2.5 \\\\times 10^{-6}$~mol\u00b7L$^{-1}$ \\\\\\\\\\n$K_{M,\\\\text{O}_2}$      & Michaelis const., O$_2$ in HIF-1$\\\\alpha$ degradation  & $5.0 \\\\times 10^{-6}$~mol\u00b7L$^{-1}$ \\\\\\\\\\n$k_{\\\\text{syn,HIF}}$    &  HIF-1$\\\\alpha$ synthesis rate   & $1.2 \\\\times 10^{-12}$~mol\u00b7L$^{-1}$\u00b7s$^{-1}$ \\\\\\\\\\n$k_{\\\\text{deg,max}}$    &  Max HIF-1$\\\\alpha$ degradation rate const. & $2.4 \\\\times 10^{-3}$~s$^{-1}$ \\\\\\\\\\n$K_d$        & $\\\\text{HIF-1}\\\\alpha$ dissociation for CLS1 promoter & $2.0 \\\\times 10^{-9}$~mol\u00b7L$^{-1}$ \\\\\\\\\\n$k_{\\\\text{syn,mRNA}}$   & Max. rate of CLS1 mRNA synthesis & $5.0 \\\\times & $3.0$~h \\\\\\\\\\n$k_{\\\\text{transl}}$     & Translation rate const., per mRNA & $1.0 \\\\times 10^{-2}$~s$^{-1}$ \\\\\\\\\\n$t_{1/2,\\\\text{prot}}$   & CLS1 protein half-life (both forms)& CLS1$^{\\\\text{WT}}$ & $1.0 \\\\times 10^{-4}$~mol\u00b7L$^{-1}$ \\\\\\\\\\n$K_{M,\\\\text{S,R279Q}}$  & Substrate Michaelis const., CLS1$^{\\\\text{R279Q}}$ & $4.0 \\\\times \\\\\\\\\\n$k_{cat,\\\\text{R279Q}}$  & Turnover number, CLS1$^{\\\\text{R279Q}}$  & $1.5$~s$^{-1}$ \\\\\\\\\\n\\\\hline\\n$\\\\ln(2)$                &   & $0.693$
