Use the full competitive inhibition Michaelis-Menten equation per isoform:\\n\\n\\\\[ v = E_{\\\\text{active}} \\\\cdot k_{\\\\text{cat}} \\\\cdot \\\\frac{[S]}{K_M (1 + [\\\\text{Lactate}]/K_i) + [S]} \\\\]\\n\\nwhere $E_{\\\\text{active}}$ is the molar concentration of catalytically active enzyme (for CLS1$^{\\\\text{WT}}$, only the unphosphorylated fraction is active).\\n\\nReport your \\\\textbf{final answer as the total steady-state rate of cardiolipin synthesis (fmol\u00b7s$^{-1}$) produced by 1$\\\\times$10$^{6}$ cells}, expressing your result to three significant figures.\\n\\n\\\\textit{You may use Avogadro's number $N_A = 6.022 \\\\times 10^{23}$~mol$^{-1}$ throughout.}\

A human corticospinal motor neuron, cultured in vitro at 37~^\\\\circ\\\\mathrm{C} and physiological pH 7.4, is modeled as a uniform, unmyelinated cylinder of length $L = 50{,}000~\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{m}$ ($50~\\\\mathrm{mm}$), with diameter $d = 1.0~\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{m}$. The axonal cytosolic environment is isotonic and all kinetic parameters given are valid at the supplied temperature and pH.\\n\\nThe axon is derived from a MELAS (Mitochondrial Encephalomyopathy, Lactic Acidosis, and Stroke-like Episodes) patient and contains a fixed mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) A3243G point mutation with **uniform heteroplasmy** fraction $f_{\\\\mathrm{MT}} = 0.85$ (i.e., $85\\\\%$ mutant mtDNA, constant along the axon; assume negligible axonal transport and no mitophagy during the experiment). All mitochondria are stationary within the axon.\\n\\n**ATP Kinetics (Reaction-Diffusion Model)**\\n\\nLet $C(x)$ (in $\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{M}$) denote the steady-state ATP concentration at position $x$ ($0 \\\\leq x \\\\leq L$). The axon is governed by:\\n\\n\\\\[\\n\\\\underbrace{D_{\\\\mathrm{ATP}} \\\\frac{d^2C}{dx^2}}_{\\\\text{diffusion (per length)}} = \\\\underbrace{J_{\\\\mathrm{prod}}(x)}_{\\\\text{production, per length}} - \\\\underbrace{J_{\\\\mathrm{cons}}(C, f_{\\\\mathrm{AP}})}_{\\\\text{consumption, per length}}\\n\\\\]\\n\\nwhere:\\n\\n- $D_{\\\\mathrm{ATP}} = 300~\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{m}^2/\\\\mathrm{s}$ is the ATP diffusion constant in axoplasm.\\n- The axonal **cross-sectional area** is $A = \\\\pi (\\\\tfrac{d}{2})^2$ in $\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{m}^2$.\\n\\n**Boundary conditions:**\\n- At $x=0$ (soma): fixed $C(0) = 2500~\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{M}$.\\n- At $x=L$ (axon terminal): $C(L)$ \\\\\\\\textbf{must equal the required threshold for synaptic vesicle recycling}, $C_{\\\\mathrm{crit}} = 500~\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{M}$ (i.e., Dirichlet boundary condition).\\n\\n**ATP Production**\\n- All production is mitochondrial, distributed **per unit volume** proportional to $\\\\rho(x) = \\\\rho_0 e^{-\\\\lambda x}$ (mitochondria per $\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{m}^{3}$).\\n- $\\\\rho_0 = 5.0~\\\\mathrm{mitochondria}/\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{m}^3$ (proximal density)\\n- $\\\\lambda = 5 \\\\times 10^{-5}~\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{m}^{-1}$\\n- Each mitochondrion produces ATP at $P_{\\\\textrm{WT}} = 5.0 \\\\times 10^3~\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{M}\\\\cdot\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{m}^3/\\\\mathrm{s}$ (wild-type) or $P_{\\\\textrm{MT}} = 1.0 \\\\times 10^3~\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{M}\\\\cdot\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{m}^3/\\\\mathrm{s}$ (mutant).\\n- Production capacity is defined as: **number of micromoles of ATP synthesized per second by a single mitochondrion, normalized to one $\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{m}^3$ cytosolic volume**.\\n- Thus, at position $x$:\\n\\\\[\\nJ_{\\\\mathrm{prod}}(x) = A \\\\cdot \\\\rho(x)~[ (1-f_{\\\\mathrm{MT}}) P_{\\\\mathrm{WT}} + f_{\\\\mathrm{MT}} P_{\\\\mathrm{MT}} ]~\\\\mathrm{(in~} \\\\mu\\\\mathrm{M}~\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{m}/\\\\mathrm{s})\\n\\\\]\\n\\n**ATP Consumption**\\nThere are two components, both **per unit length**:\\n\\n- **Basal consumption** (Michaelis-Menten, per length):\\n\\\\[\\nJ_{\\\\textrm{basal}}(C) = A \\\\cdot V_{\\\\max,\\\\mathrm{basal}} \\\\frac{C}{K_{m,\\\\mathrm{basal}}+C}\\n\\\\]\\nWith $V_{\\\\max,\\\\mathrm{basal}} = 200~\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{M}/\\\\mathrm{s}$, $K_{m,\\\\mathrm{basal}} = 100~\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{M}$.\\n_Note_: At $C \\\\gg K_m$, basal flux saturates.\\n\\n- **Activity-dependent** (all Na$^+$/K$^+$-ATPase cost is membrane surface-confined):\\nLet firing frequency be $f_{\\\\rm{AP}}$ (in $\\\\mathrm{Hz}$). The **consumption per length** is\\n\\\\[\\nJ_{\\\\mathrm{AP}}(f_{\\\\mathrm{AP}}) = S \\\\times k_{\\\\mathrm{AP}} \\\\times f_{\\\\mathrm{AP}}\\n\\\\]\\nwhere:\\n  - $S = \\\\pi d$ is the surface area per $\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{m}$ of axon ($\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{m}^2/\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{m}$).\\n  - $k_{\\\\mathrm{AP}} = 2.5 \\\\times 10^{-3}~\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{M}~\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{m}^{-2}$ per action potential per $\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{m}^2$ of membrane.\\n  - This cost is **uniform and local** all along the axon (due to distributed APs).\\n\\nSo,\\n\\\\[\\nJ_{\\\\mathrm{cons}}(C, f_{\\\\rm{AP}}) = J_{\\\\textrm{basal}}(C) + J_{\\\\mathrm{AP}}(f_{\\\\mathrm{AP}})\\n\\\\]\\n\\n\\\\vspace{1em}\\n\\n**Table~1: Summary of Key Parameters**\\n\\n\\\\begin{tabular}{ l | l | l }\\nParameter & Symbol & Value \\\\\\\\\\n\\\\hline\\nAxon Length & $L$ & $50{,}000~\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{m}$ \\\\\\\\\\nDiameter & $d$ & $1.0~\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{m}$ \\\\\\\\\\nATP Diffusion & $D_{\\\\mathrm{ATP}}$ & $300~\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{m}^2/\\\\mathrm{s}$ \\\\\\\\\\nProx. Mito Density & $\\\\rho_0$ & $5.0~\\\\mathrm{mito}/\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{m}^{3}$ \\\\\\\\\\nDecay rate & $\\\\lambda$ & $5\\\\times10^{-5}~\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{m}^{-1}$ \\\\\\\\\\nWild-type ATP prod. & $P_{\\\\textrm{WT}}$ & $5.0\\\\times10^3~\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{M}\\\\cdot\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{m}^3/\\\\mathrm{s}$ \\\\\\\\\\nMutant ATP prod. & $P_{\\\\textrm{MT}}$ & $1.0\\\\times10^3~\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{M}\\\\cdot\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{m}^3/\\\\mathrm{s}$ \\\\\\\\\\nHeteroplasmy & $f_{\\\\mathrm{MT}}$ & $0.85$ \\\\\\\\\\nBasal Vmax & $V_{\\\\max,\\\\mathrm{basal}}$ & $200~\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{M}/\\\\mathrm{s}$ \\\\\\\\\\nBasal $K_m$ & $K_{m,\\\\mathrm{basal}}$ & $100~\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{M}$ \\\\\\\\\\nAP cost/area & $k_{\\\\mathrm{AP}}$ & $2.5\\\\times10^{-3}~\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{M}~\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{m}^{-2}$ per AP \\\\\\\\\\nTemperature/pH & -- & $37~^\\\\circ\\\\mathrm{C}$, pH~7.4 \\\\\\\\\\n\\\\end{tabular}\\n\\n\\\\vspace{1em}\\n\\n**Problem:**\\n\\nCalculate the \\\\textbf{maximum steady firing frequency} $f_{\\\\mathrm{AP},\\\\max}$ (in Hz, to two decimal places) such that, at steady state, the ATP concentration at the terminal ($x=L$) is precisely $C_{\\\\mathrm{crit}}=500~\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{M}$. Assume the Michaelis-Menten term is saturated ($C \\\\gg K_m$ everywhere except near $x= L$), and all boundary/biochemical conditions above. (Hint: The reaction-diffusion ODE is per unit length, with explicit geometric factors, and the consumption and production terms are each expressed in $\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{M}~\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{m}/\\\\mathrm{s}$ along the axon.) Show all calculations.\

A 600.0\\\\,\\\\mathrm{L} atmospherically sealed laboratory microcosm (held at 298.15\\\\,\\\\mathrm{K} and 1.00\\\\,\\\\mathrm{atm}) is established to investigate drought effects on plant-herbivore interaction and plant gas exchange. Two plant species are grown in equal-sized soil trays (total soil volume 10.0\\\\,\\\\mathrm{L} per species): (1) \\\\textit{Arabidopsis thaliana} (a C$_3$ annual), and (2) \\\\textit{Kalanchoe fedtschenkoi} (a CAM succulent). Each tray contains 40.0\\\\,\\\\mathrm{g} leaf dry mass. Both populations are mature and maintained at constant leaf biomass via manual pruning and replenishment.\\n\\nAfter full establishment, a stable population of genetically engineered \\\\textit{Manduca sexta} caterpillars is introduced. The caterpillars carry the codominant locus \\\\textit{ToxR} (genotypes: AA, AK, KK), determining host-specific toxin metabolism and feeding preference. All larvae are synchronized at the penultimate (fifth) instar with average fresh mass 2.0\\\\,\\\\mathrm{g} (dry mass 0.4\\\\,\\\\mathrm{g}) and display the following properties:\\n\\\\begin{itemize}\\n  \\\\item Total larval population: $N_{herb} = 300$ (stable; no reproduction during experiment).\\n  \\\\item Genotype frequencies: $f_{AA} = 0.40$, $f_{AK} = 0.35$, $f_{KK} = 0.25$.\\n  \\\\item Each larva consumes 0.5\\\\,\\\\mathrm{g} (dry mass) of leaf tissue per hour distributed strictly according to its genotype preference:\\n    \\\\begin{table}[h!]\\n      \\\\centering\\n      \\\\begin{tabular}{lcc}\\n        \\\\toprule\\n        Genotype & Feeds on & Proportion Consumed from Each Host \\\\\\\\\\n        \\\\midrule\\n        AA     & \\\\textit{A. thaliana}         & 100\\\\% \\\\\\\\\\n        KK     & \\\\textit{K. fedtschenkoi}      & 100\\\\% \\\\\\\\\\n        AK     & Both (biomass proportional)  & $=$ 0.5 from each plant \\\\\\\\\\n        \\\\bottomrule\\n      \\\\end{tabular}\\n    \\\\end{table}\\n  \\\\item Larval respiration rate per individual: $R_{basal} = 0.6$\\\\,$\\\\mu$mol CO$_2$\\\\,hr$^{-1}$ at rest, plus 0.15\\\\,$\\\\mu$mol CO$_2$\\\\,hr$^{-1}$ per $\\\\mu$mol toxin detoxified (see below).\\n\\\\end{itemize}\\n\\nAfter acclimation, plants are subjected to chronic drought ($\\\\Psi_{soil} = -1.80$\\\\,MPa) for 48 hours, driving foliar ABA accumulation and induction of: (i) glucosinolates (GSL) in \\\\textit{Arabidopsis}; (ii) bufadienolides (BDL) in \\\\textit{Kalanchoe}. At this post-drought steady-state:\\n\\n\\\\begin{itemize}\\n  \\\\item Steady-state leaf abscisic acid content: $[\\\\mathrm{ABA}]$ (in $\\\\mu$M) in both plants: $[ABA] = 10.0 \\\\cdot (1 - e^{1.2\\\\Psi_{soil}})$.\\n  \\\\item $[GSL]$ (in $\\\\mu$mol toxin\\\\,g$^{-1}$ leaf) in \\\\textit{Arabidopsis}: $[GSL] = 0.6 \\\\cdot [ABA]$\\n  \\\\item $[BDL]$ (in $\\\\mu$mol toxin\\\\,g$^{-1}$ leaf) in \\\\textit{Kalanchoe}: $[BDL] = 0.4 \\\\cdot {([ABA])}^2$\\n\\\\end{itemize}\\n\\nDetoxification enzyme kinetics for each genotype during leaf consumption (assume tissue toxin content equals ingested toxin):\\n\\\\begin{itemize}\\n  \\\\item Homozygotes (AA and KK): $V_{max} = 12.0$\\\\,$\\\\mu$mol toxin detoxified\\\\,g$^{-1}$ larval dry mass\\\\,hr$^{-1}$\\n  \\\\item Heterozygote (AK): Both enzyme variants functional. For each toxin: $V_{max,AK} = 0.7\\\\,V_{max}$, $K_m$ same as corresponding homozygote.\\n  \\\\item Michaelis constants: $K_{m,A} = 5.0$\\\\,$\\\\mu$mol\\\\,g$^{-1}$ (GSL); $K_{m,K} = 2.5$\\\\,$\\\\mu$mol\\\\,g$^{-1}$ (BDL).\\n  \\\\item Detoxification rate (for each toxin): $V_{detox} = \\\\dfrac{V_{max}\\\\ [Toxin]}{K_m + [Toxin]}$\\n\\\\end{itemize}\\n\\nPlant net CO$_2$ assimilation (exclusive of respiration; no plant or soil microbial respiration occurs):\\n\\\\begin{itemize}\\n  \\\\item For each plant: $P_{net}$ (\\\\,$\\\\mu$mol CO$_2$\\\\,g$^{-1}$ leaf\\\\,hr$^{-1}$) $= P_{max} \\\\cdot e^{0.7\\\\Psi_{soil}}$\\n  \\\\item $P_{max,Arabidopsis} = 35.0$\\\\,$\\\\mu$mol CO$_2$\\\\,g$^{-1}$\\\\,hr$^{-1}$\\n  \\\\item $P_{max,Kalanchoe} = 13.0$\\\\,$\\\\mu$mol CO$_2$\\\\,g$^{-1}$\\\\,hr$^{-1}$ (assume measurements during daytime, when CAM fixation rate is 60\\\\% of maximal value)\\n\\\\end{itemize}\\n\\n\\\\textbf{Question:} What is the net rate of change of atmospheric CO$_2$ concentration in the microcosm (in parts per million per hour, ppm\\\\,hr$^{-1}$) \\\\emph{immediately after} equilibrium is reached under the above drought conditions? Assume all values (ingestion, detoxification, respiration, photosynthesis) are constant at this time; ignore CO$_2$ exchange with soil or experimental apparatus. Use the atmospheric conversion: $1$\\\\,ppm CO$_2$ $= 24.6$\\\\,$\\\\mu$mol CO$_2$ in $600$\\\\,L at $298.15$\\\\,K and $1$\\\\,atm. Present all necessary calculations, but your \\\\textbf{final answer} should be \\\\textbf{only} the net CO$_2$ change rate in ppm\\\\,hr$^{-1}$.\\n\\n\\\\begin{table}[h!]\\n  \\\\centering\\n  \\\\caption{Summary of Genotype Properties and Feeding Preferences}\\n  \\\\begin{tabular}{lccc}\\n    \\\\toprule\\n    Genotype & Population & Feeding Source(s) & $V_{max}$ per pathway (\\\\,$\\\\mu$mol\\\\,g$^{-1}$\\\\,hr$^{-1}$) \\\\\\\\\\n    \\\\midrule\\n    AA & 120 & \\\\textit{Arabidopsis} (100\\\\%) & 12.0 (GSL only) \\\\\\\\\\n    AK & 105 & Both (50\\\\% each) & 8.4 (GSL), 8.4 (BDL) \\\\\\\\\\n    KK & 75 & \\\\textit{Kalanchoe} (100\\\\%) & 12.0 (BDL only) \\\\\\\\\\n    \\\\bottomrule\\n  \\\\end{tabular}\\n\\\\end{table}\

An experiment investigates the transcriptional and physiological consequences of elevated H3K27me3 deposition at the \\\\\\\\textit{YUCCA6} locus during thermomemory and gravitropism in the model plant \\\\\\\\textit{Arabidopsis thaliana}.\\n\\n\\\\\\\\textbf{Biological context:} In the wild-type (WT), the histone demethylase JMJ30 is required for resetting repressive methylation (H3K27me3) at heat-inducible gene loci. In the \\\\\\\\textbf{\\textit{jmj30-1}} loss-of-function mutant (genotype: \\\\\\\\textit{jmj30-1/jmj30-1}), H3K27me3 accumulates. YUCCA6 (\\textrm{YUC6}) encodes a key root-localized enzyme for auxin (IAA) biosynthesis, crucial for gravitropic bending through differential cell elongation in epidermal cell files of the root elongation zone.\\n\\n\\\\\\\\textbf{Experimental protocol:}\\n\\\\\\\\begin{itemize}\\n  \\\\item Seedlings are grown vertically for 5 days on 1\\\\\\\\% agar MS plates at 22\\,^\\\\\\\\circ\\\\mathrm{C}, 60\\\\\\\\% RH, 80 \\\\\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{mol}~m^{-2}~s^{-1} light.\\n  \\\\item A heat-stress memory regimen is applied: \\\\\\\\textbf{1 h} @ 38\\,^\\\\\\\\circ\\\\mathrm{C}; \\\\\\\\textbf{48 h} recovery @ 22\\,^\\\\\\\\circ\\\\mathrm{C}; \\\\\\\\textbf{2 h triggering} @ 43\\,^\\\\\\\\circ\\\\mathrm{C} (in 98\\\\\\\\% RH; non-lethal, see Supplementary Table S1 for tissue viability rates).\\n  \\\\item Immediately post-trigger, roots are re-oriented 90\\,^\\\\\\\\circ, and gravistimulated in darkness at 22\\,^\\\\\\\\circ\\\\mathrm{C} and high humidity for \\\\\\\\textbf{6.0 h}.\\n\\\\\\\\end{itemize}\\n\\n\\\\\\\\textbf{Epigenetic data:}\\n- WT \\\\\\\\textit{YUCCA6} locus: mean H3K27me3 density (\\\\\\\\rho_{me3,WT}) = 0.30 mark\u00b7nucleosome^{-1}\\n- \\\\\\\\textit{jmj30-1} mutant: \\\\\\\\rho_{me3,KO} = 1.05 mark\u00b7nucleosome^{-1}\\n- The dissociation constant for HSFA1a binding at the \\\\\\\\textit{YUCCA6} promoter's heat shock element is given by: \\\\\\\\[\\nK_d = K_{d,0} \\\\, e^{\\\\\\\\gamma (\\\\\\\\rho_{me3} - \\\\\\\\rho_{me3,WT})}\\n\\\\\\\\]\\nwhere K_{d,0} = 2.0 \\\\\\\\times 10^{-9}~\\\\mathrm{M} (WT, unmarked); \\\\\\\\gamma = 2.0 (unitless).\\n- During the 2 h post-trigger, the nuclear active HSFA1a concentration [HSFA1a]_nuc = 3.0 \\\\\\\\times 10^{-8}~\\\\mathrm{M} in both genotypes.\\n\\n\\\\\\\\textbf{Transcriptional regime:}\\n- At the \\\\\\\\textit{YUCCA6} locus, let [mRNA]_ss = \\\\\\\\Omega \\\\\\\\cdot ( [HSFA1a]_nuc / ( K_d + [HSFA1a]_nuc ) ),\\n- \\\\\\\\Omega (max mRNA, per effective nucleus) = 45 molecules/nucleus; root epidermal cell nucleus mean volume = 150~\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{m}^3 (conversion: 1~\\\\mathrm{M} = 6.02 \\\\times 10^{23}~\\\\mathrm{molecules}/\\\\mathrm{L}).\\n- Translation factor \\\\\\\\beta = 1600~\\\\mathrm{enzyme~monomer~molecule} / \\\\mathrm{mRNA~molecule}.\\n- YUCCA6 acts as dimer; [YUCCA6]_enz in Molar units = (number dimers per cell) / (nuclear volume [L] \\\\\\\\times 6.02 \\\\times 10^{23} ).\\n\\n\\\\\\\\textbf{Auxin (IAA) biosynthetic regime:}\\n- Substrate [IPA]_cell = 1.0 \\\\\\\\times 10^{-4}~\\\\mathrm{M} (continuous feeding; saturating).\\n- Michaelis-Menten parameters: K_m = 6.0 \\\\\\\\times 10^{-6}~\\\\mathrm{M}; k_{cat} = 0.35~\\\\mathrm{s}^{-1}. Each dimer converts 1 IPA to 1 IAA per k_cat.\\n- Non-YUCCA6 IAA synthesis is present at J_{syn,aux} = 2.0 \\\\\\\\times 10^{-10}~\\\\mathrm{M\\\\cdot s}^{-1} per cell.\\n- IAA degradation in zone cells: first-order, k_{deg} = 0.10~\\\\mathrm{s}^{-1}.\\n- Assume all root elongation zone epidermal cell files respond identically (N_{cell,zone} = 2000 rows).\\n\\n\\\\\\\\textbf{Post-gravistimulation auxin partitioning and growth:}\\n- Effective [IAA]_{mean} is spatial mean in elongation zone epidermal cells (see above).\\n- After 90^\\circ reorientation: [IAA]_{lower} = 1.3 \\\\\\\\times [IAA]_{mean}; [IAA]_{upper} = 0.5 \\\\\\\\times [IAA]_{mean} (occupation per cell row).\\n- Epidermal cell elongation rate: \\\\\\\\[\\nv_{el} = v_{max} / \\\\left( 1 + \\\\left( [IAA]_{local} / K_i \\\\right )^{2.2} \\\\right)\\n\\\\\\\\]\\nwhere v_{max} = 1.0 \\\\\\\\times 10^{-7}~\\\\mathrm{m\\\\cdot s}^{-1}; K_i = 2.0 \\\\\\\\times 10^{-7}~\\\\mathrm{M}.\\n- Root effective diameter at elongation zone: d_{root} = 1.1 \\\\\\\\times 10^{-4}~\\\\mathrm{m}.\\n- Instantaneous d\\\\theta/dt = (v_{el,upper} - v_{el,lower}) / d_{root}.\\n- Curvature proceeds linearly until a biomechanical maximum of \\\\\\\\theta_{max} = 100^\\circ (i.e., even if calculated angle exceeds, final bending is capped at 100^\\circ).\\n- The A closed population of insular deer (\\\\textit{Cervus insulae}) has been experimentally engineered to express a homozygous gain-of-function allele \\\\textit{mem}\\\\textsuperscript{+} in the GluN2B subunit of the hippocampal CA1 pyramidal neuron NMDA receptor. This allele increases the mean time each receptor channel spends open upon synaptic activation, enhancing memory capacity but increasing neuronal calcium (Ca\\\\textsuperscript{2+}) influx and, correspondingly, hippocampal energy cost. \\n\\nA. \\\\textbf{Neurobiological Details:}\\n\\nAll CA1 neurons are isopotential, each with a soma membrane area of $A_\\\\mathrm{mem} = 2100\\\\ \\\\mu\\\\mathrm{m}^2$ evenly divided among $N_\\\\mathrm{syn} = 30{,}000$ glutamatergic synapses per neuron. Each synapse contains $N_\\\\mathrm{NMDAR} = 5$ GluN2B NMDA receptor channels, all with an individual channel permeability $P_\\\\mathrm{Ca} = 6.0\\\\times10^{-17}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{m}^3\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{s}^{-1}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{V}^{-1}$, and each channel occupies $a_\\\\mathrm{ch} = 20\\\\ \\\\mathrm{nm}^2$ of membrane. \\n\\nFor each synaptic event, an NMDAR channel opens with probability $p_\\\\mathrm{open} = 0.35$, and the mean open time is $\\\\tau_\\\\mathrm{open,mem^{+}} = 150.0\\\\ \\\\mathrm{ms}$. Synaptic drive is a stationary Poisson process with mean activation frequency $\\\\nu_\\\\mathrm{syn} = 4.0\\\\ \\\\mathrm{Hz}$ per synapse. \\n\\nDuring channel open state, the membrane potential is voltage clamped at $V_\\\\mathrm{m,open} = -20.0\\\\ \\\\mathrm{mV}$; in all other periods, channels are closed and negligible calcium influx occurs. The extracellular and intracellular Ca\\\\textsuperscript{2+} concentrations are $[\\\\mathrm{Ca}^{2+}]_\\\\mathrm{out} = 2.0\\\\ \\\\mathrm{mol}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{m}^{-3}$ and $[\\\\mathrm{Ca}^{2+}]_\\\\mathrm{in} = 5.0\\\\times10^{-5}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{mol}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{m}^{-3}$ respectively. \\n\\nThe Goldman-Hodgkin-Katz equation for a single channel's Ca\\\\textsuperscript{2+} current is:\\n\\\\begin{equation*}\\nI_{\\\\mathrm{Ca}} = z^2 F^2 \\\\frac{A_\\\\mathrm{ch} P_\\\\mathrm{Ca} V_\\\\mathrm{m}}{R T} \\\\frac{[\\\\mathrm{Ca}^{2+}]_\\\\mathrm{in} - [\\\\mathrm{Ca}^{2+}]_\\\\mathrm{out} \\\\exp\\\\left(-\\\\frac{z F V_\\\\mathrm{m}}{R T}\\\\right)}{1-\\\\exp\\\\left(-\\\\frac{z F V_\\\\mathrm{m}}{R T}\\\\right)}\\n\\\\end{equation*}\\nwhere $z = 2$, $F = 96\\\\,485\\\\ \\\\mathrm{C}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{mol}^{-1}$, $R = 8.314\\\\ \\\\mathrm{J}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{mol}^{-1}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{K}^{-1}$, temperature $T = 310\\\\ \\\\mathrm{K}$, and $M_\\\\mathrm{Ca} = 40.078\\\\ \\\\mathrm{g}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{mol}^{-1}$. Assume all ions entering through these channels are retained in the cytosol (buffering/extrusion compensation is ignored; see note). \\n\\nB. \\\\textbf{Population Details:}\\n\\nThe deer population is at carrying capacity $N_\\\\mathrm{deer} = 50\\\\,000$, each with $N_\\\\mathrm{CA1} = 5.0\\\\times 10^6$ CA1 pyramidal neurons. \\n\\nC. \\\\textbf{Experimental Context:} No other sources of calcium influx are present except the NMDAR channels described. All neurons remain healthy for exactly one sidereal year ($t_\\\\mathrm{year} = 3.156\\\\times10^{7}\\\\ \\\\mathrm{s}$). Note: You may assume that overlap of synaptic events or channel-open events is negligible, so total Ca\\\\textsuperscript{2+} charge influx sums linearly over channels, neurons, and deer for the time interval.  \\n\\n\\\\textbf{Table 1. Relevant Constants and Parameters}\\n\\\\begin{table}[h]\\n\\\\begin{tabular}{l l l}\\nParameter & Value & Units \\\\\\\\\\n\\\\hline\\n$A_\\\\mathrm{mem}$ & $2100$ & $\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{m}^2$ per neuron \\\\\\\\\\n$N_\\\\mathrm{syn}$ & $3.0\\\\times10^4$ & synapses per neuron \\\\\\\\\\n$N_\\\\mathrm{NMDAR}$ & $5$ & channels per synapse \\\\\\\\\\n$a_\\\\mathrm{ch}$ & $20$ & $\\\\mathrm{nm}^2$ per channel \\\\\\\\\\n$P_\\\\mathrm{Ca}$ & $6.0\\\\times10^{-17}$ & $\\\\mathrm{m}^3\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{s}^{-1}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{V}^{-1}$ \\\\\\\\\\n$V_\\\\mathrm{m,open}$ & $-20.0$ & mV \\\\\\\\\\n$T$ & $310$ & K \\\\\\\\\\n$F$ & $96\\\\,485$ & $\\\\mathrm{C}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{mol}^{-1}$ \\\\\\\\\\n$R$ & $8.314$ & $\\\\mathrm{J}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{mol}^{-1}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{K}^{-1}$ \\\\\\\\\\n$z$ & $2$ & unitless \\\\\\\\\\n$[\\\\mathrm{Ca}^{2+}]_\\\\mathrm{out}$ & $2.0$ & $\\\\mathrm{mol}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{m}^{-3}$ \\\\\\\\\\n$[\\\\mathrm{Ca}^{2+}]_\\\\mathrm{in}$ & $5\\\\times10^{-5}$ & $\\\\mathrm{mol}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{m}^{-3}$ \\\\\\\\\\n$N_\\\\mathrm{CA1}$ & $5.0\\\\times10^6$ & neurons per deer \\\\\\\\\\n$N_\\\\mathrm{deer}$ & $5.0\\\\times10^4$ & deer \\\\\\\\\\n$t_\\\\mathrm{year}$ & $3.156\\\\times10^7$ & s \\\\\\\\\\n$M_\\\\mathrm{Ca}$ & $40.078$ & $\\\\mathrm{g}\\\\cdot\\\\mathrm{mol}^{-1}$ \\\\\\\\\\n$p_\\\\mathrm{open}$ & $0.35$ & unitless \\\\\\\\\\n$\\\\tau_\\\\mathrm{open,mem^{+}}$ & $0.150$ & s \\\\\\\\\\n$\\\\nu_\\\\mathrm{syn}$ & $4.0$ & Hz \\\\\\\\\\n\\\\end{tabular}\\n\\\\end{table}\\n\\n\\\\textbf{Question:}\\n\\n\\\\emph{Calculate the total mass (in milligrams, mg) of Ca\\\\textsuperscript{2+} ions that enter the entire population of CA1 pyramidal neurons (across all deer on the island) through NMDAR channels over exactly one sidereal year. Express your answer with three significant digits.}\\n\\n\\\\textbf{Note:} Assume Ca\\\\textsuperscript{2+} influx is strictly limited to the open time of NMDAR channels as described. Ignore calcium buffering, extrusion, and any other sources or sinks.\

A neurophysiologist is studying energy-dependent synaptic vesicle release at the calyx of Held in a wild-type C57BL/6J mouse at 37\u00b0C under moderate, physiologically relevant hypoxia (7% O\u2082, 93% N\u2082; arterial pO\u2082 ~50 mmHg), perfused with oxygenated artificial cerebrospinal fluid (aCSF). The nerve terminal has a spherical geometry with volume $V_{term} = 4.00~\\\\mathrm{pL}$. \\\\newline\\n\\n#### Experimental Protocol:\\nA 250 Hz stimulus train is delivered to the afferent fiber for 120 ms. Each action potential causes synchronous fusion of vesicles from the readily releasable pool (RRP). Vesicle pool replenishment from the reserve pool is negligible during this interval.\\\\newline\\n\\n#### System Data and Parameters:\\n- **Readily Releasable Pool (RRP):**\\n    - Maximum RRP size: $N_{\\\\mathrm{RRP,max}} = 1500$ vesicles\\n    - Steady-state RRP size is reduced under hypoxia according to:\\n      $$N_{\\\\mathrm{RRP}} = N_{\\\\mathrm{RRP,max}} \\\\times \\\\left[1 - 0.20 \\\\left(1 - \\\\frac{[\\\\mathrm{ATP}]_{ss}}{[\\\\mathrm{ATP}]_{norm}}\\\\right) \\\\right]$$\\n    - Each vesicle in the RRP has a fixed probability of release ($p_r$) for each action potential: $p_r = 0.36$\\n- **ATP Dynamics:**\\n    - At steady state (before stimulation), terminal ATP concentration: $[\\\\mathrm{ATP}]_{ss}$\\n    - Normoxic ATP concentration: $[\\\\mathrm{ATP}]_{norm} = 2.8~\\\\mathrm{mM}$\\n    - Hypoxic ATP concentration: $[\\\\mathrm{ATP}]_{ss} = [\\\\mathrm{ATP}]_{norm} - \\\\Delta[\\\\mathrm{ATP}]$\\n    - $\\\\Delta[\\\\mathrm{ATP}]$ is determined by the balance of ATP synthesis vs. hydrolysis (see below).\\n- **ATP Synthesis & Consumption:**\\n    - Mitochondria: $N_{\\\\mathrm{mito}} = 1300$ mitochondria/terminal\\n    - Terminal mitochondrial volume fraction: $f_{mito} = 0.13$\\n    - \\n      Glycolytic ATP synthesis: $J_{gly} = 2.1 \\\\times 10^{-18}~\\\\mathrm{mol} \\\\cdot \\\\mathrm{s}^{-1}$ (constant)\\n    - \\n      Oxidative ATP synthesis: $J_{mito} = f_{O_2,cap} \\\\cdot J_{mito,max}$\\n    - \\n        $f_{O_2,cap} = 0.83$ (fractional cap due to hypoxia)\\n    - \\n        $J_{mito,max}$ is computed as:\\n        $$J_{mito,max} = N_{\\\\mathrm{mito}} \\\\cdot V_{mito,avg} \\\\cdot k_{cat,CII} \\\\cdot [\\\\mathrm{succinate}]_{mito} \\\\cdot \\\\left(\\\\frac{[\\\\mathrm{O}_2]}{K_{m,O_2} + [\\\\mathrm{O}_2]}\\\\right) \\\\cdot \\\\mathrm{P/O}_{succ}$$\\n        Where:\\n        \\n        - $V_{mito,avg} = 0.40~\\\\mathrm{pL}/N_{\\\\mathrm{mito}}$\\n        - $k_{cat,CII} = 80.0~\\\\mathrm{s}^{-1}$\\n        - $[\\\\mathrm{succinate}]_{mito} = 0.98~\\\\mathrm{mM}$\\n        - $[\\\\mathrm{O}_2] = 80~\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{M}$ (hypoxic aCSF, saturated)\\n        - $K_{m,O_2} = 10~\\\\mu\\\\mathrm{M}$\\n        - $\\\\mathrm{P/O}_{succ} = 1.5$ mol ATP per mol succinate oxidized\\n    - \\n      Total ATP hydrolysis: $J_{hyd} = k_{hyd} \\\\cdot [\\\\mathrm{ATP}]_{ss} \\\\cdot V_{term}$, with $k_{hyd} = 1.30~\\\\mathrm{s}^{-1}$\\n- **Stimulation Parameters:**\\n    - Number of action potentials: $N_{AP} = (250~\\\\mathrm{Hz}) \\\\times (0.120~\\\\mathrm{s}) = 30$\\n    - Vesicle pool replenishment is negligible on this timescale.\\n- **Assumptions:**\\n    - Terminal is in steady-state for ATP before the stimulus.\\n    - All parameters are at 37\u00b0C unless otherwise stated.\\n    - RRP depletion follows simple binomial statistics for $N_{AP}$ trials with probability $p_r$, no replacement.\\n\\n#### Table 1: Key Constants\\n\\n\\\\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}\\n\\\\hline\\nParameter & Value & Units \\\\\\\\\\n\\\\hline\\n$N_{\\\\mathrm{mito}}$ & $1300$ & mitochondria/terminal \\\\\\\\\\n$V_{mito,avg}$ & $0.40/1300$ & pL/mitochondrion \\\\\\\\\\n$V_{term}$ & $4.00$ & pL \\\\\\\\\\n$k_{cat,CII}$ & $80.0$ & s$^{-1}$ \\\\\\\\\\n$[\\\\mathrm{succinate}]_{mito}$ & $0.98$ & mM \\\\\\\\\\n$\\\\mathrm{P/O}_{succ}$ & $1.5$ & mol ATP/mol succinate \\\\\\\\\\n$[\\\\mathrm{O}_2]$ & $80$ & $\\\\mu$M \\\\\\\\\\n$K_{m,O_2}$ & $10$ & $\\\\mu$M \\\\\\\\\\n$J_{gly}$ & $2.1 \\\\times 10^{-18}$ & mol/s \\\\\\\\\\n$k_{hyd}$ & $1.30$ & s$^{-1}$ \\\\\\\\\\n$[\\\\mathrm{ATP}]_{norm}$ & $2.8$ & mM \\\\\\\\\\n\\\\hline\\n\\\\end{tabular}\\n\\n---\\n\\n**Question:**\\n\\nCalculate the *total number of vesicles released from the terminal during the 250 Hz, 120 ms stimulus train*, given these data and assuming all necessary physiological conversions. Round your answer to the nearest integer.\

An in vitro experiment investigates the antigen presentation dynamics of a primary murine conventional dendritic cell (cDC1) line, each cultured singly in a 96-well plate at 37^\\\\circ\\\\mathrm{C} in standard RPMI-1640 medium (glucose 10 mM, L-glutamine 2 mM) supplemented with 10\\\\% FBS and 50 \\\\mu\\\\mathrm{g}/\\\\mathrm{mL} gentamicin. Each well contains 200 \\\\mu\\\\mathrm{L} medium, and every cDC1 is assumed spherical with a cellular volume of 1.2~\\\\mathrm{pL} (picoliters).\\n\\nAt time t = 0, each cDC1 is infected at a multiplicity of infection (MOI) of 10 by a recombinant Influenza A virus encoding nucleoprotein (NP) engineered to present the class I immunodominant peptide SIINFEKL (OVA_{257-264}) within the NP sequence. Upon infection, viral replication and host translation dynamics are as follows:\\n\\n**1. Viral NP Synthesis & Degradation**\\n- After a 600 s eclipse phase, host shut-off commences: host translation drops to 5\\\\% of pre-infection rates while viral translation rises sigmoidally. The intracellular NP concentration at any time t (in seconds, t > 600) is:\\n\\\\[\\n[\\\\mathrm{NP}](t) = \\\\frac{C_{\\\\max}}{1 + e^{-k_{NP}(t-t_{mid})}}\\n\\\\]\\n- C_{\\\\max} = 900 nM, k_{NP} = 3.5 \\\\times 10^{-4}~\\\\mathrm{s}^{-1}, t_{mid} = 10{,}800~\\\\mathrm{s}\\n- NP is uniformly processed by proteasomes to release SIINFEKL with a yield fraction \\\\delta = 0.007 per degraded NP.\\n\\n**2. Competitive Peptide Supply to TAP & ER**\\n- Peptide pool delivered to the ER includes both viral (SIINFEKL) and host-derived peptides. In the infected cell, host peptide supply is 20-fold less than pre-infection.\\n- At t > 600 s, per-cell cytosolic peptide concentrations are:\\n\\\\[\\n[\\\\mathrm{SIINFEKL}](t) = \\\\delta \\\\cdot [\\\\mathrm{NP}](t) \\\\\\\\\\n[\\\\mathrm{HOST}](t) = q_{host} = 80~\\\\mathrm{nM}\\n\\\\]\\n- The TAP transporter follows Michaelis-Menten kinetics for competitive substrates:\\n\\\\[\\nv_{tap,S}(t) = \\\\frac{V_{max} \\\\cdot [S](t)}{K_{m,S}\\\\big(1 + \\\\frac{[H](t)}{K_{m,H}} \\\\big) + [S](t)}\\n\\\\]\\nWhere S = SIINFEKL, H = host peptides. Constants:\\n- V_{max} = 1300 peptides/cell/s\\n- K_{m,S} = 250~\\\\mathrm{nM}, K_{m,H} = 60~\\\\mathrm{nM}\\n\\n**3. Peptide Loading & Complex Stability**\\n- Only TAP-transported peptides enter the ER; they compete for loading onto nascent H-2K^b molecules at the ER (3.5\\\\times 10^{5} H-2K^b/cell/30 min synthesized steadily post-infection).\\n- SIINFEKL loading efficiency is \\\\eta_{S} = 0.18; for HOST, \\\\eta_{H} = 0.11.\\n- The rate of SIINFEKL-H-2K^b complex appearance at the surface is given by transport delay \\\\tau_{ves} = 1500~\\\\mathrm{s}:\\n\\\\[\\nJ_{surf,S}(t) = \\\\eta_{S} \\\\cdot v_{tap,S}(t - \\\\tau_{ves})\\n\\\\]\\n- H-2K^b/SIINFEKL complexes decay with k_{deg,S} = 6.0 \\\\times 10^{-5}~\\\\mathrm{s}^{-1}.\\n\\n**4. Initial & Boundary Conditions**\\n- At t < 600 s: [NP](t) = 0, v_{tap,S}(t) = 0.\\n- For all t: N_{S}(t=0) = 0.\\n- Ignore allelic variants, all host peptides are functionally equivalent.\\n\\n**Question:**\\nUsing the provided parameters and explicit cell volume, calculate the **total number of H-2K^b/SIINFEKL complexes present on the surface of one cDC1 cell at t = 18{,}000~\\\\mathrm{s}** (5 h post-infection), rounded to the nearest integer. You must show all steps needed to unambiguously arrive at the answer, including conversion between per-cell concentrations and numbers of molecules (Avogadro's number: 6.022 \\\\times 10^{23}/\\\\mathrm{mol}).\\n\\n\\\\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}\\n\\\\hline\\nQuantity & Symbol & Value \\\\\\\\\\n\\\\hline\\ncDC1 cytosolic volume & V_{cell} & 1.2~\\\\mathrm{pL} \\\\\\\\\\nAvogadro's number     & N_A      & 6.022 \\\\times 10^{23}/\\\\mathrm{mol} \\\\\\\\\\nMax NP concentration  & C_{max}  & 900~\\\\mathrm{nM} \\\\\\\\\\nTAP maximum rate      & V_{max}  & 1300~\\\\mathrm{pept}/cell/s \\\\\\\\\\nNP to SIINFEKL yield  & \\\\delta   & 0.007 \\\\\\\\\\nTAP K_m, SIINFEKL     & K_{m,S}  & 250~\\\\mathrm{nM} \\\\\\\\\\nTAP K_m, HOST peptide & K_{m,H}  & 60~\\\\mathrm{nM} \\\\\\\\\\nHOST peptide concentration & q_{host} & 80~\\\\mathrm{nM} \\\\\\\\\\nLoading eff., SIINFEKL & \\\\eta_{S} & 0.18 \\\\\\\\\\nComplex decay, SIINFEKL & k_{deg,S} & 6.0\\\\times 10^{-5}~\\\\mathrm{s}^{-1} \\\\\\\\\\nTransport delay       & \\\\tau_{ves} & 1500~\\\\mathrm{s} \\\\\\\\\\n\\\\hline\\n\\\\end{tabular}\
